Speaker: NA
Text: UNIFORM TAXATION.

Speaker: Mr WILSON
Text: M y question is directed

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Prime Minister. In view of the

Speaker: NA
Text: statement of the Premier of New South

Speaker: NA
Text: Wales that he is now willing to join the

Speaker: NA
Text: Premier of Victoria in challenging the

Speaker: NA
Text: uniform tax act, and in view of the fact

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Premier of South Australia has tently,

Speaker: NA
Text: consistently asked for the return of taxing

Speaker: NA
Text: powers to his State and, further, in view

Speaker: NA
Text: the statement of the Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: the Treasurer that the Commonwealth is

Speaker: NA
Text: willing to return the taxing powers to the

Speaker: NA
Text: States, will the Government now intro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duce legislation to repeal the uniform tax

Speaker: NA
Text: act in order to give the States the respon-

Speaker: NA
Text: sibihty of collecting the revenues that they

Speaker: NA
Text: spend?

Speaker: Mr MENZIES
Text: Th e abolition of the

Speaker: NA
Text: uniform tax law is something which ought

Speaker: NA
Text: in the not to be undertaken except on a broad

Speaker: NA
Text: of agreement with the State Premiers.

Speaker: NA
Text: of In other words, uniform tax cannot be

Speaker: NA
Text: in one State and not in another,

Speaker: NA
Text: the and we must have a co-operative approach

Speaker: NA
Text: this matter. The simple truth is that the

Speaker: NA
Text: interests of the taxpayers, of whom there

Speaker: NA
Text: are many hundreds of thousands in Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: must be considered. We do not want

Speaker: NA
Text: a multiplicity of tax laws, if we can avoid

Speaker: NA
Text: We want a good, sensible system

Speaker: NA
Text: will work. We have repeatedly stated

Speaker: NA
Text: views on this matter at conferences with

Speaker: NA
Text: the State Premiers. I do not think that

Speaker: NA
Text: the attitude of any one of the Premiers

Speaker: NA
Text: should be over-simplified. We stand by the

Speaker: NA
Text: statements that I have made in the past.

Speaker: NA
Text: If and when the Premiers are prepared to

Speaker: NA
Text: agree to a return of their taxing powers on

Speaker: NA
Text: terms which meet the various conditions

Speaker: NA
Text: that I have stated, this Government will be

Speaker: NA
Text: to take the necessary steps. Per-

Speaker: NA
Text: haps I ought to take advantage of this

Speaker: NA
Text: to point out to honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: prebers that the question of policy as to

Speaker: NA
Text: whether there should be a return of taxing

Speaker: NA
Text: to the States is quite different from

Speaker: NA
Text: legal question-whic h is now being

Speaker: NA
Text: depuapproached, I gather-a s to whether this

Speaker: NA
Text: I Parliament has the power to pass a uniform

Speaker: NA
Text: in taxation law. I want to keep those two

Speaker: NA
Text: in separate compartments. We can-

Speaker: NA
Text: in not interpret the Commonwealth Constitu-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion by consent. No doubt the High Court

Speaker: NA
Text: will give its view on the legal issue in due

Speaker: NA
Text: course. On the matter of policy, I have

Speaker: NA
Text: nothing to state in modification of the views

Speaker: NA
Text: which I have expressed on behalf of this

Speaker: NA
Text: Government to Premiers conferences more

Speaker: NA
Text: than once, but I suggest to my friend, the

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member for Sturt, that we can-

Speaker: NA
Text: not operate on the basis of one, two, or

Speaker: NA
Text: three of the Premiers being in that mood.

Speaker: NA
Text: Indeed, I venture to suggest that, inadver-

Speaker: NA
Text: he has rather over-simplified the view

Speaker: NA
Text: of my friend, the Premier of South Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: of tralia. His view has never seemed to mc

Speaker: NA
Text: and to be quite so simple as that.

Speaker: NA
Text: TELEPHONE SERVICES.

Speaker: Mr COSTA
Text: I n answer to a question

Speaker: NA
Text: last week, the Postmaster-General stated

Speaker: NA
Text: lhat 85,000 applications for telephone ser-

Speaker: NA
Text: vices in Australia were outstanding. Will

Speaker: NA
Text: he inform the House now whether the

Speaker: NA
Text: amendment of the regulations has been

Speaker: NA
Text: made which will have the effect of inflicting

Speaker: NA
Text: a £10 installation fee on all new applicants

Speaker: NA
Text: for telephones? Will the Minister say how

Speaker: NA
Text: many of the 85,000 outstanding applica-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions are regarded as new applications? I

Speaker: NA
Text: understand that most of the applicants have

Speaker: NA
Text: been waiting for several years for a tele-

Speaker: NA
Text: phone service. In answer to a previous

Speaker: NA
Text: question on this matter, the Minister said

Speaker: NA
Text: that if a proposal had already been made to

Speaker: NA
Text: an applicant regarding the installation oi

Speaker: NA
Text: a telephone, the installation fee would not

Speaker: NA
Text: be charged. Will the Minister state what he

Speaker: NA
Text: means by " a proposal"?

Speaker: Mr DAVIDSON
Text: Th e regulations that

Speaker: NA
Text: will vary telephone charges and other

Speaker: NA
Text: charges made by the Postal Department

Speaker: NA
Text: have been promulgated. There were 86,000

Speaker: NA
Text: outstanding applications at that time. I do

Speaker: NA
Text: not quite know what the honorable member

Speaker: NA
Text: means when he asks me to say how many

Speaker: NA
Text: of them are regarded as new applications.

Speaker: NA
Text: With regard to the £10 installation fee,

Speaker: NA
Text: the position is as I have stated it previously

Speaker: NA
Text: to the House. In all cases where an appli-

Speaker: NA
Text: cation has been processed by the depart-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment to the extent that the department

Speaker: NA
Text: has made a proposal to the prospective

Speaker: NA
Text: subscriber indicating what the rental of

Speaker: NA
Text: the telephone will be, and has received from

Speaker: NA
Text: him a notification of acceptance of the

Speaker: NA
Text: department's terms, and where the prospec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive subscriber has paid the first year's

Speaker: NA
Text: rental before 1st October, the installation

Speaker: NA
Text: tee of £10 will not be charged. We found

Speaker: NA
Text: during the last week or two weeks that some

Speaker: NA
Text: applicants who had had telephones installed

Speaker: NA
Text: did not know whether an installation fee

Speaker: NA
Text: of £10 was payable. I have found one or

Speaker: NA
Text: two instances of the fees having been asked

Speaker: NA
Text: for, really inadvertently, and I have issued

Speaker: NA
Text: instructions that the statement I made in

Speaker: NA
Text: this House stands. If there has been any

Speaker: NA
Text: case in the last week or two of the fee of

Speaker: NA
Text: £10 having been asked for and paid when

Speaker: NA
Text: the rental has been paid before 1st October,

Speaker: NA
Text: each such payment would be refunded. I

Speaker: NA
Text: want to make clear that what I have said

Speaker: NA
Text: in the House about the date from which

Speaker: NA
Text: this fee applies will stand, and that there

Speaker: NA
Text: will be no departure from it.

Speaker: NA
Text: SUEZ CANAL.

Speaker: Mr KENT HUGHES
Text: I direct a ques-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion to the Minister for External Affairs.

Speaker: NA
Text: Is there any later information he can give

Speaker: NA
Text: to the House with respect to the discussions

Speaker: NA
Text: in the United Nations on the Suez ques-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion, additional to what has been published

Speaker: NA
Text: in the press?

Speaker: Mr CASEY
Text: Yes , in the last 24 hours

Speaker: NA
Text: a number of countries have expressed

Speaker: NA
Text: themselves in the Security Council in re-

Speaker: NA
Text: spect of the Suez matter, and 1 would

Speaker: NA
Text: expect that just about now the Security

Speaker: NA
Text: Council is going into secret session. Dur-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing yesterday, Australian time, a number

Speaker: NA
Text: of countries expressed themselves on the

Speaker: NA
Text: matter. Iran said, in effect, that the draft

Speaker: NA
Text: resolution-tha t is, the British-French

Speaker: NA
Text: resolution-deserve d support in principle

Speaker: NA
Text: as a possible basis for peaceful negotiation

Speaker: NA
Text: Belgium said, in brief, that Egypt's disre-

Speaker: NA
Text: gard of the 1951 resolution of the council

Speaker: NA
Text: regarding the blockade against Israel made

Speaker: NA
Text: it clear that the canal should not be left

Speaker: NA
Text: solely under Egyptian control. The seizure

Speaker: NA
Text: of the canal, it said, was a clear violation of

Speaker: NA
Text: ihe 1888 convention. Nationalist China

Speaker: NA
Text: said that the users of the canal could have

Speaker: NA
Text: some measure and form of participation in

Speaker: NA
Text: its operation without violating Egypt's

Speaker: NA
Text: sovereignty. Pera said that there should be

Speaker: NA
Text: negotiations based on the principles of the

Speaker: NA
Text: United Nations Charter. Dr Ronald

Speaker: NA
Text: Walker, speaking for Australia, said thai

Speaker: NA
Text: Egypt's repudiation of the Suez Canal con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cession, without consultation or agreement,

Speaker: NA
Text: was a breach of international law which,

Speaker: NA
Text: if condoned, could lead to the encourage-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of further acts of lawlessness, and

Speaker: NA
Text: that Egypt's record in the Security Council

Speaker: NA
Text: was not good-fo r example. Egypt had

Speaker: NA
Text: disregarded the 1951 and 1954 Security

Speaker: NA
Text: Council resolutions against the Egyptian

Speaker: NA
Text: blockade directed against Israel. He said

Speaker: NA
Text: that the canal was of great importance to

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, and that Egypt's action in seiz-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the canal, unless remedied, was likely

Speaker: NA
Text: to have wide repercussions on the inter-

Speaker: NA
Text: national flow of capital to under-developed

Speaker: NA
Text: countries, and might result in a serious set-

Speaker: NA
Text: back to the whole process of co-operative

Speaker: NA
Text: world economic development. Dr Walker

Speaker: NA
Text: also said that Australia was ready to partici-

Speaker: NA
Text: pate constructively in whatever negotiations

Speaker: NA
Text: might be possible. He said that Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: would, of course, support the draft resolu-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion proposed by the United Kingdom and

Speaker: NA
Text: France. We have not yet received any

Speaker: NA
Text: news of what the representatives of Yugo-

Speaker: NA
Text: slavia and the United States of America

Speaker: NA
Text: said yesterday, although presumably they

Speaker: NA
Text: would have stated their views by this time.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, as I informed the House pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: viously, the United States announced its

Speaker: NA
Text: support for the United Kingdom-French

Speaker: NA
Text: draft resolution last week. That is all of a

Speaker: NA
Text: positive nature that I am able to report in

Speaker: NA
Text: respect of developments in the last three or

Speaker: NA
Text: four hours.

Speaker: NA
Text: not think it is true that films of a sadistic

Text: been passed by the Commonwealth Film

Text: Censorship Board as being fit at least

Speaker: NA
Text: shown to adults. In the second place,

Speaker: NA
Text: so many things in our federal system,

Speaker: NA
Text: authority to deal with films is divided

Text: between the Commonwealth and State to

Text: Governments. The Commonwealth Goof

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment is responsible for censoring

Text: adults ", or " suitable for adults only ". The

Speaker: NA
Text: be allowed into cinemas showing films

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot emphasize too strongly that this

Text: Government has no authority at all to pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: vent any child from entering into a cinema

Speaker: NA
Text: Ausshowing a classified film.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr J. R. Fraser -Excep t in its own

Speaker: Mr OSBORNE
Text: 1 accept the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member's qualification. The only other

Text: comment I can usefully make at this stage

Text: children ". 1 will certainly have that sug-

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: children they develop a disinclination to

Speaker: NA
Text: and see it. That is only one aspect of

Speaker: NA
Text: " C " to SUBSIDIES FOR PRIMARY PRODUCTS.

Speaker: Mr LUCOCK
Text: I preface my question

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Minister for Primary Industry by

Speaker: NA
Text: out that it is acknowledged that

Speaker: NA
Text: the main answer to our balance of pay-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments problem is increased exports. While

Speaker: NA
Text: I think all would agree that subsidies are

Speaker: NA
Text: not a complete answer, I ask the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: he will consider investigating the

Speaker: NA
Text: possibility of increasing subsidies, at least

Speaker: NA
Text: as a temporary expedient, on certain of our

Speaker: NA
Text: I do primary products, thus enabling those

Speaker: NA
Text: primary industries to compete more favor-

Speaker: NA
Text: ably on the overseas markets and thus

Speaker: NA
Text: here has increase our export income.

Speaker: Mr MCMAHON
Text: Th e suggestion made

Speaker: NA
Text: to be by the honorable member for Lyne is not

Speaker: NA
Text: like a novel one. I agree with him that one

Speaker: NA
Text: the of the answers to Australia's export or

Speaker: NA
Text: overseas balance of payments problem is

Speaker: NA
Text: increase our exports, particularly exports

Speaker: NA
Text: our primary industries. However, as to

Speaker: NA
Text: subsidies, I do not think the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: so could give very much more consideration

Speaker: NA
Text: this matter and hope to come out with

Speaker: NA
Text: a favorable reply. In the case of a country

Speaker: NA
Text: like Australia, which is perhaps the greatest

Speaker: NA
Text: trading country in the world per head of

Speaker: NA
Text: population, two things could happen: First,

Speaker: NA
Text: we might embark on a trade war with com-

Speaker: NA
Text: petitors who are much stronger than we,

Speaker: NA
Text: and therefore our prospects of success

Speaker: NA
Text: would be remote; and second, we could

Speaker: NA
Text: grant subsidies, but I cannot think at the

Speaker: NA
Text: present time that subsidies would be the

Speaker: NA
Text: answer to this question, particularly when

Speaker: NA
Text: we are complaining so bitterly about sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: sidies being given by other countries to

Speaker: NA
Text: their export industries. I assure the honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able gentleman that this problem has

Speaker: NA
Text: received very careful consideration by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government, but it has been decided that

Speaker: NA
Text: it would not be in our best interests to

Speaker: NA
Text: follow the course of action that he suggests.

Speaker: NA
Text: RADIO AUSTRALIA.

Speaker: Mr WENTWORTH
Text: Ca n the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for External Affairs tell the House whether

Speaker: NA
Text: any progress has been made with the

Speaker: NA
Text: casting of programmes in Mandarin

Speaker: NA
Text: Chinese from Radio Australia?

Speaker: Mr CASEY
Text: I should think that this

Speaker: NA
Text: question, perhaps, should be more properly

Speaker: NA
Text: directed to my friend and colleague, the latest.

Speaker: NA
Text: Postmaster-General, or, even, possibly, to

Speaker: NA
Text: both of us. The Postmaster-General and

Speaker: NA
Text: the Postal Department have what might be

Speaker: NA
Text: called executive charge of the running of

Speaker: NA
Text: Radio Australia, but since the Department

Speaker: NA
Text: of External Affairs is very interested,

Speaker: NA
Text: indeed I am, too, in Radio Australia,

Speaker: NA
Text: perhaps I might be allowed to answer

Speaker: NA
Text: the question. For just over three months,

Speaker: NA
Text: a programme in Mandarin Chinese has been

Speaker: NA
Text: broadcast over Radio Australia. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: additional to the programmes in English.

Speaker: NA
Text: French, Thai and Indonesian. It is a new

Speaker: NA
Text: service and lasts for an hour a day every

Speaker: NA
Text: day. It is done entirely in Mandarin

Speaker: NA
Text: Chinese, which is, I understand, the princi-

Speaker: NA
Text: pal language of educated overseas Chinese,

Speaker: NA
Text: particularly in South-East Asia. The popu-

Speaker: NA
Text: larity of the broadcast has been reflected in

Speaker: NA
Text: the fact that a substantial " fan " mail of

Speaker: NA
Text: considerably more than 1,500 letters has

Speaker: NA
Text: been received since this service started. As

Speaker: NA
Text: I said, the broadcast lasts for one hour a

Speaker: NA
Text: day. Of that time, about twelve minutes

Speaker: NA
Text: is devoted to news, about five minutes to

Speaker: NA
Text: comments on news and the remainder to a

Speaker: NA
Text: series of commentaries generally on the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian way of life and on matters of possible

Speaker: NA
Text: interest between overseas Chinese in South-

Speaker: NA
Text: East Asia and ourselves. I think the ser-

Speaker: NA
Text: 1 vice has been well justified and I hope that

Speaker: NA
Text: it will not remain static in its present form,

Speaker: NA
Text: to but will progress and expand.

Text: tee caused by the resignation of the chair-

Text: man of the committee, Senator-no w Mr.

Text: that there will be no undue delay in filling

Text: the vacancy, thus allowing the committee

Speaker: NA
Text: UNIFORM TAXATION.

Speaker: Mr FREETH
Text: I wish to ask the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister a question on the subject of uni-

Speaker: NA
Text: form taxation which is supplementary to

Speaker: NA
Text: as that asked by the honorable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Sturt. Has the right honorable gentleman

Speaker: NA
Text: seen a proposal that the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: should return some limited taxing rights to

Speaker: NA
Text: (he States instead of making a tax reim-

Speaker: NA
Text: bursement supplementary to the reimburse-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment under the formula, and allowing the

Speaker: NA
Text: States, if they think fit. to raise, by means

Speaker: NA
Text: of such transferred taxing powers, the

Speaker: NA
Text: extra amount of money that they require

Speaker: NA
Text: over and above the amount received by way

Speaker: NA
Text: of formula reimbursement provided they

Speaker: NA
Text: use the Commonwealth assessment legisla-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion? Will the right honorable gentleman

Speaker: NA
Text: consider this proposal, which, I think, was

Speaker: NA
Text: first outlined in an article that appeared

Speaker: NA
Text: in the " Economic Record " of May last?

Speaker: NA
Text: The suggestion seems to me to have some

Speaker: NA
Text: merit. If the Prime Minister considers

Speaker: NA
Text: that it has, will he discuss it with the State

Speaker: NA
Text: Premiers?

Speaker: Mr MENZIES
Text: I n spite of my

Speaker: NA
Text: advanced years I have a lively recollection

Speaker: NA
Text: of 1934, when, as Acting Premier of Vic-

Speaker: NA
Text: toria, I advanced a similar proposal, at

Speaker: NA
Text: a Premiers conference, to that outlined by

Speaker: NA
Text: the honorable member. My clear recol-

Speaker: NA
Text: lection is that it was not very well received,

Speaker: NA
Text: and I am very interested to hear that the

Speaker: NA
Text: proposal has been resuscitated. I am pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: pared, of course, to consider to-day what

Speaker: NA
Text: I advocated 22 years ago, but the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member will, of course, realize that the

Speaker: NA
Text: problem is a pretty complex one. I and my

Speaker: NA
Text: colleagues have, from first to last, wished

Speaker: NA
Text: io devise a system under which the restora-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of taxing authority to the States would

Speaker: NA
Text: be accompanied by as great a degree of

Speaker: NA
Text: uniformity as possible, so that there would

Speaker: NA
Text: not be a duplication of returns or a multi-

Speaker: NA
Text: plicity of conflicting laws. We stand ready

Speaker: NA
Text: at all times to consider any suggestion along

Speaker: NA
Text: those lines. No State has, in what are

Speaker: NA
Text: termed modern times, put forward a sug-

Speaker: NA
Text: gestion that it should be given some form

Speaker: NA
Text: of taxing power now exclusive to the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth. As the honorable member

Speaker: NA
Text: clearly understands, of course, any proposal

Speaker: NA
Text: that a particular kind of tax now exclusive

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Commonwealth should be made

Speaker: NA
Text: available to the States would involve a con-

Speaker: NA
Text: stitutional amendment, to which the people

Speaker: NA
Text: would have to agree, and experience does

Speaker: NA
Text: not suggest that people vote very heartily in

Speaker: NA
Text: favour of proposals that some one else

Speaker: NA
Text: should have a chance to tax them. That

Speaker: NA
Text: seems to me to be one of the facts of life,

Speaker: NA
Text: but hope springs eternal, and I am always

Speaker: NA
Text: prepared to try anything.

Text: time, and that people may conclude that a

Text: department which takes four years to settle

Text: a simple question is hardly to be trusted

Speaker: NA
Text: with the proper mobilization of Australia's

Speaker: NA
Text: defences?

Speaker: Mr CRAMER
Text: M y great regret is that

Speaker: NA
Text: the bonorable member has not mentioned

Speaker: NA
Text: this matter to me before to-day. I should

Speaker: NA
Text: have been very pleased to look into it, and

Speaker: NA
Text: I am confident that it could have been satis-

Speaker: NA
Text: factorily explained. As it has its origin

Speaker: NA
Text: in the past, I have no knowledge of it.

Speaker: NA
Text: I may say that, in my experience, the

Text: Army has always been co-operative in

Text: matters of this kind, and I am sure that

Text: there must be some other aspect that the

Text: honorable member has not mentioned. I

Speaker: NA
Text: shall certainly investigate it to see what can

Speaker: NA
Text: be 'done, and can promise the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member an early reply.

Text: appropriate body to examine the possibility

Text: ALLEGED ILLEGAL ENTRY OF

Text: for Labour and National Service and

Text: Minister for Immigration) -b y leave-

Speaker: NA
Text: Yesterday, the honorable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Text: being illegally admitted into Australia. I

Text: said that I would make a report to the

Text: Parliament on the matter raised by him

Speaker: NA
Text: number of newspapers that there is a wide-

Speaker: NA
Text: spread smuggling ring to get migrants

Text: illegally into Australia. These allegations

Text: views with an Italian woman described by

Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: were brought to my notice, I stated that the

Text: report. It shows that the allegations are

Text: mation of honorable members and for the

Text: public, the full text of the report.

Text: Since the report was prepared, I have

Speaker: NA
Text: considered the case of the woman, called

Speaker: NA
Text: Carla " in the newspaper article. As will

Text: be clear from the report, she is an illegal

Text: entrant to Australia, as she deserted the ship country illegally.

Speaker: NA
Text: on which she was employed. She has a

Speaker: NA
Text: husband and three children in Italy. In

Text: all the circumstances, I have decided that

Speaker: NA
Text: <ihe should be required to leave Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: The woman had been issued with a cer-

Speaker: NA
Text: tificate of exemption, valid for a period of

Speaker: NA
Text: six months. This is a normal procedure

Speaker: NA
Text: which does not necessarily imply that the

Speaker: NA
Text: person concerned is to be allowed to stay

Speaker: NA
Text: for the full period stated in the certificate.

Speaker: NA
Text: I feel it necessary to emphasize

Speaker: NA
Text: minence has been given by at least one

Speaker: NA
Text: newspaper to the fact of the issue of an

Speaker: NA
Text: exemption certificate for that period, and

Speaker: NA
Text: it has been taken as signifying that she

Speaker: NA
Text: will be permitted to remain in Australia for

Speaker: NA
Text: atleast that time. This does not follow.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am empowered by the Immigration

Speaker: NA
Text: Act to cancel the certificate of exemption

Speaker: NA
Text: at any time, and, upon doing so, to issue stances, I move-

Speaker: NA
Text: a deportation order. If certificates were

Speaker: NA
Text: issued for muchshorter periods, for

Speaker: NA
Text: example, a week or a month, the necessity

Speaker: NA
Text: would arise in some cases for extension

Speaker: NA
Text: while a passage is being arranged for the

Speaker: NA
Text: person concerned, or while inquiries are in

Speaker: NA
Text: progress. It is important that certificates

Speaker: NA
Text: should not be allowed to expire because

Speaker: NA
Text: power to deport under the section of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Immigration Act by which they are issued

Speaker: NA
Text: can disappear if the exemption is not kept

Speaker: NA
Text: current. The appropriate action will now

Speaker: NA
Text: be taken to cancel the exemption and to

Speaker: NA
Text: arrange for deportation.

Speaker: NA
Text: It will be evident to honorable members

Speaker: NA
Text: when they read the report of the Departacceptance

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of Immigration that not only is there

Speaker: NA
Text: no substance in the allegations, but they

Speaker: NA
Text: have been based on information supplied by

Speaker: NA
Text: what can only be regarded on the facts as

Speaker: NA
Text: now known as very unreliable sources.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is to be hoped that the same promin-

Speaker: NA
Text: ence will be given by the press to the facts

Speaker: NA
Text: as they now appear as was given in the

Speaker: NA
Text: first instance to allegations which reflected

Speaker: NA
Text: on the conduct of members of the Vic-

Speaker: NA
Text: torian Police Force and officers of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Department of Immigration. Justice de-

Speaker: NA
Text: mands that it be made abundantly clear

Speaker: NA
Text: that no irregularity of any kind can be attri-

Speaker: NA
Text: buted to any one of them, nor is there any

Speaker: NA
Text: evidence of an organized racket of migrant

Speaker: NA
Text: smuggling into this country. We, in Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia, can expect attempts to enter this

Speaker: NA
Text: Other countries of

Speaker: NA
Text: attraction to migrants, such as Canada and

Speaker: NA
Text: the United States, experience these diffi-

Speaker: NA
Text: culties also, but the department has its own

Speaker: NA
Text: methods of checking illegal entry and deal-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing promptly and effectively with such cases

Speaker: NA
Text: as occur.

Speaker: NA
Text: I lay on the table the following paper:-

Speaker: NA
Text: Migrants-Allege d Illegal Entry-Departmenta l

Speaker: NA
Text: Report.

Speaker: Dr EVATT
Text: Wil l the Minister move that

Speaker: NA
Text: this, as prothe paper be printed?

Speaker: Mr HAROLD HOLT
Text: I have no objec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion if an opportunity for discussion is

Speaker: NA
Text: desired.

Speaker: Dr EVATT
Text: I t is quite clear that what

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister has tabled is a portion of more

Speaker: NA
Text: extensive documents, and there may be

Speaker: NA
Text: some occasion for comment on it later.

Speaker: Mr HAROLD HOLT
Text: I n the circum-

Speaker: NA
Text: That the paper be printed.

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate (on motion by Dr Evatt)

Speaker: NA
Text: adjourned.

Speaker: NA
Text: ASSENT TO BILLS.

Speaker: NA
Text: Assent to fhe following bills reported:-

Speaker: NA
Text: Social Services Bill 1956.

Speaker: NA
Text: Repatriation Bill 1956.

Speaker: NA
Text: INTERNATIONAL WHEAT

Speaker: NA
Text: AGREEMENT BILL 1956.

Speaker: NA
Text: Motion (by Mr MCMahon)-b y leave-

Speaker: NA
Text: agreed to-

Speaker: NA
Text: That leave be given to bring in a bill to approve

Speaker: NA
Text: by Australia of the International Wheat

Speaker: NA
Text: Agreement 1956, and for otber purposes.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill presented, and read a first time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading.

Speaker: Mr MCMAHON
Text: Lowe-Ministe r for

Speaker: NA
Text: Primary Industry) [3.23J -b y leave- I

Speaker: NA
Text: move-

Speaker: NA
Text: That the bill be now read a second tune.

Speaker: NA
Text: The purpose of this bill is to seek the

Speaker: NA
Text: approval of Parliament for the ratification

Speaker: NA
Text: by Australia of the International Wheat

Speaker: NA
Text: Agreement 1956. Honorable members will

Speaker: NA
Text: recall that the first post-war International

Speaker: NA
Text: Wheat Agreement came into force in 1949,

Speaker: NA
Text: and covered a four-year period up to 31st

Speaker: NA
Text: July, 1953. That agreement was renewed,

Speaker: NA
Text: with certain modifications, by the three-year

Speaker: NA
Text: International Wheat Agreement of 1953,

Speaker: NA
Text: which expired on 31st July of this year.

Speaker: NA
Text: The 1956 agreement, to which this bill

Speaker: NA
Text: relates, provides for a further three-yea;

Speaker: NA
Text: extension, with some amendments, of the

Speaker: NA
Text: arrangements covered by the two earlier

Speaker: NA
Text: agreements. Copies of the new agreement

Speaker: NA
Text: have been distributed to honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers for their information and reference.

Speaker: NA
Text: The text of this agreement was negotiated

Speaker: NA
Text: at a special United Nations Wheat Confer-

Speaker: NA
Text: ence, which met in October-November,

Speaker: NA
Text: 1955, and again during February-April,

Speaker: NA
Text: 1956. The entry into force of the agree-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment was made conditional upon it being

Speaker: NA
Text: signed and ratified by governments of coun-

Speaker: NA
Text: tries responsible for a prescribed proportion

Speaker: NA
Text: of the volume of wheat covered by its pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: visions concerning guaranteed purchases

Speaker: NA
Text: and sales. Following the negotiations, Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia became a signatory to the new agree-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, as did also 39 other countries. How-

Speaker: NA
Text: ever, signature did not in any final manner

Speaker: NA
Text: commit Australia or any other country to

Speaker: NA
Text: adherence to the agreement, which is depen-

Speaker: NA
Text: dent upon the deposit before 1st December,

Speaker: NA
Text: 1956, of a formal instrument of acceptance,

Speaker: NA
Text: or ratification, in accordance with the con-

Speaker: NA
Text: stitutional or legislative requirements of

Speaker: NA
Text: each individual country. In conformity

Speaker: NA
Text: with the practice followed in respect of the

Speaker: NA
Text: two earlier agreements, the Government is

Speaker: NA
Text: now seeking parliamentary approval for the

Speaker: NA
Text: lodgment ot an instrument of acceptance

Speaker: NA
Text: to permit Australia's participation in the

Speaker: NA
Text: agreement.

Speaker: NA
Text: In principle, the new agreement is idenprices

Speaker: NA
Text: tical with its predecessors, which have

Speaker: NA
Text: operated for seven years. As the arrangeaccount

Speaker: NA
Text: ment is well known to honorable members.

Speaker: NA
Text: and to Australian wheat-growers, it is, I

Speaker: NA
Text: believe, unnecessary for me to elaborate on

Speaker: NA
Text: the general nature of the agreement and

Speaker: NA
Text: its historical background. The basic objec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tives are defined in article I . as being " to

Speaker: NA
Text: assure supplies of wheat to importing coun-

Speaker: NA
Text: tries and markets for wheat to exporting

Speaker: NA
Text: countries at equitable and stable prices ".

Speaker: NA
Text: They must be regarded as very worthy

Speaker: NA
Text: objectives in relation to . a commodity

Speaker: NA
Text: which, in times when no international

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme operated, was notorious for the

Speaker: NA
Text: violent manner in which its prices fluctuated.

Speaker: NA
Text: The agreement attempts to achieve its

Speaker: NA
Text: objectives by provisions governing both

Speaker: NA
Text: prices and quantities. Maximum and

Speaker: NA
Text: minimum prices are stated, and transac-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions under the agreement must be within

Speaker: NA
Text: the prescribed price range. For each

Speaker: NA
Text: importing member country there is a quota,

Speaker: NA
Text: or " guaranteed quantity ", which it may be

Speaker: NA
Text: required to purchase at the minimum

Speaker: NA
Text: price, or which exporting countries may be

Speaker: NA
Text: required to sell to it at the maximum price.

Speaker: NA
Text: Similarly, for each exporting member

Speaker: NA
Text: country there is a quota which it may be

Speaker: NA
Text: required to sell at the maximum price, or

Speaker: NA
Text: which importing countries may be required

Speaker: NA
Text: to purchase from it at the minimum price.

Speaker: NA
Text: The experience of the last seven years

Speaker: NA
Text: demonstrates that these arrangements work

Speaker: NA
Text: satisfactorily in practice, and go a long way

Speaker: NA
Text: towards providing a reasonable degree of

Speaker: NA
Text: stability in the international wheat trade.

Speaker: NA
Text: Although similar to the 1.953 agreement

Speaker: NA
Text: in principle, the new agreement differs from

Speaker: NA
Text: it in two important points of detail. The

Speaker: NA
Text: first concerns the basic maximum and

Speaker: NA
Text: minimum prices which, in the new agree-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, are 2 dollars and 1.50 dollars respec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tively, on the basis of No. 1 Manitoba

Speaker: NA
Text: Northern wheat in bulk in store Fort

Speaker: NA
Text: William/Port Arthur, the main shipping

Speaker: NA
Text: points for Canadian wheat. These basic

Speaker: NA
Text: prices are 5 cents lower, in each case, than

Speaker: NA
Text: the prices specified in the 1953 agreement,

Speaker: NA
Text: reflecting to some extent, but by no means

Speaker: NA
Text: wholly, the decline which has occurred in

Speaker: NA
Text: wheat prices since the last agreement was

Speaker: NA
Text: negotiated. The new agreement includes

Speaker: NA
Text: the same formulas as did the 1953 Inter-

Speaker: NA
Text: national Wheat Agreement for determining

Speaker: NA
Text: the equivalent maximum and minimum

Speaker: NA
Text: for wheat shipped from other export-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing countries. These formulas take into

Speaker: NA
Text: differences in transportation costs,

Speaker: NA
Text: the relative qualities of various types of

Speaker: NA
Text: wheat, and different currencies. The under-

Speaker: NA
Text: lying principle is that wheat sold at the

Speaker: NA
Text: maximum or minimum prices in the

Speaker: NA
Text: difierent exporting countries should be com-

Speaker: NA
Text: petitive, one with another, in the various

Speaker: NA
Text: markets, thereby conforming to com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mercial practice. In the case of Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: f.a.q. wheat, the new maximum price is

Speaker: NA
Text: equivalent to 18s. a bushel, f.o.b. Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian ports. The equivalent minimum

Speaker: NA
Text: price for Australian wheat will vary from

Speaker: NA
Text: time to time in accordance with movements

Speaker: NA
Text: in transportation costs, but on the basis of

Speaker: NA
Text: current freights is about 12s. a bushel,

Speaker: NA
Text: f.o.b. eastern Australian ports. The figures

Speaker: NA
Text: I have quoted as the equivalent maximum

Speaker: NA
Text: and minimum prices for Australian wheat

Speaker: NA
Text: are, in each case, subject to such allow-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance as may be agreed between Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: and the importing country concerned to

Speaker: NA
Text: take account of differences in wheat quality.

Speaker: NA
Text: The second point on which the new

Speaker: NA
Text: agreement differs from the last is in respect

Speaker: NA
Text: of membership and guaranteed quantities.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the 1953 International Wheat Agreement,

Speaker: NA
Text: 44 importing countries participated, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: volume of wheat covered by the importers'

Speaker: NA
Text: quotas amounted to 395,000,000 bushels.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the new agreement, as negotiated, 44

Speaker: NA
Text: importing countries again submitted figures

Speaker: NA
Text: for inclusion, but, in many cases, the quotas

Speaker: NA
Text: which they were willing to subscribe were

Speaker: NA
Text: substantially less than their commitments

Speaker: NA
Text: under the 1953 agreement. In consequence,

Speaker: NA
Text: the total quantity covered by the importers'

Speaker: NA
Text: side of the agreement has been reduced by

Speaker: NA
Text: almost a quarter, to 303,000,000 bushels.

Speaker: NA
Text: To some extent, those reductions reflect a

Speaker: NA
Text: growing dependence upon domestic produc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion, often stimulated by high support

Speaker: NA
Text: prices. In some cases, too, the quantities

Speaker: NA
Text: for which particular countries were pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: pared to subscribe were undoubtedly in-

Speaker: NA
Text: fluenced by their hopes or expectations of

Speaker: NA
Text: securing wheat outside the agreement under

Speaker: NA
Text: one or another of the United States pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: grammes for the disposal of accumulated

Speaker: NA
Text: wheat stocks.

Speaker: NA
Text: On the exporting side, the new agree-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment is significantly different. In the first

Speaker: NA
Text: two International Wheat Agreements, the

Speaker: NA
Text: main exporting member countries were the

Speaker: NA
Text: United States, Canada, and Australia,

Speaker: NA
Text: whilst France, though a member, had only

Speaker: NA
Text: a nominal quota. On this occasion,

Speaker: NA
Text: Argentina and Sweden have joined as ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: porting members, and France, which since

Speaker: NA
Text: 1953 has emerged as a substantial wheat

Speaker: NA
Text: exporter in normal seasons, is included with

Speaker: NA
Text: a significant quota. The effect of these two

Speaker: NA
Text: changes-th e reduction in a total quantity

Speaker: NA
Text: subscribed by importing countries and the

Speaker: NA
Text: participation of France, Argentina and

Speaker: NA
Text: Sweden-ha s been a steep reduction in the

Speaker: NA
Text: quotas available for Australia, Canada and

Speaker: NA
Text: the United States. In Australia's case, our

Speaker: NA
Text: quota has been reduced from 45,000,000

Speaker: NA
Text: bushels under the 1953 agreement to

Speaker: NA
Text: 30,000,000 bushels in the new agreement.

Speaker: NA
Text: The figures I have just quoted are those

Speaker: NA
Text: which appear in the text of the agreement

Speaker: NA
Text: which was negotiated, copies of which have

Speaker: NA
Text: been distributed. I should add that some

Speaker: NA
Text: minor variations from those figures are

Speaker: NA
Text: possible when the agreement is fully in

Speaker: NA
Text: force. I mentioned earlier that each coun-

Speaker: NA
Text: try which has signed the agreement has

Speaker: NA
Text: until 1st December, 1956, to declare its

Speaker: NA
Text: adherence to the agreement by the deposit

Speaker: NA
Text: of a formal instrument of acceptance.

Speaker: NA
Text: Accordingly, the final position regarding

Speaker: NA
Text: membership will not be known until that

Speaker: NA
Text: date, but on the information currently

Speaker: NA
Text: available it is likely that the changes, if

Speaker: NA
Text: any. which will be necessary will be rela-

Speaker: NA
Text: tively small. Although Australia and a

Speaker: NA
Text: number of other countries which have in-

Speaker: NA
Text: dicated that they intend adhering to the

Speaker: NA
Text: agreement have not yet formally ratified it.

Speaker: NA
Text: the operative provisions concerning prices

Speaker: NA
Text: and quantities came into force on 1st

Speaker: NA
Text: August, 1956, and transactions are now

Speaker: NA
Text: taking place within the terms of the new

Speaker: NA
Text: agreement.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government regards the existence of

Speaker: NA
Text: an effective International Wheat Agreement

Speaker: NA
Text: as being of very great value to the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian wheat industry, and to the economy

Speaker: NA
Text: generally. This is particularly the case

Speaker: NA
Text: in times like the present, when stocks of

Speaker: NA
Text: unsold wheat are at record levels and any-

Speaker: NA
Text: thing in the nature of " panic selling " could

Speaker: NA
Text: bring widespread distress to wheat-growers

Speaker: NA
Text: and sharply reduced export earnings for

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. The Government, therefore,

Speaker: NA
Text: through its delegation to the recent con-

Speaker: NA
Text: ference, pursued every means of obtaining

Speaker: NA
Text: the best possible agreement under which

Speaker: NA
Text: some measure of stability might be given

Speaker: NA
Text: to the export marketing of Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: wheat. The Government is convinced that,

Speaker: NA
Text: in the present circumstances, the new

Speaker: NA
Text: agreement is the best obtainable. The new

Speaker: NA
Text: price range cannot be regarded as other

Speaker: NA
Text: than satisfactory, in the light of current

Speaker: NA
Text: price levels. The quantity of wheat covered

Speaker: NA
Text: by the new agreement is, admittedly, dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: appointing, as it represents only about one-

Speaker: NA
Text: third of the wheat entering world trade.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government would have liked to have

Speaker: NA
Text: seen an agreement with a very much wider

Speaker: NA
Text: coverage, as the effectiveness of an arrange-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of this type is, to some extent at least,

Speaker: NA
Text: influenced by the relationship it bears to

Speaker: NA
Text: total world trade in the particular com-

Speaker: NA
Text: modity.

Speaker: NA
Text: But in considering the alternatives of

Speaker: NA
Text: having no agreement at all, or of staying

Speaker: NA
Text: out of an agreement which other countries

Speaker: NA
Text: -ou r competitors and our markets-wer e

Speaker: NA
Text: prepared to implement, the new agreement

Speaker: NA
Text: undoubtedly offers advantages to Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: which far outweigh any reservations asso-

Speaker: NA
Text: ciated with the reduction in quantities. For

Speaker: NA
Text: example, the formal adherence by such a

Speaker: NA
Text: large and representative group of countries

Speaker: NA
Text: to the basic objective of the agreement

Speaker: NA
Text: offers some prospects that fundamental

Speaker: NA
Text: wheat problems, such as the stimulation of

Speaker: NA
Text: uneconomic production, will be kept within

Speaker: NA
Text: limits. Again, with accumulated wheat

Speaker: NA
Text: stocks so great it is imperative that some

Speaker: NA
Text: degree of orderliness in export marketing

Speaker: NA
Text: should prevail. An international wheat

Speaker: NA
Text: agreement provides the only convenient

Speaker: NA
Text: and effective way of introducing any degree

Speaker: NA
Text: of orderliness. In connexion with this point,

Speaker: NA
Text: I attach considerable importance to the

Speaker: NA
Text: entry into the agreement of Argentina and

Speaker: NA
Text: Sweden, and the participation of France on

Speaker: NA
Text: a substantial basis. And finally, whilst the

Speaker: NA
Text: agreement is kept in existence, particularly

Speaker: NA
Text: with Argentina, France and Sweden par-

Speaker: NA
Text: ticipating, there is always the possibility

Speaker: NA
Text: that a more satisfactory agreement, em-

Speaker: NA
Text: bracing wider membership and large quotas,

Speaker: NA
Text: might be negotiated. A complete break-

Speaker: NA
Text: down now would put back the clock by

Speaker: NA
Text: twenty years, to the time of the chaotic

Speaker: NA
Text: marketing conditions of the early 1930's,

Speaker: NA
Text: when efforts to find a solution to inter-

Speaker: NA
Text: national wheat marketing problems had

Speaker: NA
Text: their origin.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is for these reasons that the Governr'eveloDmenrs

Speaker: NA
Text: ment is convinced that participation in

Speaker: NA
Text: new agreement, which is sought by this

Speaker: NA
Text: would be of undoubted benefit to Ausexample,

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian wheat-growers and to the economy

Speaker: NA
Text: of this country. I wish to make it clear

Speaker: NA
Text: that in reaching its decision in regard to

Speaker: NA
Text: ratification of the agreement, the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment has had the advice and the views of

Speaker: NA
Text: the wheat industry. Indeed, the chairman

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Australian Wheat Board, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: general president and general secretary of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Wheat Growers Federation,

Speaker: NA
Text: served as members of the AustraUan dele-

Speaker: NA
Text: gation to the negotiating conference. Those

Speaker: NA
Text: gentlemen are in full accord with the Go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment's views on the desirability ot

Speaker: NA
Text: ratification by Australia. I commend the

Speaker: NA
Text: bill to the House.

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate (on motion by Mr Calwell)

Speaker: NA
Text: adjourned.

Speaker: NA
Text: HOME NURSING SUBSIDY BILL 1956.

Speaker: NA
Text: Motion (by Dr Donald Cameron)-b y

Speaker: NA
Text: leave-agree d to-

Speaker: NA
Text: That leave be given to bring in a bill to

Speaker: NA
Text: provide for the grant of subsidies to Home Nursing

Speaker: NA
Text: Organizations.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill presented, and read a first time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading.

Speaker: Dr DONALD CAMERON
Text: Oxley-

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Health) [3.37] -b y leave- I

Speaker: NA
Text: move-

Speaker: NA
Text: That the bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: NA
Text: The object of this bill is to authorize finan

Speaker: NA
Text: cial assistance by the Commonwealth to

Speaker: NA
Text: approved organizations engaged in the con-

Speaker: NA
Text: duct of home-nursing services. The

Speaker: NA
Text: national health service is based on certain

Speaker: NA
Text: principles. One of the most important is

Speaker: NA
Text: the idea of a partnership-o f co-operation

Speaker: NA
Text: between patient and doctor. Implicit in this

Speaker: NA
Text: is the realization that a powerful factor in

Speaker: NA
Text: recovery from illness and restoration to

Speaker: NA
Text: health is the sense of personal responsibility

Speaker: NA
Text: of the patient for what happens to him.

Speaker: NA
Text: This means that the foundation of :.

Speaker: NA
Text: national health scheme should be an efficient

Speaker: NA
Text: and competent general practitioner service

Speaker: NA
Text: The importance of domiciliary medicine can

Speaker: NA
Text: hardly be over-estimated. A hospital ser-

Speaker: NA
Text: vice can never be a true substitute for the

Speaker: NA
Text: family doctor, whose role is becoming more,

Speaker: NA
Text: instead of less, important with the recent

Speaker: NA
Text: in medical knowledge. The

Speaker: NA
Text: the modern general practitioner has powerful

Speaker: NA
Text: bill, weapons in his hands, such things, for

Speaker: NA
Text: as the sulphonamides and the

Speaker: NA
Text: -ntibio'ics. and if his own standard of work

Speaker: NA
Text: end knowledge is high, can undertake in

Speaker: NA
Text: ihc home, r.nd ia full and proper collabora-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion with the specialist, a great deal of

Speaker: NA
Text: ireatmem to the great benefit of his patients

Speaker: NA
Text: in particular, and the country in general.

Speaker: NA
Text: Much is said nowadays about the ques-

Speaker: NA
Text: lion of medical and hospital benefits, and

Speaker: NA
Text: all sorts of claims are made that these

Speaker: NA
Text: should be higher or more extensive. Whether

Speaker: NA
Text: this is so or not, the thing of fundamental

Speaker: NA
Text: importance is the quality of medical care,

Speaker: NA
Text: and it is essential that there must be not

Speaker: NA
Text: only no deterioration of the standard of

Speaker: NA
Text: family and general practice from the high

Speaker: NA
Text: level at which it has existed in the past,

Speaker: NA
Text: hut that this standard should be main-

Speaker: NA
Text: lined and, if possible, raised.

Speaker: NA
Text: if this is so, then several things are

Speaker: NA
Text: sary. Not only is there need for good train-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing of general practitioners, but the condi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions of general practice must be such as to

Speaker: NA
Text: give scope to men who possess good train-

Speaker: NA
Text: ins, and ability, and be designed to allow

Speaker: NA
Text: their patients to benefit from it to the full.

Speaker: NA
Text: This means in modern medical practice that

Speaker: NA
Text: trained assistance, by a complementary

Speaker: NA
Text: service, namely the nursing profession,

Speaker: NA
Text: should be available.

Speaker: NA
Text: For more than 50 years home nursing care

Speaker: NA
Text: has been provided for the poor and needy

Speaker: NA
Text: throughout Australia by district and bush

Speaker: NA
Text: nursing associations and religious organiza-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions. Honorable members will be familiar

Speaker: NA
Text: with the charitable and public-spirited work

Speaker: NA
Text: of these bodies whose efforts have brought

Speaker: NA
Text: relief to the sick and aged, particularly in

Speaker: NA
Text: the poorer areas of the cities. The nurses

Speaker: NA
Text: employed by these home-nursing organiza-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions are generally known in Australia as

Speaker: NA
Text: " district " nurses. The special feature of

Speaker: NA
Text: iheir work is that it is carried out by visits

Speaker: NA
Text: io the homes of the patients as distinct from

Speaker: NA
Text: hospital, clinic, or institutional care, or the

Speaker: NA
Text: services rendered by a nurse engaged pri-

Speaker: NA
Text: vately by the patient.

Speaker: NA
Text: The district nurses are generally referred

Speaker: NA
Text: to the patients, in the first instance, by a

Speaker: NA
Text: hospital or by a local doctor. The majority

Speaker: NA
Text: of patients nursed are those with long-term

Speaker: NA
Text: illnesses such as patients suffering from

Speaker: NA
Text: cardiac disease, arthritis, incurable carci-

Speaker: NA
Text: noma, and so on. Many of these patients

Speaker: NA
Text: ure very ill and would be transferred to

Speaker: NA
Text: hospitals or other institutions but for thc

Speaker: NA
Text: serious shortage of hospital beds. The

Speaker: NA
Text: nursing these patients require is mainly

Speaker: NA
Text: general care, sponging, supervision, and

Speaker: NA
Text: general nursing treatment which is always

Speaker: NA
Text: arduous and time-consuming, though there

Speaker: NA
Text: are many cases which do not require more

Speaker: NA
Text: than a daily visit, or perhaps a visit several

Speaker: NA
Text: times a week.

Speaker: NA
Text: Although chronic illnesses are prevalent

Speaker: NA
Text: among all age groups, they mainly affect

Speaker: NA
Text: people over 60 years of age. It is these

Speaker: NA
Text: people that make up the majority of the

Speaker: NA
Text: district nurses' patients. It is estimated

Speaker: NA
Text: that approximately three-quarters of the

Speaker: NA
Text: patients of each district nursing association

Speaker: NA
Text: are chronically ill and over the age of 60

Speaker: NA
Text: years. A considerable amount of home-

Speaker: NA
Text: nursing work is also done for patients

Speaker: NA
Text: who cannot be classified as chronically ill.

Speaker: NA
Text: necesbut who require prolonged care, such as

Speaker: NA
Text: those requiring after-care for unhealed

Speaker: NA
Text: wounds following operations. At the same

Speaker: NA
Text: time, under modern conditions, an increas-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing number of acute cases is becoming suit-

Speaker: NA
Text: able for treatment at home.

Speaker: NA
Text: Since the war, it has been impossible for

Speaker: NA
Text: hospital construction to be maintained at a

Speaker: NA
Text: rate in any way commensurate with the

Speaker: NA
Text: growth in population. Consequently, it has

Speaker: NA
Text: become necessary for surgical and acutely

Speaker: NA
Text: ill cases to be discharged from hospital at

Speaker: NA
Text: the earliest possible time, whilst the chroni-

Speaker: NA
Text: cally and less acutely ill have found it pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: gressively more difficult to obtain hospital

Speaker: NA
Text: accommodation at all. Many of these

Speaker: NA
Text: chronically ill people, who in other days

Speaker: NA
Text: would have been hospital cases, cannot now

Speaker: NA
Text: receive the nursing attention they require

Speaker: NA
Text: unless they are visited by the district nurses.

Speaker: NA
Text: Because of this oppressive shortage of hos-

Speaker: NA
Text: pital beds, the need for adequate properly

Speaker: NA
Text: equipped home-nursing services has greatly

Speaker: NA
Text: intensified in recent years.

Speaker: NA
Text: At the present time, some 150 district

Speaker: NA
Text: nurses are employed by home-nursing asso-

Speaker: NA
Text: ciations. A work analysis recently made

Speaker: NA
Text: indicates that each of these 150 nurses is

Speaker: NA
Text: at present saving the provision of six hospi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tal beds; that is, the home-nursing services

Speaker: NA
Text: are saving 900 hospital beds throughout

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. The capital cost of providing

Speaker: NA
Text: new hospital accommodation has risen to

Speaker: NA
Text: extraordinary heights. In the case of hos-

Speaker: NA
Text: pitals recently completed, the cost is

Speaker: NA
Text: reckoned at at least £7,000 a bed. The cost

Speaker: NA
Text: of maintaining a hospital bed has also

Speaker: NA
Text: reached a new and very high level. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: now rarely, if ever, less than £3 a day, and

Speaker: NA
Text: in the case of many individual hospitals

Speaker: NA
Text: is considerably more than that. By way of

Speaker: NA
Text: contrast, the cost of a visit to a home by a

Speaker: NA
Text: district nurse averages something like 7s.

Speaker: NA
Text: These figures give some indication of the

Speaker: NA
Text: savings of very great significance to the

Speaker: NA
Text: community that are to be made by encour-

Speaker: NA
Text: aging home-nursing for the sick, instead of

Speaker: NA
Text: hospitalization, whenever it is possible. It

Speaker: NA
Text: has been reliably estimated that the main-

Speaker: NA
Text: tenance of 150 nurses in district nursing

Speaker: NA
Text: work keeps hospital running costs down by

Speaker: NA
Text: at least £1,000,000 a year. The total cost

Speaker: NA
Text: of keeping these 150 nurses in the field is

Speaker: NA
Text: less than one-fifth of that sum.

Speaker: NA
Text: Can I give the House a further example?

Speaker: NA
Text: If in a few years' time home-nursing were

Speaker: NA
Text: to expand to four times its present level

Speaker: NA
Text: there would be, on these considerations, a

Speaker: NA
Text: saving of 3,600 beds, resulting in the fol-

Speaker: NA
Text: lowing financial savings:-

Speaker: NA
Text: Annual maintenance expenditure

Speaker: NA
Text: relating to these beds . . ..

Speaker: NA
Text: A capital expenditure, assuming they

Speaker: NA
Text: were all provided, of well over 20,000,000

Speaker: NA
Text: The cost of home-nursing services to pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duce such a result would be very small

Speaker: NA
Text: indeed. These are, of course, theoretical

Speaker: NA
Text: figures, but they indicate the magnitude of

Speaker: NA
Text: the financial relief which could be afforded

Speaker: NA
Text: to the general problem of hospital costs,

Speaker: NA
Text: in an expanding population.

Speaker: NA
Text: These, in brief, are thefinancialand prac-

Speaker: NA
Text: tical considerations in favour of the develop-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of home-nursing services. At the

Speaker: NA
Text: same time it is realized that many patients,

Speaker: NA
Text: particularly old people, will be much

Speaker: NA
Text: happier and perhaps will be better, if they

Speaker: NA
Text: can be nursed at home, and modern medical

Speaker: NA
Text: thought favours this practice. Furthermore,

Speaker: NA
Text: it is now realized that the visiting nurse,

Speaker: NA
Text: can do much effective work in the field of

Speaker: NA
Text: preventive medicine, giving instruction in

Speaker: NA
Text: general health, nutrition, food habits, &c.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is advantages of this kind which Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian and overseas authorities are now

Speaker: NA
Text: coming to recognize in the practice of send-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the nurse into the home, instead of

Speaker: NA
Text: sending the patient into hospital. In view

Speaker: NA
Text: of these developments, the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: recently decided that the building up of

Speaker: NA
Text: numerically stronger and better equipped

Speaker: NA
Text: organizations of district nurses should bz

Speaker: NA
Text: encouraged, so far as it is practicable for

Speaker: NA
Text: the Commonwealth to do so. The volun-

Speaker: NA
Text: tary organizations already in the field have

Speaker: NA
Text: done splendid work. They have kept their

Speaker: NA
Text: services going when times were difficult

Speaker: NA
Text: and have accepted heavy financial burdens

Speaker: NA
Text: in an effort to expand their services in

Speaker: NA
Text: recent times to keep pace with growing

Speaker: NA
Text: public demands. We, therefore, believe

Speaker: NA
Text: that the most promising approach to the

Speaker: NA
Text: expansion of home-nursing services is to

Speaker: NA
Text: provide financial assistance for public and

Speaker: NA
Text: religious organizations qualified to perform

Speaker: NA
Text: this work. As the Commonwealth is enter-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing this field for the first time, we felt ti

Speaker: NA
Text: inadvisable to specify in this bill precise

Speaker: NA
Text: terms and conditions on which Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth financial assistance will be made

Speaker: NA
Text: available. These matters will be determined

Speaker: NA
Text: according to circumstances affecting par-

Speaker: NA
Text: ticular organizations and, perhaps, varied

Speaker: NA
Text: from time to time in the light of experience.

Speaker: NA
Text: In general terms, the Commonwealth's

Speaker: NA
Text: £ policy will be to grant to non-profit making

Speaker: NA
Text: home-nursing organizations now in the field

Speaker: NA
Text: subsidies approximating the salaries paid to

Speaker: NA
Text: nursing sisters employed by them over and

Speaker: NA
Text: above the number ordinarily employed dur-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the year prior to the commencement

Speaker: NA
Text: of the act. Thus, if an organization has

Speaker: NA
Text: ordinarily employed, say, ten nurses dur-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the past year and increases its staff

Speaker: NA
Text: !o twelve nurses when this scheme com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mences, it will receive a subsidy approximat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the salary of the two additional nurses:

Speaker: NA
Text: if it increases its staff to fifteen nurses It

Speaker: NA
Text: will receive a subsidy approximating the

Speaker: NA
Text: salarv of the five additional nurses. This

Speaker: NA
Text: basis for calculating the subsidy will be

Speaker: NA
Text: applied in relation to the organizations

Speaker: NA
Text: which are conducting home-nursing services

Speaker: NA
Text: at the present time. It is possible, ot course,

Speaker: NA
Text: lhat new organizations will enter the field.

Speaker: NA
Text: It will be evident to honorable members

Speaker: NA
Text: that it will not be practicable to subsidize

Speaker: NA
Text: these " new" organizations on exactly the

Speaker: NA
Text: same basis as that proposed for the exist-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing organizations, because that would in-

Speaker: NA
Text: volve the payment of a Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: subsidy equal to the full salary of even

Speaker: NA
Text: nurse employed by each " new " organiza-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. This would put " new " organizations

Speaker: NA
Text: on a much more favorable basis than thosi-

Speaker: NA
Text: that have pioneered this field. It is pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: posed, therefore, that the organizations

Speaker: NA
Text: which commence home-nursin? services

Speaker: NA
Text: after this act comes into operation will be

Speaker: NA
Text: entitled to apply for a subsidv equal to

Speaker: NA
Text: approximately half the salarv paid to each

Speaker: NA
Text: nurse employed on home-nursing duty.

Speaker: NA
Text: This, I think, is a fair and equitable basis

Speaker: NA
Text: for handling this problem.

Speaker: NA
Text: Up to the present, finance for the district

Speaker: NA
Text: nursing associations' work has come mainly

Speaker: NA
Text: from State government subsidies, collections

Speaker: NA
Text: from patients, and donations by the public.

Speaker: NA
Text: We think il right that money should con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tinue to be supplied to the associations from

Speaker: NA
Text: these sources. The work of the district

Speaker: NA
Text: nurses results in a significant saving in

Speaker: NA
Text: State hospital expenditure, and the States,

Speaker: NA
Text: as I have pointed out already, support

Speaker: NA
Text: organizations engaged in this work. This

Speaker: NA
Text: bill provides that the subsidy to be paid by

Speaker: NA
Text: ihe Commonwealth is not in any case to

Speaker: NA
Text: exceed the State government subsidy.

Speaker: NA
Text: Naturally it is proposed to consult with the

Speaker: NA
Text: State governments about the effective carry-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing out of the provisions of the bill. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister's approval will be required before

Speaker: NA
Text: an organization is granted a subsidy under

Speaker: NA
Text: this scheme. The organizations which arc-

Speaker: NA
Text: granted subsidies will, of course, have lo

Speaker: NA
Text: supply the Director-General of Health with

Speaker: NA
Text: adequate information and properly audited

Speaker: NA
Text: accounts and reports. For example, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Director-General of Health will in all cases

Speaker: NA
Text: have to be satisfied that the nurses on

Speaker: NA
Text: account of whom the subsidy is claimed are

Speaker: NA
Text: properly qualified. At the same time. 1

Speaker: NA
Text: assure Ihe House that the department will

Speaker: NA
Text: not be seeking to impose conditions or

Speaker: NA
Text: restrictions which will hamper the organi-

Speaker: NA
Text: sations in their conduct of their work.

Speaker: NA
Text: There will be no attempt by the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment to interfere with the organizations'

Speaker: NA
Text: management and control of their affairs,

Speaker: NA
Text: except insofar as is consistent with thc

Speaker: NA
Text: proper expenditure of public funds. 1

Speaker: NA
Text: believe that this measure will prove to be

Speaker: NA
Text: of very great importance and value in the

Speaker: NA
Text: field of public health. I , therefore, hope

Speaker: NA
Text: that all members will be sympathetic to its

Speaker: NA
Text: objectives and will accord it their full

Speaker: NA
Text: support.

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate (on motion by Mr Chambers)

Speaker: NA
Text: adjourned.

Speaker: NA
Text: ESTIMATES 1956-57.

Speaker: NA
Text: In Committee of Supply: Consideration

Speaker: NA
Text: resumed from 9th October (vide page

Speaker: NA
Text: Department of Supply.

Speaker: NA
Text: Proposed Vote, £15,132.000.

Speaker: NA
Text: Department of Defence Production.

Speaker: NA
Text: Proposed Vote, £19,891,000.

Speaker: NA
Text: Other Services.

Speaker: NA
Text: Proposed Vote, £988,000.

Speaker: NA
Text: (Ordered to be considered together.)

Speaker: Mr JEFF BATE
Text: Macarthur) [3.51] -

Speaker: NA
Text: When considering the proposed vote for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Department of Defence Production, one

Speaker: NA
Text: thinks of the making of ammunition, and

Speaker: NA
Text: one may be forgiven for recalling those

Speaker: NA
Text: days in 1944 and 1945 when Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: troops, already emerging into an atomic

Speaker: NA
Text: age because an atomic bomb was used in

Speaker: NA
Text: 1945 to end the war, were in the jungle

Speaker: NA
Text: wrestling with the problems relating to the

Speaker: NA
Text: supply of ammunition for their weapons.

Speaker: NA
Text: I can remember, and I suppose many

Speaker: NA
Text: other honorable members can remember,

Speaker: NA
Text: too, endeavouring to get ammunition

Speaker: NA
Text: through the jungle up to the troops in the

Speaker: NA
Text: from line.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Dean -Dry .

Speaker: Mr JEFF BATE
Text: An d to get it there

Speaker: NA
Text: dry, as the honorable member for Robert-

Speaker: NA
Text: son says. The .303 ammunition was still

Speaker: NA
Text: being packed in a steel container of a type

Speaker: NA
Text: which was introduced, I suppose, in World

Speaker: NA
Text: War I . , 30 years earlier. The containers

Speaker: NA
Text: held 1,248 rounds, and it was impossible to

Speaker: NA
Text: carry them on the jungle trails. The con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tainers had to be opened and the ammuni-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion transferred in small quantities to sand-

Speaker: NA
Text: bags, which became wet, and so the troops

Speaker: NA
Text: were forced to carry with them wet rounds

Speaker: NA
Text: which they could not trust. Further, they

Speaker: NA
Text: carried not only .303 ammunition but also

Speaker: NA
Text: 9-mm. and 7-mm. ammunition, rounds for

Speaker: NA
Text: the various machine guns, belts for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Vickers, magazines for the Brens, mortar

Speaker: NA
Text: bombs of all types, rounds for artillery

Speaker: NA
Text: pieces, and so on. This situation led to

Speaker: NA
Text: a lowering of morale in the troops, and

Speaker: NA
Text: great difficulties in the supply lines both for

Speaker: NA
Text: ourselves and for the Americans at whose

Speaker: NA
Text: side and on whose side we were fighting.

Speaker: NA
Text: All sorts of difficulties were encountered in

Speaker: NA
Text: bringing the ammunition to the islands, and

Speaker: NA
Text: taking it from the ports or beaches into

Speaker: NA
Text: the jungle and from the jungle bases to

Speaker: NA
Text: the front line. The problems encountered

Speaker: NA
Text: were almost incredibly difficult. From this

Speaker: NA
Text: state of affairs the ideal of having one size

Speaker: NA
Text: of ammunition to suit all the western

Speaker: NA
Text: nations was conceived. We now have an

Speaker: NA
Text: agreement, I believe, that the FN .30 rifle,

Speaker: NA
Text: which is a semi-automatic carbine similar,

Speaker: NA
Text: I think, to the American carbine, will be

Speaker: NA
Text: standard equipment and that all armies at

Speaker: NA
Text: the side of which we are likely to fight

Speaker: NA
Text: use common ammunition. I f we are

Speaker: NA
Text: forced to fight on the side of other troops

Speaker: NA
Text: or alone, it will be a boon indeed to have

Speaker: NA
Text: the .30 rifle in use. The agreement to

Speaker: NA
Text: which I have referred was made some years

Speaker: NA
Text: ago. The need for it was apparent many

Speaker: NA
Text: years ago, when the honorable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Adelaide ( Mr Chambers) was Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: the Army. It was apparent to me as a very

Speaker: NA
Text: lowly officer, and I made a report about it.

Speaker: NA
Text: I do not know whether the report ever

Speaker: NA
Text: reached the honorable gentleman; probably

Speaker: NA
Text: it was stopped at some low level. The

Speaker: NA
Text: report referred to the dangers of having old

Speaker: NA
Text: types of ammunition packages. Whereas

Speaker: NA
Text: the Japanese were carrying light packages

Speaker: NA
Text: wrapped in tarred paper, which enabled

Speaker: NA
Text: mortar bombs and other ammunition to be

Speaker: NA
Text: kept dry and in good condition for years,

Speaker: NA
Text: we were still being supplied with steel

Speaker: NA
Text: packages of ammunition which were not

Speaker: NA
Text: suitable for that type of warfare. The

Speaker: NA
Text: point I am making is that, in spite of the

Speaker: NA
Text: need which then existed and which now

Speaker: NA
Text: exists, we have not yet reached the

Speaker: NA
Text: stage of manufacturing .30 ammunition.

Speaker: NA
Text: Perhaps the Minister for Defence Pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duction ( Sir Eric Harrison) will correct

Speaker: NA
Text: me if I am wrong, but I believe

Speaker: NA
Text: that we are still making .303 ammu-

Speaker: NA
Text: nition for the .303 rifles that are used for

Speaker: NA
Text: training and rifle practice. Stocks of such

Speaker: NA
Text: ammunition have to be maintained for use

Speaker: NA
Text: in this rifle which, I think, was used 40

Speaker: NA
Text: years ago in World War I . I make that

Speaker: NA
Text: observation because I want to refer to a

Speaker: NA
Text: term that is being commonly used to-day-

Speaker: NA
Text: the inflexibility of defence preparations.

Speaker: NA
Text: Although this Parliament has been thinking

Speaker: NA
Text: in terms of nuclear warfare, radar, and

Speaker: NA
Text: guided missiles, which seek out enemy air-

Speaker: NA
Text: craft, we still go on with the inflexible

Speaker: NA
Text: preparations which are a legacy to us from

Speaker: NA
Text: previous military regimes. The defence

Speaker: NA
Text: chiefs are still forced to make recommenda-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions which carry on the manufacture of

Speaker: NA
Text: the kind of ammunition that is being pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duced at Maribyrnong.

Speaker: NA
Text: We are not concerned merely with

Speaker: NA
Text: manufacture of practice rounds, or even

Speaker: NA
Text: with the manufacture of rounds for the

Speaker: NA
Text: FN .30 rifle, with which, I understand,

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Army will soon be equipped.

Speaker: NA
Text: Because the use of infantry is essential to

Speaker: NA
Text: the defence of this country, we must con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tinue to manufacture rounds for small

Speaker: NA
Text: will arms, but whilst we carry on with these

Speaker: NA
Text: inflexible defence preparations, we also art-

Speaker: NA
Text: obliged to find ammunition for new

Speaker: NA
Text: weapons, such as those used in aircraft,

Speaker: NA
Text: tank guns and mortars. Under the Seato

Speaker: NA
Text: treaty we have obligations to the other mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber nations. We have obligations, too, to

Speaker: NA
Text: Great Britain, which some of us thought

Speaker: NA
Text: we might have to honour in connexion with

Speaker: NA
Text: the Suez Canal situation. Then, we have

Speaker: NA
Text: obligations to America. This Government

Speaker: NA
Text: has made defence arrangements with other

Speaker: NA
Text: nations which I think those who sit on the

Speaker: NA
Text: other side of the Parliament also would have

Speaker: NA
Text: made had they been in power. The Go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment has embarked on defence pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: parations in accordance with the arrange-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments made with Australia's allies for

Speaker: NA
Text: mutual security. We have spent

Speaker: NA
Text: £190,000,000 a year on defence. We have

Speaker: NA
Text: all kinds of military weapons, and we must

Speaker: NA
Text: have ammunition for those weapons.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Minister for the Army ( Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Cramer) referred to the use of Centurion

Speaker: NA
Text: tanks. Suppose that we had Centurion

Speaker: NA
Text: tanks but no ammunition for them. Think

Speaker: NA
Text: what would happen if there were no hand

Speaker: NA
Text: grenades, no mortar bombs, no bombs for

Speaker: NA
Text: aircraft and no means of providing war

Speaker: NA
Text: heads, propellant charges, fuses, and so on.

Speaker: NA
Text: All of those things are essential to defence

Speaker: NA
Text: preparations. For that reason, the factory

Speaker: NA
Text: at Salisbury is being used by the long-range

Speaker: NA
Text: weapons organization, and the factory at

Speaker: NA
Text: Maribyrnong is producing small arms, but

Speaker: NA
Text: because we had no factories which could

Speaker: NA
Text: supply us with the other very necessary

Speaker: NA
Text: items of military equipment, such as bombs,

Speaker: NA
Text: mines, shells, propellant charges, war heads

Speaker: NA
Text: for shells and fuses, it became imperative,

Speaker: NA
Text: in order that we might be capable of

Speaker: NA
Text: honouring our obligations to our allies, to

Speaker: NA
Text: construct the ammunition filling factory at

Speaker: NA
Text: St. Mary's. It has been argued that there

Speaker: NA
Text: is no need for that factory, but, obviously,

Speaker: NA
Text: if we are to have defence preparations, we

Speaker: NA
Text: must have ammunition. Not only must

Speaker: NA
Text: ammunition be in the storage magazines,

Speaker: NA
Text: but also we must have a plant which is

Speaker: NA
Text: the capable of producing newly developed

Speaker: NA
Text: munitions at short notice, and by the most

Speaker: NA
Text: modern processes, including automation. If.

Speaker: NA
Text: the at any moment, we are attacked and have

Speaker: NA
Text: to defend ourselves, we shall be able to

Speaker: NA
Text: depend upon the factory at St. Mary's to

Speaker: NA
Text: the ammunition that is needed.

Speaker: NA
Text: Many of us found ourselves, in the early

Speaker: NA
Text: .part of the war, in the situation where we

Speaker: NA
Text: "had arms but no ammunition. I remember

Speaker: NA
Text: an episode that occurred after Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Churchill had sent practically all of his

Speaker: NA
Text: -materiel to the Middle East. England was

Speaker: NA
Text: under threat of attack across the channel,

Speaker: NA
Text: and a tank colonel ordered the mobilization

Speaker: NA
Text: of his tanks to try to save England from

Speaker: NA
Text: invasion. The quartermaster reported to

Speaker: NA
Text: him that there were no rounds available,

Speaker: NA
Text: >to which the colonel replied, " Get the

Speaker: NA
Text: rounds"! The quartermaster thereupon

Speaker: NA
Text: -produced wooden rounds for the defence

Speaker: NA
Text: of Great Britain! There are, in this Par-

Speaker: NA
Text: liament, people who never want to see a

Speaker: NA
Text: recurrence of those events, nor do they

Speaker: NA
Text: want to see thousands of young Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: men offering to defend their country but

Speaker: NA
Text: having no ammunition with which to do it.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is the duty of this Parliament to make

Speaker: NA
Text: sure that there are adequate supplies of

Speaker: NA
Text: -munitions.

Speaker: NA
Text: Because the Minister for Defence Pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duction may not speak again in the Parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment after to-day, I wish to take this

Speaker: NA
Text: tunity to congratulate him on his deter-

Speaker: NA
Text: mination to give Australia and its defence

Speaker: NA
Text: -forces adequate supplies of ammunition,

Speaker: NA
Text: although in doing so he has been attacked,

Speaker: NA
Text: f publicly congratulate him for his part in

Speaker: NA
Text: the establishment of the factory at St.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mary's. There was a need for the factory;

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister knew that the need existed,

Speaker: NA
Text: and he went ahead with the project. In my

Speaker: NA
Text: -opinion, the need for the St. Mary's plant

Speaker: NA
Text: has already been established, and I think

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Parliament and the country should

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: -of the press which have attacked the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: -fect with utter irresponsibility.

Speaker: NA
Text: Since the need for the factory at St.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mary's has been established, let us look at

Speaker: NA
Text: the methods used to establish it, which,

Speaker: NA
Text: 'perhaps, have been, in part, the reason for

Text: the attack. The factory was to be con-

Text: structed on a new method known as a cost

Speaker: NA
Text: -plus fixed fee contract, or a negotiated

Speaker: NA
Text: tract. A firm named Stephenson and

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: -architects, which was a most unusual course,

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: group of men. The designing and super-

Speaker: NA
Text: vision of the factory, therefore, was placed

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Concrete Constructions Proprietary Limited,

Speaker: NA
Text: war which obtained the fixed fee contract, have

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: methods in this country. If honorable

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: see that the work is not being carried out

Speaker: NA
Text: by the government stroke. I have never

Speaker: NA
Text: seen men work so hard. Naturally, some

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: they are working. They are also proud

Speaker: NA
Text: of the modern machinery that they have

Speaker: NA
Text: been given.

Speaker: NA
Text: 1 remind the committee that work on

Speaker: NA
Text: the Eildon weir project in Victoria, whicb

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: the fee of £10,000 a day for that period.

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Mary's, a modern and splendid plant of

Speaker: NA
Text: which every Australian may be proud.
