Speaker: NA
Text: intend to say anything more about it now.

Speaker: NA
Text: Because of the general criticism that has

Speaker: NA
Text: been levelled against the defence Estimates

Speaker: NA
Text: by Opposition members and by persons out-

Speaker: NA
Text: side this chamber, the picture that has

Speaker: NA
Text: already been painted by the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Defence ( Sir Philip MCBride) and the Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ters in charge of the various defence ser-

Speaker: NA
Text: vices would not be complete if I , as Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter for Defence Production, did not place

Speaker: NA
Text: before this committee and the country

Speaker: NA
Text: what has been achieved by the Department

Speaker: NA
Text: of Defence Production over the last five

Speaker: NA
Text: years. Therefore, I wish to set out the

Speaker: NA
Text: functions of the department and what it

Speaker: NA
Text: stands for, and also to deal with the various

Speaker: NA
Text: factories that come within the administration

Speaker: NA
Text: of the department, such as ordnance, air-

Speaker: NA
Text: craft, munitions, filling, explosives and the

Speaker: NA
Text: like. The main production functions of the

Speaker: NA
Text: department cover munitions, explosives,

Speaker: NA
Text: ordnance, aircraft and small arms. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: also responsible for arranging production

Speaker: NA
Text: in industry generally in annexes and by

Speaker: NA
Text: major and general contractors.

Speaker: NA
Text: The committee will realize that the func-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions of this department are many, and that

Speaker: NA
Text: the department itself has very, very wide

Speaker: NA
Text: 'ramifications indeed. The department has

Speaker: NA
Text: an employment figure of some 13,000

Speaker: NA
Text: persons in four States of the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth-11,00 0 in the government factories

Speaker: NA
Text: and 2,000 engaged on general administra-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive work, stores, &c. It recruits and trains

Speaker: NA
Text: its own apprentices and professional cadets,

Speaker: NA
Text: and thereby establishes a nucleus of highly

Speaker: NA
Text: skilled production executives capable of

Speaker: NA
Text: expansion and integration in any emer-

Speaker: NA
Text: gency. It controls assets with a replace-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment cost of more than £100,000,000. I

Speaker: NA
Text: ask the committee just to consider that par-

Speaker: NA
Text: ticular matter for a moment, because this

Speaker: NA
Text: department is really big business. Last

Speaker: NA
Text: year it was responsible for production

Speaker: NA
Text: valued at £34,000,000, which together with

Speaker: NA
Text: the department's own votes accounts for

Speaker: NA
Text: approximately one-quarter of the total

Speaker: NA
Text: defence allocation. It operates twelve fac-

Speaker: NA
Text: tories as well as ancillary services such

Speaker: NA
Text: as the flight test airfield at Avalon, central

Speaker: NA
Text: stores, drawing offices, maintenance units

Speaker: NA
Text: and synthetic ammonia plants. It produces

Speaker: NA
Text: equipment varying from clockwork fuse

Speaker: NA
Text: mechanisms to 3,600 horse-power marine

Speaker: NA
Text: diesel engines. If honorable members have

Speaker: NA
Text: ever studied the intricacies of the fuse sys-

Speaker: NA
Text: tems and compared the fine tolerances in-

Speaker: NA
Text: volved with the tolerances associated with

Speaker: NA
Text: a 3,600 horse-power marine diesel engine,

Speaker: NA
Text: they will get some idea of the great range

Speaker: NA
Text: of skilled technical knowledge, technicians

Speaker: NA
Text: and skilled artisans that we have in our

Speaker: NA
Text: employ. We can produce articles from air-

Speaker: NA
Text: craft to munitions and we can produce and

Speaker: NA
Text: maintain ordnance varying from the infan-

Speaker: NA
Text: tryman's rifle to the biggest guns in use in

Speaker: NA
Text: the Royal Australian Navy.

Speaker: NA
Text: The department co-operates with indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: try in production, and naturally we estab-

Speaker: NA
Text: lish industrial annexes and provide indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: try with know-how so that-we can call upon

Speaker: NA
Text: industry and expand rapidly in case of

Speaker: NA
Text: crisis. Last year, we arranged for the

Speaker: NA
Text: manufacture of goods in industry to a

Speaker: NA
Text: value of £17,000,000. Let me now give the

Speaker: NA
Text: committee some idea of the typical produc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of the department in the last five years,

Speaker: NA
Text: because it is over that period that we have

Speaker: NA
Text: been subjected to criticism, and over that

Speaker: NA
Text: period that the Opposition and the press

Speaker: NA
Text: have stated that we have spent large sums

Speaker: NA
Text: of money but have got very little in return

Speaker: NA
Text: for that expenditure. Let us have a look

Speaker: NA
Text: at the production of munitions and explo-

Speaker: NA
Text: sives for a start.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have produced approximately

Speaker: NA
Text: 100,000,000 rounds of small arms ammuni-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion, more than 3,000,000 shell cases of

Speaker: NA
Text: various calibres, approximately 1,250,000

Speaker: NA
Text: percussion, time, mechanical, and electronic

Speaker: NA
Text: fuses and primers-produce d to the excep-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional standards of accuracy and tolerance

Speaker: NA
Text: that I mentioned before. We have pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duced more than 100,000 3-in. rockets,

Speaker: NA
Text: manufactured or reconditioned for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Royal Australian Air Force and the Royal

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Navy. We have produced

Speaker: NA
Text: almost 2,000,000 20-mm. cartridges, filled

Speaker: NA
Text: and packed. We have also produced

Speaker: NA
Text: 500,000 40-mm. cartridges, 34,000 4-in.

Speaker: NA
Text: cartridges, 28,000 4.5-in. cartridges and

Speaker: NA
Text: manufactured 6,000 25-pounder cartridges.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have manufactured 78,000 bodies of

Speaker: NA
Text: hand grenades and assembled and filled

Speaker: NA
Text: them. We have manufactured special pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: pellants for rockets and boosts made for

Speaker: NA
Text: the long-range weapons research establish-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, including filling for more than 2,000

Speaker: NA
Text: 5-in. rockets. We have produced 200,000

Speaker: NA
Text: aircraft engine starting cartridges and

Speaker: NA
Text: approximately 1,250,000 cartridges for use

Speaker: NA
Text: with 3-in. rockets. We have made nearly

Speaker: NA
Text: 200,000 rounds of military pyrotechnic and

Speaker: NA
Text: signal stores of various types. Apart from

Speaker: NA
Text: rockets and cordite, we have produced

Speaker: NA
Text: approximately 850 tons of cordite pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: pellant, and more than 2,800 short tons of

Speaker: NA
Text: cannon and rifle powder for the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: services and Nato- I remind honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: members that we are required to supply

Speaker: NA
Text: certain items to Nato.

Speaker: NA
Text: May I now turn to aircraft, because when

Speaker: NA
Text: we take into consideration that we have the

Speaker: NA
Text: De Haviland factory and the establishments

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Commonwealth Aircraft Corpora-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion Proprietary Limited, which require conhave

Speaker: NA
Text: tractual obligations to be carried out by

Speaker: NA
Text: with capital equipment and materials sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: plied by us. it will give an indication

Speaker: NA
Text: the Department of Defence Production

Speaker: NA
Text: comesinto the picture of these other air-

Speaker: NA
Text: craft establishments outside the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment aircraft factories in a very big way.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bearing all that in mind, I inform honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able members that we have, in this period,

Speaker: NA
Text: produced twelve Lincoln four-engine heavy

Speaker: NA
Text: hombers at the Government aircraft factory,

Speaker: NA
Text: 52 Vampire jetfightersat De Haviland Air-

Speaker: NA
Text: craft Company Proprietary Limited, 41

Speaker: NA
Text: Vampire jet trainers at the same company,

Speaker: NA
Text: 29 Winjeel propellor trainers at the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth Aircraft Corporation Pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: prietary Limited. Ninety-one radio-con-

Speaker: NA
Text: trolled target aircraft have been designed

Speaker: NA
Text: and produced by the Government aircraft

Speaker: NA
Text: factory, and 34 Canberra jet bombers

Speaker: NA
Text: turned out at the same establishment.

Speaker: NA
Text: Forty-four Sabre jet fighters have been

Speaker: NA
Text: delivered by the Commonwealth Aircrafi

Speaker: NA
Text: Corporation Proprietary Limited to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Royal Australian Air Force. There are

Speaker: NA
Text: fourteen Sabre jets at present at Avalon.

Speaker: NA
Text: and two at the factory of the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth Aircraft Corporation Proprietary

Speaker: NA
Text: Limited ready to go to Avalon. Those at

Speaker: NA
Text: Avalon are awaiting test flights so that it

Speaker: NA
Text: may be said that there are fourteen ai

Speaker: NA
Text: Avalon and two with the Commonwealth-

Speaker: NA
Text: Aircraft Corporation Proprietary Limited,

Speaker: NA
Text: making a total of 60 Sabre jet aircraft so

Speaker: NA
Text: far produced.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have also produced 70 Nene jet

Speaker: NA
Text: engines for the Vampire fighters, and 78

Speaker: NA
Text: Avon jet engines for the Canberra bombers

Speaker: NA
Text: and for fighters. These have been pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duced by the Commonwealth Aircraft Cor-

Speaker: NA
Text: poration Proprietary Limited. In the five-

Speaker: NA
Text: year period we have overhauled and serviced

Speaker: NA
Text: a total of 742 airframes, 2,088 engines and

Speaker: NA
Text: 155,000 ancillary aircraft equipment units.

Speaker: NA
Text: Also in thatfive-yearperiod we have deli-

Speaker: NA
Text: vered to the services 123,100 different items

Speaker: NA
Text: of aircraft spare parts, as they have been

Speaker: NA
Text: required.

Speaker: NA
Text: Now I shall turn to ordnance, because we

Speaker: NA
Text: heard the honorable member for Bendigo

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Clarey) make some observations about

Speaker: NA
Text: that matter last night. We have produced

Speaker: NA
Text: ten 4.5-in. naval gun mountings on revolv-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing platforms, and there are nine under

Speaker: NA
Text: construction. These units weigh approxi-

Speaker: NA
Text: mately 80 tons each, so the committee will

Speaker: NA
Text: some idea of the extraordinary size of

Speaker: NA
Text: us the undertakings of our ordnance factories.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are 170 120-mm. recoilless anti-tank

Speaker: NA
Text: thai guns in the course of production, and

Speaker: NA
Text: initial deliveries have commenced. Foui

Speaker: NA
Text: main gearing sets for anti-submarine fri-

Speaker: NA
Text: gates and destroyers have been completed,

Speaker: NA
Text: and seven more are under construction

Speaker: NA
Text: A gear case weighs about 40 tons. Fourteen

Speaker: NA
Text: 40-mm. naval anti-aircraft guns with pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: dictors have been completed, and five are

Speaker: NA
Text: in the course of production. Five 21-in.

Speaker: NA
Text: torpedo tubes and mountings have been

Speaker: NA
Text: completed and two are under construction,

Speaker: NA
Text: as well as other secret types of naval arma-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments. We have converted 121 40-mm.

Speaker: NA
Text: oaval anti-aircraft guns from manual opera-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion to power operation. Ordnance equip-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment for 25-lb. and 3.7-in. guns has been

Speaker: NA
Text: repaired in industry to a value of £122,500.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let me turn to small arms. The honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Macquarie ( Mr Luchetti)

Speaker: NA
Text: will be interested in the figures showing the

Speaker: NA
Text: activities of the Small Arms Factory at Lith-

Speaker: NA
Text: gow. In recent years, the factory has been

Speaker: NA
Text: mainly occupied with the repair and recon-

Speaker: NA
Text: ditioning of small arms weapons rather

Speaker: NA
Text: than with new production. As the commit-

Speaker: NA
Text: tee knows, the factory is tooling up for

Speaker: NA
Text: production of the FN rifle. Recent opera-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions include the repair and conditioning

Speaker: NA
Text: of 102,000 .303-in. rifles, 32,220 light

Speaker: NA
Text: machine guns and sub-machine guns of

Speaker: NA
Text: various types, 23,250 pistols and 60,000

Speaker: NA
Text: bayonets and scabbards, as well as anti-

Speaker: NA
Text: tank infantry weapons, mortars and spare

Speaker: NA
Text: parts for weapons.

Speaker: NA
Text: ln addition, we have gone in for what

Speaker: NA
Text: can be called miscellaneous production. Ir

Speaker: NA
Text: is interesting to note that the production

Speaker: NA
Text: of Doxford-type marine engines has been

Speaker: NA
Text: developed for the first time in Australia at

Speaker: NA
Text: the marine engine works at Port Mel-

Speaker: NA
Text: bourne. Seven of these engines, each of

Speaker: NA
Text: which develops over 3,000 horse-power

Speaker: NA
Text: and weighs 270 tons, have been completed

Speaker: NA
Text: for the Australian Shipbuilding Board, for

Speaker: NA
Text: installation in bulk cargo carriers, and four

Speaker: NA
Text: more are in the course of production. Over

Speaker: NA
Text: 1,250,000 ball bearings have been produced

Speaker: NA
Text: at Echuca in the last five years. At the

Speaker: NA
Text: department's synthetic ammonia plants, re-

Speaker: NA
Text: serve capacity has been occupied in pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: ducing 220,000 tons of ammonium sul-

Speaker: NA
Text: phate for fertilizers-representin g approxi-

Speaker: NA
Text: mately 40 per cent, of Australian produc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion; over 18.000 tons of methanol for

Speaker: NA
Text: the plastics industry-th e total Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: production; and over 11.000 tons of

Speaker: NA
Text: ammonium nitrate for both fertilizers and

Speaker: NA
Text: civil explosives. Approximately 2,000

Speaker: NA
Text: spherical naval buoys and 2,500 marine

Speaker: NA
Text: markers have been produced in industry

Speaker: NA
Text: through the department. Boom defence

Speaker: NA
Text: equipment, including anti-submarine and

Speaker: NA
Text: anti-torpedo nets, to the value of £160 000

Speaker: NA
Text: has been produced in industry. Over

Speaker: NA
Text: 1,200 mobile transceivers have been made

Speaker: NA
Text: in industry for the Army, as well as

Speaker: NA
Text: approximately 500 walkie-talkie sets for

Speaker: NA
Text: sonal use in the field. Pontoons have been

Speaker: NA
Text: repaired in industry to the value of

Speaker: NA
Text: In addition to these examples, which are

Speaker: NA
Text: by no means exhaustive, the department has

Speaker: NA
Text: consistently followed a policy of develop-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing or auuing to production. capacity with

Speaker: NA
Text: a view to meeting the requirements of the

Speaker: NA
Text: nation in an emergency. It recognizes thai

Speaker: NA
Text: in such an emergency we should need to

Speaker: NA
Text: rely on the developing structure of Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian secondary industry. Therefore, ii

Speaker: NA
Text: places developmental orders and works in

Speaker: NA
Text: close harmony with industry advisory com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mittees. Almost one-half of the

Speaker: NA
Text: £34,000,000 worth of production arranged

Speaker: NA
Text: by the department in 1955-56 was under-

Speaker: NA
Text: taken in industry-mainl y the aircrafi

Speaker: NA
Text: industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let me turn to capital facilities. As I

Speaker: NA
Text: have mentioned previously, there have been

Speaker: NA
Text: developments also in the establishment of

Speaker: NA
Text: such facilities. During the period from

Speaker: NA
Text: 1951 to 1955 moneys available to thc

Speaker: NA
Text: department for new capital expenditurc

Speaker: NA
Text: averaged approximately £2,800,000 a year

Speaker: NA
Text: With those financial resources, new facili-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties have been developed. They include a

Speaker: NA
Text: new test airfield at Avalon. This is

Speaker: NA
Text: essential for the testing of jet aircraft. The

Speaker: NA
Text: largest jet aircraft at present in production

Speaker: NA
Text: can take off from and land at Avalon air-

Speaker: NA
Text: field. We have established Avon engine

Speaker: NA
Text: production capacity in Australia. We have

Speaker: NA
Text: established a plant for the production ot

Speaker: NA
Text: picrite, the new flashless propellani

Speaker: NA
Text: that is so. necessary in modern warfare.

Speaker: NA
Text: Other new facilities include a plant for the

Speaker: NA
Text: manufacture of RDX, a powerful high

Speaker: NA
Text: explosive entirely new to conventional war-

Speaker: NA
Text: fare; a specialized plant for tool room use:

Speaker: NA
Text: production capacity for new type fuses; and

Speaker: NA
Text: additions and modifications to existing go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment munitions and aircraft establish-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments.

Speaker: NA
Text: It might be as well if I told the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mittee that the department, in addition to

Speaker: NA
Text: supplying the wants of the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: services, has been seeking orders Irom over-

Speaker: NA
Text: seas. We are in consultation with New-

Speaker: NA
Text: Zealand in connexion with aircraft, and

Speaker: NA
Text: we are arranging to sell to Sweden a num-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber of Jindiviks. The Jindivik, as honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able members know, is a pilotless aircraft

Speaker: NA
Text: -almos t a guided missile. Earlier this

Speaker: NA
Text: per- year, a delegation from the Royal Swedish

Speaker: NA
Text: Air Board visited Australia and examined

Speaker: NA
Text: the Jindivik then in production at the

Speaker: NA
Text: government aircraft factories, with a view

Speaker: NA
Text: to purchase. The department has now

Speaker: NA
Text: received a telecablegram from its London

Speaker: NA
Text: representative to the effect that he, in turn,

Speaker: NA
Text: has received a telegram from the Royal

Speaker: NA
Text: Swedish Air Board stating that the Swedes

Speaker: NA
Text: are prepared to order ten Jindiviks, and

Speaker: NA
Text: that a detailed letter will follow. Major

Speaker: NA
Text: Silven, who was a member of the Swedish

Speaker: NA
Text: mission to Australia, and who is now in

Speaker: NA
Text: London, has informed the departmental

Speaker: NA
Text: representative there that the purchase order,

Speaker: NA
Text: with a detailed letter, will be issued before

Speaker: NA
Text: 16th October. Major Silven has also

Speaker: NA
Text: informed the departmental representative

Speaker: NA
Text: that a public announcement has been made

Speaker: NA
Text: in Sweden that the Swedish Government

Speaker: NA
Text: is proposing to order Australian Jindiviks.

Speaker: NA
Text: The total value of the order, including

Speaker: NA
Text: ground equipment, supply and technical

Speaker: NA
Text: data, camera pods, &c, is approximately

Speaker: NA
Text: £500,000, of which the British content is

Speaker: NA
Text: approximately £190,000. This is a mag-

Speaker: NA
Text: nificent tribute to the design engineers at

Speaker: NA
Text: the government aircraft factories, as well as

Speaker: NA
Text: to the production team which has been

Speaker: NA
Text: responsible for the manufacture of the air-

Speaker: NA
Text: craft and the installation of complex

Speaker: NA
Text: guidance equipment.

Speaker: NA
Text: From time to time, members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition seek a reduction of the votes

Speaker: NA
Text: for the defence departments. They say

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Government is spending too much

Speaker: NA
Text: money on defence and that we are not

Speaker: NA
Text: getting value for our money. They urge

Speaker: NA
Text: that defence expenditure be reduced. But,

Speaker: NA
Text: apparently, they fail to realize that if the

Speaker: NA
Text: vote for a service department is reduced,

Speaker: NA
Text: that department will reduce the number

Speaker: NA
Text: of orders that it places with government

Speaker: NA
Text: defence factories, with the result that some

Speaker: NA
Text: of the men employed in those factories

Speaker: NA
Text: will be dismissed, because there is no work

Speaker: NA
Text: available for them. When that happens,

Speaker: NA
Text: there is a tremendous howl from the mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers of the Opposition. They say that we

Speaker: NA
Text: must keep the men in employment, but

Speaker: NA
Text: they seek to deny to us the money necessary

Speaker: NA
Text: to do so. They cannot have it both ways.

Speaker: NA
Text: If they want us to reduce expenditure on

Speaker: NA
Text: defence, they must accept the consequences

Speaker: NA
Text: of such a reduction. Therefore, I want to

Speaker: NA
Text: say something about employment. Total

Speaker: NA
Text: employment in government defence fac-

Speaker: NA
Text: tories has risen from 8,000 persons between

Speaker: NA
Text: 1946 and 1949, to 11,000 persons now.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is a very high peace-time employment

Speaker: NA
Text: figure for such factories. However, the

Speaker: NA
Text: work load on munitions and aircraft fac-

Speaker: NA
Text: tories is of a cyclical nature. The manufac-

Speaker: NA
Text: ture of the Canberra bomber, the 4.5-in..

Speaker: NA
Text: twin mountings, the S.T.A.A.G. mountings-

Speaker: NA
Text: and the torpedo tube mountings for

Speaker: NA
Text: destroyers, the modification of Lincoln:

Speaker: NA
Text: aircraft, the servicing of Merlin engines, the

Speaker: NA
Text: manufacture of .303 rifles, are typical

Speaker: NA
Text: manufacturing projects coming to an end-

Speaker: NA
Text: In some instances replacement projects-'

Speaker: NA
Text: have been selected, for example the F.N..

Speaker: NA
Text: rifle. In other cases, for example the new

Speaker: NA
Text: types of naval ordnance, the replacement

Speaker: NA
Text: project is, for the time being, somewhat un-

Speaker: NA
Text: certain. The so-called sophisticated weapons

Speaker: NA
Text: -guide d weapons-ar e in advanced experi-

Speaker: NA
Text: mental and design stages but, in the main;

Speaker: NA
Text: they are not ready for operational use. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Government and the services are exercising

Speaker: NA
Text: caution before embarking on new produc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion programmes in the ordnance and air-

Speaker: NA
Text: craft factories. Consequently, there must

Speaker: NA
Text: be some immediate retrenchment in the

Speaker: NA
Text: various government munitions and aircraft

Speaker: NA
Text: establishments. This is a period of con-

Speaker: NA
Text: solidation. The work force in the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment defence production establishments

Speaker: NA
Text: will, therefore, for the time being, be cut

Speaker: NA
Text: back roughly to the level that obtained

Speaker: NA
Text: when the Government took office. The

Speaker: NA
Text: first batch of notices of dismissals will be

Speaker: NA
Text: given next Friday. I want only to say, in

Speaker: NA
Text: conclusion, that these men who will be

Speaker: NA
Text: given their notices of dismissal are

Speaker: NA
Text: not necessarily going to remain out

Speaker: NA
Text: of employment. As the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for Labour and National Service ( Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Harold Holt) has pointed out, this is.

Speaker: NA
Text: a transfer of labour from government muni-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions factories to private industry, which

Speaker: NA
Text: wants these men. We have already had

Speaker: NA
Text: recently, in our ordnance factories, cases of

Speaker: NA
Text: approximately 80 men who have handed i n

Speaker: NA
Text: their resignations and obtained new jobs.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Chambers -Ho w many will be dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: missed?

Speaker: Sir ERIC HARRISON
Text: I cannot give

Speaker: NA
Text: the honorable gentleman the actual figure

Speaker: NA
Text: at present, because we are still working or>

Speaker: NA
Text: it, but I have given an approximate figure

Speaker: NA
Text: snowing an eventual decrease in employ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment from 11,000, to 8,000. We will even-

Speaker: NA
Text: tually bring the figure back, unless some-

Speaker: NA
Text: thing very unforeseen happens, to approxi-

Speaker: NA
Text: mately the figure when we took office, but

Speaker: NA
Text: that will be over a period.

Speaker: Dr EVATT
Text: Wil l the figure go below

Speaker: Sir ERIC HARRISON
Text: No , it will not

Speaker: NA
Text: go below 8,000, and the reduction will be

Speaker: NA
Text: spread over a period of years, and will not

Speaker: NA
Text: be made immediately. I want to make it

Speaker: NA
Text: perfectly clear to the committee that unless

Speaker: NA
Text: we can get orders, which presupposes that

Speaker: NA
Text: unless money is available to the services,

Speaker: NA
Text: we cannot continue to keep this extra-

Speaker: NA
Text: ordinarily large peace-time work force in

Speaker: NA
Text: operation. The Government's term of office

Speaker: NA
Text: has been an exceptional period in which we

Speaker: NA
Text: have had to remedy all the deficiencies and

Speaker: NA
Text: shortages with which we were faced as a

Speaker: NA
Text: result of the Labour Government's neglect

Speaker: NA
Text: during its period of office. We had to

Speaker: NA
Text: bring the government factories back to a

Speaker: NA
Text: productive level, and bring back the ser-

Speaker: NA
Text: vices to a proper equipment standard, be-

Speaker: NA
Text: cause Labour had failed to do the job when

Speaker: NA
Text: it was in power. That fact necessitated our

Speaker: NA
Text: stepping up our work force to the extent

Speaker: NA
Text: to which we did step it up. Now we have

Speaker: NA
Text: established the desired position and we have

Speaker: NA
Text: given the services the equipment they want.

Speaker: NA
Text: They have their reserves, and we are now in

Speaker: NA
Text: a. position in which we can consolidate

Speaker: NA
Text: that which we have started. I think that

Speaker: NA
Text: the committee will certainly come to the

Speaker: NA
Text: conclusion, if it looks at these figures and

Speaker: NA
Text: digests the facts about the great work done,

Speaker: NA
Text: the skilled work done, that the Department

Text: and done its duty, during the whole term of

Speaker: NA
Text: office of this Government.

Speaker: NA

Text: tinued- .

Text: defended. Australia was a sector as menaced, and

Text: as helpless, as the Philippines.

Text: not like innuendoes being made, while our

Speaker: NA
Text: proceedings are being broadcast, that Great

Speaker: NA
Text: Britain and the United States of America are

Speaker: NA
Text: the culprits in this connexion. I agree with

Speaker: NA
Text: the statement by the honorable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Mackellar ( Mr Wentworth) last night

Speaker: NA
Text: that, until Russia is prepared to come to

Speaker: NA
Text: the party, as it were, we would be very

Speaker: NA
Text: foolish to curtail our tests, which are

Speaker: NA
Text: designed to provide us with the knowledge

Speaker: NA
Text: we need. We do not want to be aggressors,

Speaker: NA
Text: but it is important for us to learn all we

Speaker: NA
Text: possibly can from the atomic tests, not

Speaker: NA
Text: only so that we may retaliate if we are

Speaker: NA
Text: attacked, but also so that we may apply

Speaker: NA
Text: atomic power to peace-time purposes.

Speaker: NA
Text: It amazes me to hear members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition criticizing the atomic tests in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. As has been rightly pointed out

Speaker: NA
Text: by fhe Minister, and the scientists associ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ated with him in this venture, the last test

Speaker: NA
Text: was held in order to obtain information on

Speaker: NA
Text: how best to protect the civilian population

Speaker: NA
Text: from the effects of an atomic bomb explo-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion. It is no secret whatever that, on the

Speaker: NA
Text: occasion of the particular test that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition has criticized, in the area likely

Speaker: NA
Text: to be affected by the fall-out there were

Speaker: NA
Text: sheep, goats and other animals and herbage

Speaker: NA
Text: for them to eat. There was also more herb-

Speaker: NA
Text: age farther away from the centre of the

Speaker: NA
Text: blast which could be fed subsequently to

Speaker: NA
Text: the animals in order to observe whether any

Speaker: NA
Text: degree of radio-activity was present which

Speaker: NA
Text: would render them unfit for human con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sumption. In addition, scientific experi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments were carried out in relation to various

Speaker: NA
Text: kinds of clothing and other material, as

Speaker: NA
Text: well as buildings, for the purpose of obtain-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing information that would enable us to

Speaker: NA
Text: protect the civilian population from an

Speaker: NA
Text: atomic attack.

Speaker: NA
Text: I was particularly interested in one aspect

Speaker: NA
Text: of the experiment. I produce citrus fruit

Speaker: NA
Text: at an orchard which is situated about 16

Speaker: NA
Text: miles from Perth, and I wanted to learn

Speaker: NA
Text: the period of time that should elapse after

Speaker: NA
Text: an atomic explosion before fruit that was

Speaker: NA
Text: exposed to radiation would be fit for human

Speaker: NA
Text: consumption. If we had not taken all

Speaker: NA
Text: necessary precautions in connexion with tbe

Speaker: NA
Text: recent atomic tests, the Labour party would

Speaker: NA
Text: have every right to kick the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: from one end of the country to the other.

Speaker: NA
Text: But I think that it is an absolute disgrace

Speaker: NA
Text: -for honorable members opposite to criticize

Speaker: NA
Text: our scientists as they have done. I am

Speaker: NA
Text: ashamed of the tactics that the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: is employing.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Opposition has submitted a motion

Speaker: NA
Text: to reduce the proposed vote by £1. Last

Speaker: NA
Text: night, during the debate on another group

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Estimates, 1 referred to the value of

Speaker: NA
Text: the experiments that are being conducted

Speaker: NA
Text: at the Woomera Rocket Range. It must be

Speaker: NA
Text: realized that these tests cannot be con-

Speaker: NA
Text: ducted without a considerable expenditure

Speaker: NA
Text: if we are to obtain the knowledge we

Speaker: NA
Text: need. As far as I am concerned, if an

Speaker: NA
Text: expenditure of £60,000,000 is needed in

Speaker: NA
Text: order to obtain information that might

Speaker: NA
Text: result in the saving of the lives of 1,000,000

Speaker: NA
Text: people. I am satisfied. As those honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: members who had the privilege of visiting

Speaker: NA
Text: Maralinga and Woomera saw, many miles of

Speaker: NA
Text: electric wires and telephone cables have

Speaker: NA
Text: been installed, as well as airstrips and

Speaker: NA
Text: water-supply services. At Maralinga, it was

Speaker: NA
Text: necessary to provide a water-supply service,

Speaker: NA
Text: so that the men who were getting on with

Speaker: NA
Text: the job could enjoy some amenities, because

Speaker: NA
Text: tbe water from the bores was saltier than

Speaker: NA
Text: the sea. It is necessary to incur expenditure

Speaker: NA
Text: on such items. When we were at Woomera

Speaker: NA
Text: the other day, we saw firing contraptions

Speaker: NA
Text: similar to what one sees on a battleship.

Speaker: NA
Text: Underneath a flat piece of concrete on

Speaker: NA
Text: the ground were the innards of a battleship,

Speaker: NA
Text: which we had the privilege of inspecting. To

Speaker: NA
Text: instal such equipment under some feet of

Speaker: NA
Text: concrete involves a large expenditure; yet

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable members opposite continue to

Speaker: NA
Text: ask the Government to cut down the

Speaker: NA
Text: expenditure on defence. They are putting

Speaker: NA
Text: up a sham fight. Only a few minutes ago,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister .for Defence Production

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Sir Eric Harrison) threw back in the teeth

Speaker: NA
Text: of honorable members opposite their asser-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions in relation to the employment situation

Speaker: NA
Text: in the various defence factories. I advise

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable members opposite to study the

Speaker: NA
Text: facts of this subject, byfirst-handinspection

Speaker: NA
Text: and reading, before putting over the air

Speaker: NA
Text: stupid and nonsensical remarks about our

Speaker: NA
Text: defence preparations, and creating panic in

Speaker: NA
Text: the minds of the Australian people.

Speaker: Mr LUCHETTI
Text: Macquarie) [5.15] -

Speaker: NA
Text: The committee is considering the Estimates

Speaker: NA
Text: for the Department of Supply, the Depart-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of Defence Production and other ser-

Speaker: NA
Text: vices. I ask at the outset: What is the use

Speaker: NA
Text: of considering these items in view of the

Speaker: NA
Text: attitude to-day of the Minister for Defence

Speaker: NA
Text: Production ( Sir Eric Harrison) and other

Speaker: NA
Text: Ministers, who have indicated that the

Speaker: NA
Text: policy of the Government is undergoing a

Speaker: NA
Text: change with respect to these matters? Just

Speaker: NA
Text: how much can we believe of what is con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tained in these proposed votes? Does the

Speaker: NA
Text: information portray a correct picture of

Speaker: NA
Text: these departments' activities, or are we to

Speaker: NA
Text: understand that some new figures and some

Speaker: NA
Text: new basis for consideration will be arrived

Speaker: NA
Text: at, that employees are to be sacked from

Speaker: NA
Text: various departments and that the amount

Speaker: NA
Text: of money to be voted under these Estimates

Speaker: NA
Text: will be considerably in excess of the amount

Speaker: NA
Text: required?

Speaker: NA
Text: Before dealing with those matters, I join

Speaker: NA
Text: with the Leader of the Opposilion (Dr

Speaker: NA
Text: Evatt) in making a plea to the members of

Speaker: NA
Text: the committee, to the people of Australia,

Speaker: NA
Text: and to mankind generally, that we should

Speaker: NA
Text: view the matter of atomic war in an

Speaker: NA
Text: entirely different light. Surely the time has

Speaker: NA
Text: arrived when we, as responsible people

Speaker: NA
Text: elected to serve the people of Australia,

Speaker: NA
Text: should get into harmony with the thinkers

Speaker: NA
Text: and humanitarian people throughout the

Speaker: NA
Text: world who feel that some action ought to

Speaker: NA
Text: be taken in regard to this matter. Are we,

Speaker: NA
Text: the elected representatives of the people,

Speaker: NA
Text: such arrant cowards that we are not

Speaker: NA
Text: prepared to say that nuclear warfare is

Speaker: NA
Text: horrible and will bring destruction to man-

Speaker: NA
Text: kind, and that all sane people ought to play

Speaker: NA
Text: their part in seeing that it is overcome once

Speaker: NA
Text: and for all? 1 join with all honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: members who say that the policies of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Soviet Union, the United States of

Speaker: NA
Text: America, the United Kingdom and, for that

Speaker: NA
Text: matter, Australia's contribution too, should

Speaker: NA
Text: be reviewed. But where "can we start in

Speaker: NA
Text: dealing with a question of this kind? Do

Speaker: NA
Text: we agree with the other nations, or do we

Speaker: NA
Text: indicate to the world by our own actions

Speaker: NA
Text: what we think is right? If we really believe

Speaker: NA
Text: that what we arc doing is right, if we want

Speaker: NA
Text: to save generations of the future from the

Speaker: NA
Text: most agonizing and terrible death, then it

Speaker: NA
Text: is our responsibilily now. in the National

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament of Australia, during a time of

Speaker: NA
Text: peace, to say to the world, Now is the

Speaker: NA
Text: time to review this matter; and Australia,

Speaker: NA
Text: as one of the countries which has led the

Speaker: NA
Text: world in all sorts of reforms, will make

Speaker: NA
Text: its contribution and indicate just where we

Speaker: NA
Text: stand in relation to i t " . Consequently, I

Speaker: NA
Text: am pleased to support the Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition, who, in a clear and definite

Speaker: NA
Text: manner, highlights the importance of this

Speaker: NA
Text: matter.

Speaker: NA
Text: I desire, however, to speak upon another

Speaker: NA
Text: subject related to the Department of

Speaker: NA
Text: Defence Production. I should like to take

Speaker: NA
Text: the minds of the committee back not to the

Speaker: NA
Text: statement made by the Minister for Defence

Speaker: NA
Text: Production in this place a few minutes ago

Speaker: NA
Text: but to a statement which he made in this

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament approximately two years ago. I

Speaker: NA
Text: should like the Minister himself and the

Speaker: NA
Text: people of Australia who are concerned with

Speaker: NA
Text: the defence of this country to take notice

Speaker: NA
Text: of that statement. Two years ago, he said

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Government was proceeding with

Speaker: NA
Text: its programme and, in reply to remarks I

Speaker: NA
Text: was in the course of making, he indicated

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Commonwealth Government was

Speaker: NA
Text: proceeding with the manufacture of the

Speaker: NA
Text: new FN.30 rifle at the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: Small Arms Factory at Lithgow. His

Speaker: NA
Text: exact words were-

Speaker: NA
Text: In order lo obviate the necessity to rise later

Speaker: NA
Text: to reply to the honorable gentleman in respect ot

Speaker: NA
Text: the one matter, I now inform him lhal we have

Speaker: NA
Text: already placed orders for the new standard service

Speaker: NA
Text: rifles, which will be manufactured at Li.hgow.

Speaker: NA
Text: The date of that statement was 16th Septem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber, 1954. Two years have elapsed since

Speaker: NA
Text: that time. Yet, the Minister for Defence

Speaker: NA
Text: Production made a very important state-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment this afternoon in which he said that

Speaker: NA
Text: it will be two years before the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: will obtain the sealed drawings for this

Speaker: NA
Text: weapon. Two years have elapsed since that

Speaker: NA
Text: previous promise was made to the people

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australia. Not only did the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: make that statement to this Parliament, but

Speaker: NA
Text: he also went on record in the press. In the

Speaker: NA
Text: " Daily Telegraph" of 17th September,

Speaker: NA
Text: 1954. appears an article in which the Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter sought to bolster up his own status as

Speaker: NA
Text: a most progressive Minister by declaring

Speaker: NA
Text: that this service rifle was to be manufac-

Speaker: NA
Text: tured. Inter alia, the article reads-

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government had placed orders for the new

Speaker: NA
Text: s'.andard service rifle. Sir Eric Harrison said

Speaker: NA
Text: today.

Speaker: NA
Text: Sir Erie is Minisier for Defence Production. He

Speaker: NA
Text: told the House of Representatives that the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monweal .h Small Arms Factory at Lithgow would

Speaker: NA
Text: manufacture the rifle.

Speaker: NA
Text: The rifle is self-loading.

Speaker: NA
Text: The article then - deals with other aspects.

Speaker: NA
Text: Yet, the Minister now says that a further

Speaker: NA
Text: two years will elapse before the sealed draw-

Speaker: NA
Text: ings will be available to proceed with the

Speaker: NA
Text: manufacture of this weapon. I suggest that

Speaker: NA
Text: if the Minister had considered the planning

Speaker: NA
Text: of this service rifle with the same meticulous

Speaker: NA
Text: care and detail that he has planned his

Speaker: NA
Text: departure from Australia to take a job in

Speaker: NA
Text: Mayfair, the rifle would have been much

Speaker: NA
Text: further advanced than it is at the present

Speaker: NA
Text: time.

Speaker: NA
Text: 1 have sought information on this matter

Speaker: NA
Text: from the Minister for Defence Production

Speaker: NA
Text: and have asked him to go to Lithgow to

Speaker: NA
Text: make an inspection of the factory. He gave

Speaker: NA
Text: me a promise that he would visit Lithgow,

Speaker: NA
Text: but he has not yet visited the small arms

Speaker: NA
Text: factory. I do not blame the executive of

Speaker: NA
Text: the small arms factory at Lithgow. I

Speaker: NA
Text: join with the Minister in paying a very

Speaker: NA
Text: fine tribute to those engaged in the factory.

Speaker: NA
Text: I pay a compliment to those engaged on the

Speaker: NA
Text: Munitions Board generally, but I em-

Speaker: NA
Text: phasize that the Minister ought to set about

Speaker: NA
Text: to see what is wrong and take positive

Speaker: NA
Text: action to deal with this problem. It is of

Speaker: NA
Text: little use dealing with all the other matters

Speaker: NA
Text: relating to defence if this Government can-

Speaker: NA
Text: not produce a service rifle, or cannot even

Speaker: NA
Text: reach a decision in regard to the matter.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Minister should, without equivocause

Speaker: NA
Text: tion, now say what has caused the hold-up

Speaker: NA
Text: in the production of the new service rifle.

Speaker: NA
Text: All the Minister has said in the past must

Speaker: NA
Text: be rejected because it is not in accord with

Speaker: NA
Text: the facts. The facts speak for themselves

Speaker: NA
Text: and I say that the Minister had a duty

Speaker: NA
Text: to-day to tell the committee just how many

Speaker: NA
Text: people are to be dismissed from the various

Speaker: NA
Text: factories. He should have told the comAnglicized

Speaker: NA
Text: mittee this afternoon how many people are

Speaker: NA
Text: to be dismissed from the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: Small Arms Factory at Lithgow. It has

Speaker: NA
Text: been reported in the " Sydney Morning

Speaker: NA
Text: Herald " thai dismissals will occur

Speaker: NA
Text: factory and I should like to know from

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister whether the number will be

Speaker: NA
Text: 500, 700, 250 or any other figure.

Speaker: NA
Text: has had the opportunity to tell the comwhen

Speaker: NA
Text: mittee what the position is.

Speaker: NA
Text: The bitter pill in regard to this matter

Speaker: NA
Text: came from the Minister himself this after-

Speaker: NA
Text: noon when he indicated that a number oi

Speaker: NA
Text: dismissals will take place at the smail arms

Speaker: NA
Text: factory at Lithgow. When one considers,

Speaker: NA
Text: the proposed vote for this department, one

Speaker: NA
Text: sees lhat adequate funds are available to

Speaker: NA
Text: produce this rifle. What is wrong? is

Speaker: NA
Text: the Army to blame; does confusion and

Speaker: NA
Text: indecision exist in regard to the manufac-

Speaker: NA
Text: ture of the rifle from the military stand-

Speaker: NA
Text: point? If that is the case, this commiltee

Speaker: NA
Text: should know and the Minister should say

Speaker: NA
Text: so. If the Colonel Blimps in the United

Speaker: NA
Text: Kingdom War Office are to blame, thai

Speaker: NA
Text: should also be stated. Plainly, the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: should say whether the new rifle is to be

Speaker: NA
Text: accepted. If it is not, why have definite

Speaker: NA
Text: promises been made over a period of time?

Speaker: NA
Text: It is pertinent to ask whether the rifle has

Speaker: NA
Text: actually been accepted at this stage, and

Speaker: NA
Text: whether agreement has been reached be-

Speaker: NA
Text: tween the North Atlantic Treaty Organiza-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion and the Commonwealth of Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: I very much doubt whether agreement has

Speaker: NA
Text: been reached. Indeed, I should say that, if

Speaker: NA
Text: agreement has been reached, the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Government has been treated as the poor

Speaker: NA
Text: relation. Indeed, the Government is deserv-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing of censure for its failure to send overseas

Speaker: NA
Text: until quite recently responsible officers of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Department of Defence Production in

Speaker: NA
Text: connexion with this matter. That action

Speaker: NA
Text: should have been taken two years ago.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is not much use dealing with this

Speaker: NA
Text: matter in this fashion now. It is not much

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister telling us what he intends

Speaker: NA
Text: to do at St. Mary's unless we know the type

Speaker: NA
Text: of weapon to be used. So much time has

Speaker: NA
Text: elapsed-tw o years to this stage-ar>< l *

Speaker: NA
Text: further two years will pass before the sealed

Speaker: NA
Text: drawings are received. The Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Defence Production made the magnificent

Speaker: NA
Text: statement that the drawings had to be trans-

Speaker: NA
Text: lated from the metric system to an

Speaker: NA
Text: version. One could steal plans

Speaker: NA
Text: from an opponent in a war and go into pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duction much speedier than this.

Speaker: NA
Text: Sir Eric Harrison -Tel l that to Canada

Speaker: NA
Text: in that or to the United Kingdom.

Speaker: Mr LUCHETTI
Text: I remind the Minister,

Speaker: NA
Text: who is a champion of private enterprise,

Speaker: NA
Text: He that General Motors-Holden's Limited,

Speaker: NA
Text: it decided to change the type of car

Speaker: NA
Text: it was making, continued production of the

Speaker: NA
Text: existing model and produced a new model

Speaker: NA
Text: within a year without altering a scale or

Speaker: NA
Text: making any changeover at all. If General

Speaker: NA
Text: Motors-Holden's Limited could do that,

Speaker: NA
Text: certainly the Commonwealth should be able

Speaker: NA
Text: to do much better.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is a reflection upon this Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: that Canada was obliged to step in and

Speaker: NA
Text: say, " We will pioneer this work because it

Speaker: NA
Text: is not being done in the United Kingdom

Speaker: NA
Text: and because Australia has not been invited

Speaker: NA
Text: into the councils of Nato to play its part

Speaker: NA
Text: in the development of this weapon ". It

Speaker: NA
Text: is a most serious matter. It goes beyond the

Speaker: NA
Text: city and district of Lithgow. The question

Speaker: NA
Text: te whether we are to produce in this country

Speaker: NA
Text: Ihe weapons we need or whether we, like

Speaker: NA
Text: the Arab nations, shall become dependent

Speaker: NA
Text: upon the gun-runners of the world for the

Speaker: NA
Text: weapons that we require for our security.

Speaker: NA
Text: We can have all the new weapons of

Speaker: NA
Text: destruction, chaos and suppression, but in

Speaker: NA
Text: the end the areas that we take over must be

Speaker: NA
Text: policed. The only way in which any area

Speaker: NA
Text: can be policed is for the occupation forces

Speaker: NA
Text: to have rifles or weapons of that nature.

Speaker: NA
Text: I suggest that it is time the United King-

Speaker: NA
Text: dom, the United States of America and the

Speaker: NA
Text: various members of the North Atlantic

Speaker: NA
Text: Treaty Organization finally determined this

Speaker: NA
Text: question one way or the other. It is utterly

Speaker: NA
Text: absurd that we can get plans from Belgium

Speaker: NA
Text: but cannot proceed immediately with the

Speaker: NA
Text: production of this rifle. I ask the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mittee to consider this as a most important

Speaker: NA
Text: matter. These things warrant a con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sidered statement from the Minister. He

Speaker: NA
Text: has tried to emphasize certain difficulties.

Speaker: NA
Text: The change over to the manufacture of a

Speaker: NA
Text: new rifle should certainly not require four

Speaker: NA
Text: years before tooling-up commences. Any

Speaker: NA
Text: statement made by the Minister for De-

Speaker: NA
Text: fence Production in the past has begged the

Speaker: NA
Text: question.

Speaker: NA
Text: I pay a tribute to the men who have the

Speaker: NA
Text: capacity, the ingenuity and the skill to do

Speaker: NA
Text: this work. The men at the small arms fac-

Speaker: NA
Text: tory at Lithgow have produced all the

Speaker: NA
Text: weapons that the Administration has asked

Speaker: NA
Text: them to produce. In addition, they have

Speaker: NA
Text: produced Westinghouse talking apparatus

Speaker: NA
Text: and sealed units for refrigerators and ful-

Speaker: NA
Text: filled many other peace-time orders. Surely

Speaker: NA
Text: the skilled operatives should be kept in that

Speaker: NA
Text: factory so that their services and skill can

Speaker: NA
Text: be called upon in the future. It is most

Speaker: NA
Text: unfortunate that their services will be lost

Speaker: NA
Text: to the nation.

Speaker: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN
Text: ( Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bowden) -Order ! The honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber's time has expired.

Speaker: Mr BOSTOCK
Text: Indi) 15.301 -Th e pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: position of the Leader of the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: (Dr Evatt) that we should cease atomic

Speaker: NA
Text: weapon tests reflects, I believe, the wishes

Speaker: NA
Text: of all sensible people in the world. But

Speaker: NA
Text: we will not achieve that position merely

Speaker: NA
Text: by talking about it. To forego essential

Speaker: NA
Text: tests whilst atomic weapons are not com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pletely banned and controlled would be to

Speaker: NA
Text: forego the race to keep pace with our

Speaker: NA
Text: potential enemies in the development of

Speaker: NA
Text: this modern, disastrous weapon of mass-

Speaker: NA
Text: destruction.

Speaker: NA
Text: Already the United Nations has a Dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: armament Committee which is constantly

Speaker: NA
Text: examining the question of banning and

Speaker: NA
Text: properly controlling atomic weapons. It

Speaker: NA
Text: has been unable to reach any satisfactory

Speaker: NA
Text: arrangement which would ensure the proper

Speaker: NA
Text: policing of such a system. Until that

Speaker: NA
Text: situation is arrived at, it would be nothing

Speaker: NA
Text: less than suicidal for the western democ-

Speaker: NA
Text: racies to relax their efforts to develop

Speaker: NA
Text: atomic weapons.

Speaker: NA
Text: As was pointed out by the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Canning ( Mr Hamilton), in

Speaker: NA
Text: this atomic race we have to consider very

Speaker: NA
Text: carefully not only the attack side but also

Speaker: NA
Text: the defence side of atomic weapons. I

Speaker: NA
Text: notice in the Estimates that last year the

Speaker: NA
Text: provision for civil defence was £234,000,

Speaker: NA
Text: of which only £88,782 was spent, and that

Speaker: NA
Text: this year the provision is only £70,000.

Speaker: NA
Text: That does not seem to me to reflect an

Speaker: NA
Text: energetic policy for the promotion of civil

Speaker: NA
Text: defence in this country. Quite recently,

Speaker: NA
Text: Lord Montgomery said that unless civil

Speaker: NA
Text: defence is effective in any future atomic

Speaker: NA
Text: war, it is doubtful whether any nation

Speaker: NA
Text: could survive. In other words, unless an

Speaker: NA
Text: effective civil defence organization is estab-

Speaker: NA
Text: lished, the attack organization is likely to

Speaker: NA
Text: fail because the morale of the people will

Speaker: NA
Text: be destroyed. I know that civil defence is

Speaker: NA
Text: a very difficult matter and that a great

Speaker: NA
Text: number of people say that the probability

Speaker: NA
Text: of attack is remote. But the result of an

Speaker: NA
Text: atomic explosion on one of our major

Speaker: NA
Text: centres of population would be such a catas-

Speaker: NA
Text: trophe-suc h a horrible affair-tha t we

Speaker: NA
Text: should take reasonable precautions even if

Speaker: NA
Text: the possibility of attack is not strong.

Speaker: NA
Text: We could do certain things which, I be-

Speaker: NA
Text: lieve, would help but which perhaps would

Speaker: NA
Text: not cost a great deal of money. I think

Speaker: NA
Text: we could do three things. Firstly, we could

Speaker: NA
Text: promulgate information about personal sur-

Speaker: NA
Text: vival. I do not think that there are many

Speaker: NA
Text: people in this country who know what to

Speaker: NA
Text: do, in the event of an atomic attack, to

Speaker: NA
Text: preserve their own welfare. It would not

Speaker: NA
Text: be very expensive to promulgate through-

Speaker: NA
Text: out the Commonwealth, and particularly in

Speaker: NA
Text: our more populous centres, information on

Speaker: NA
Text: some of the simple things that a person can

Speaker: NA
Text: do to preserve his life. To give an example

Speaker: NA
Text: of the sort of thing that I have in mind,

Speaker: NA
Text: I shall read a paragraph from a publication

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Home Office of the United Kingdom

Speaker: NA
Text: Government. The paragraph reads-

Speaker: NA
Text: People in the open might receive second degree

Speaker: NA
Text: burns . . . on exposed skin at a range of 16

Speaker: NA
Text: rniles from a 10 megaton ground burst bomb.

Speaker: NA
Text: . . . If, however, they should take cover in

Speaker: NA
Text: a few seconds they would escape this damage.

Speaker: NA
Text: Moreover, at this range the blast wave would

Speaker: NA
Text: not arrive for another minute and a half so that

Speaker: NA
Text: any effects due to the blast in the open . . .

Speaker: NA
Text: could be completely avoided.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is a very simple instruction, but 1 am

Speaker: NA
Text: prepared to wager that if one asked the first

Speaker: NA
Text: half-dozen people one met whether, in

Speaker: NA
Text: event of an atomic explosion, they would

Speaker: NA
Text: be better inside a building or outside

Speaker: NA
Text: they would not know. There are a number

Speaker: NA
Text: of other steps of this kind that we could

Speaker: NA
Text: take. They would not cost a great deal, and

Speaker: NA
Text: an education campaign of this nature would

Speaker: NA
Text: pay good dividends.

Speaker: NA
Text: The second matter that we should attend

Speaker: NA
Text: to, and which would not involve very much

Speaker: NA
Text: expenditure, is the establishment of some

Speaker: NA
Text: sort of radiation warning network, using

Speaker: NA
Text: existing communication systems in conDepartment

Speaker: NA
Text: junction with the meteorological organizaas

Speaker: NA
Text: tions, so that i f an atomic

Speaker: NA
Text: place our warning organization could tell

Speaker: NA
Text: people within the radius of radioactive

Speaker: NA
Text: danger that they should do something about

Speaker: NA
Text: it quickly. That is merely a matter of

Speaker: NA
Text: organization and planning, and would cost

Speaker: NA
Text: virtually nothing.

Speaker: NA
Text: Thirdly, we should increase very greatly*

Speaker: NA
Text: the number of people who are trained in

Speaker: NA
Text: matters of civil defence. The Government

Speaker: NA
Text: has established a school and has turned

Speaker: NA
Text: four or five classes of trained civil defence

Speaker: NA
Text: instructors. That is not nearly sufficient.

Speaker: NA
Text: We want large numbers of trained people

Speaker: NA
Text: dispersed throughout the Commonwealth,

Speaker: NA
Text: and particularly throughout the major

Speaker: NA
Text: centres of population. The way in which

Speaker: NA
Text: this might be done, I suggest, is to transfer

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth responsibility for civil

Speaker: NA
Text: defence from the Department of the Interior

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Department of the Army. That

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibility should, logically, rest with

Speaker: NA
Text: the Department of the Army, because, iri

Speaker: NA
Text: modern times, civil defence is definitely a

Speaker: NA
Text: military responsibility. If an atomic bomb

Speaker: NA
Text: fell on Sydney or Melbourne, martial law

Speaker: NA
Text: would be inevitable. The military authori-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties would have to take over, and it seems

Speaker: NA
Text: only logical and reasonable that civil

Speaker: NA
Text: defence functions should be allocated to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Army. If that were done, and if the

Speaker: NA
Text: Army included civil defence as a major

Speaker: NA
Text: subject in the curriculum of national

Speaker: NA
Text: service trainees, every year we would turn

Speaker: NA
Text: out thousands of young men trained, to a

Speaker: NA
Text: significant degree, in civil defence duties.

Speaker: NA
Text: Furthermore, they would be dispersed

Speaker: NA
Text: throughout the 'Commonwealth.

Speaker: NA
Text: While I do not advocate the expenditure

Speaker: NA
Text: of large amounts of money on shelters or

Speaker: NA
Text: things of that kind at this stage, I do believe

Speaker: NA
Text: that there are a few simple matters, wbich

Speaker: NA
Text: the would not cost very much, fhat we could

Speaker: NA
Text: attend to. We should disseminate widely

Speaker: NA
Text: it, information about personal survival. We

Speaker: NA
Text: should tell fhe people of the action that

Speaker: NA
Text: they should take, on fheir own initiative.

Speaker: NA
Text: We should establish a warning organization,

Speaker: NA
Text: so that people may be informed whether

Speaker: NA
Text: they are in the path of resultant Tadioactive

Speaker: NA
Text: fall out from an atomic explosion. Thirdly,

Speaker: NA
Text: we should considerably increase the num-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers of persons trained in civil defence

Speaker: NA
Text: matters, by transferring that function from

Speaker: NA
Text: the Department of the Interior to the

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Army, and including it

Speaker: NA
Text: a major .subject in the training of national

Speaker: NA
Text: blast did take service trainees.

Speaker: NA
Text: MT. WENTWORTH (Mackellar) [5.40J.

Speaker: NA
Text: - I support the views put forward by the

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member for Indi ( Mr Bostock).

Speaker: NA
Text: The three practical courses of action that

Speaker: NA
Text: he has suggested are well worth while. I

Speaker: NA
Text: add to them only one suggestion: The people

Speaker: NA
Text: should be trained in survival procedure in

Speaker: NA
Text: the event of their being in an area of radio-

Speaker: NA
Text: active fallout. The lethal area of fall-

Speaker: NA
Text: out out can be very much greater than the

Speaker: NA
Text: area directly affected by bomb damage, but

Speaker: NA
Text: fallout need not be lethal if we know how

Speaker: NA
Text: to deal with it. Therefore, in comparatively

Speaker: NA
Text: large areas those who have been trained will

Speaker: NA
Text: survive an atomic explosion, while those

Speaker: NA
Text: who have not been trained will die.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is with great regret that I notice the

Speaker: NA
Text: meagre provisions made in these Estimates

Speaker: NA
Text: for civil defence. Indeed, the whole posi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion with regard to civil defence is

Speaker: NA
Text: regrettable. The Government has not faced

Speaker: NA
Text: up to its responsibilities, and it is sadly

Speaker: NA
Text: neglecting this vital matter. I do not

Speaker: NA
Text: suggest that civil defence will ever be

Speaker: NA
Text: anything more than part of a complete

Speaker: NA
Text: defence plan, but I am reminded by the

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member for Indi of the words of

Speaker: NA
Text: Field Marshal Montgomery, who said that

Speaker: NA
Text: without adequate civil defence all other

Speaker: NA
Text: defence preparations are likely to be

Speaker: NA
Text: brought to nothing.

Speaker: NA
Text: What is the position in this country with

Speaker: NA
Text: regard to civil defence? Last year, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government allocated for this purpose the

Speaker: NA
Text: miserably inadequate sum of £234,000, and

Speaker: NA
Text: of that amount it spent barely one-third. On

Speaker: NA
Text: civil defence last year we spent only

Speaker: NA
Text: £88.000, and this year the allocation is even

Speaker: NA
Text: less than that amount, being a mere £70,000.

Speaker: NA
Text: I suggest to the Government that it is

Speaker: NA
Text: nonsense to restrict our expenditure to this

Speaker: NA
Text: amount. Something is wrong. This, surely,

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot be the considered plan of any person

Speaker: NA
Text: who looks at the situation sensibly. In other

Speaker: NA
Text: parts of the world very much more has

Speaker: NA
Text: been done in the field of civil defence, but

Speaker: NA
Text: even in other countries, such as the United

Speaker: NA
Text: States of America and Great Britain, it is

Speaker: NA
Text: admitted that what is being done is still

Speaker: NA
Text: inadequate.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have been told that the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: is following an appreciation of the situation

Speaker: NA
Text: made by its military advisers, and that

Speaker: NA
Text: there is no danger. I do not know whether

Speaker: NA
Text: the appreciation that is spoken of is to that

Speaker: NA
Text: effect or not. All I can say about it is that

Speaker: NA
Text: the enemy will not consider himself bound

Speaker: NA
Text: by even the most intelligent appreciation of

Speaker: NA
Text: our Chiefs of Staff. There is a risk, there

Speaker: NA
Text: is a possibility, and, as the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Indi said, while that risk and

Speaker: NA
Text: possibility exist we should do something

Speaker: NA
Text: about them. Some people say that Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian cities are not targets of a sufficiently

Speaker: NA
Text: high priority to warrant anxiety on our

Speaker: NA
Text: part. That kind of argument portrays

Speaker: NA
Text: complete ignorance of what is happening

Speaker: NA
Text: in the world to-day. The present situation

Speaker: NA
Text: is this: The enemy is not short of nuclear

Speaker: NA
Text: resources. By attacking targets of lower

Speaker: NA
Text: priority he will not in any substantial way

Speaker: NA
Text: diminish his power to attack targets of

Speaker: NA
Text: higher priority. Indeed, the targets of

Speaker: NA
Text: lower priority are, perhaps, the more likely

Speaker: NA
Text: to be attacked, for reasons that Sir Winston

Speaker: NA
Text: Churchill has given. He has suggested

Speaker: NA
Text: that the great powers, the present possessors

Speaker: NA
Text: of nuclear weapons, are not likely to em-

Speaker: NA
Text: bark on a metropolitan war involving the

Speaker: NA
Text: destruction of their own cities. Fringe

Speaker: NA
Text: wars, however, are not ruled out by this

Speaker: NA
Text: concept of the situation, and the nations

Speaker: NA
Text: that have no nuclear resources may find

Speaker: NA
Text: themselves exposed to the danger of these

Speaker: NA
Text: fringe wars, and even to the use of nuclear

Speaker: NA
Text: weapons against their territories by their

Speaker: NA
Text: enemies, simply because they are withoui

Speaker: NA
Text: the power to retaliate. The very fact thai

Speaker: NA
Text: it is unthinkable for the Great Powers to

Speaker: NA
Text: embark on courses which mean metro-

Speaker: NA
Text: politan war for them, means that they limit

Speaker: NA
Text: their power to come to the aid of those

Speaker: NA
Text: countries on the fringe that may be attacked.

Speaker: NA
Text: Therefore, looking at the thing reasonably

Speaker: NA
Text: and logically, one would say that the cities

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australia are in at least as great danger

Speaker: NA
Text: of nuclear attack as are the cities of Great

Speaker: NA
Text: Britain or America-perhap s even greater

Speaker: NA
Text: danger, because we are a fringe nation and

Speaker: NA
Text: have not that power of atomic retaliation

Speaker: NA
Text: which alone is likely to deter an enemy from

Speaker: NA
Text: attacking.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is therefore, I think, a matter of very-

Speaker: NA
Text: grave negligence that the Government is

Speaker: NA
Text: leaving this aspect of our defence prepara-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions entirely untouched. The honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Indi said a moment ago that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Department of the Interior was not the

Speaker: NA
Text: right place from which to provide this

Speaker: NA
Text: defence service. There, again, I agree

Speaker: NA
Text: with him. He is doing no more than echo-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the most responsible opinion overseas

Speaker: NA
Text: It is wrong to consider this purely as a

Speaker: NA
Text: subsidiary function of a department and

Speaker: NA
Text: put it in a place in the budget-eve n in this

Speaker: NA
Text: slightly contemptuous form-t o which ii

Speaker: NA
Text: does not belong. Though it is defence

Speaker: NA
Text: expenditure it is put under the control of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Department of the Interior.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have done nothing of any con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sequence as yet. The lact that we spent

Speaker: NA
Text: only £88.000 last year shows how little wc

Speaker: NA
Text: have done. It is true that at Mount

Speaker: NA
Text: Macedon the Commonwealth Government

Speaker: NA
Text: has set up a defence school. Of its kind

Speaker: NA
Text: it is an excellent and efficient establish-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. I was privileged to be present al

Speaker: NA
Text: the opening ceremony. I know some of

Speaker: NA
Text: the instructors and I have had the privi-

Speaker: NA
Text: lege of seeing the courses which are being

Speaker: NA
Text: given to the trainees. There is nothing

Speaker: NA
Text: wrong with the school or the way in which

Speaker: NA
Text: it is administered, but it is miserably inade-

Speaker: NA
Text: quate for the kind of emergency with which

Speaker: NA
Text: we might be faced. The school is training

Speaker: NA
Text: a few people, but it is not a few people

Speaker: NA
Text: that one needs in an emergency such as

Speaker: NA
Text: may-w e hope it will not-com e upon us.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honorable member for Indi has been

Speaker: NA
Text: quite right in stressing that we should train

Speaker: NA
Text: masses of people in the measures essential

Speaker: NA
Text: for their own personal survival. This can-

Speaker: NA
Text: not be done by conducting two or three

Speaker: NA
Text: classes a quarter, each graduating from one

Speaker: NA
Text: small, single school. This school has, how-

Speaker: NA
Text: ever, one very valuable aspect. Its indoc-

Speaker: NA
Text: trination courses may allow other people

Speaker: NA
Text: to learn of the problem and thus spread an

Speaker: NA
Text: awareness of it throughout the community.

Speaker: NA
Text: In this way the school, although not directly

Speaker: NA
Text: of very much consequence, may have the

Speaker: NA
Text: excellent,, indirect effect of generating

Speaker: NA
Text: public opinion of the kind that will force

Speaker: NA
Text: upon the Government a proper, more com-

Speaker: NA
Text: prehensive and more adequate policy for

Speaker: NA
Text: the present situation.

Speaker: NA
Text: I was very pleased to hear the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: remark some weeks ago that he would be

Speaker: NA
Text: glad if, at some later time, honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers of this House could undergo a short

Speaker: NA
Text: indoctrination course at the school. They

Speaker: NA
Text: would learn the facts of nuclear warfare

Speaker: NA
Text: in their most authentic form-on e

Speaker: NA
Text: which they could not query-an d realize

Speaker: NA
Text: the political implications of the physical

Speaker: NA
Text: facts which they face.

Speaker: NA
Text: Honorable members will recall that for

Speaker: NA
Text: some time now I have tried to press this

Speaker: NA
Text: matter by every means in my power. I am

Speaker: NA
Text: afraid that when it was before the Parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment Jast year the Government misled the

Speaker: NA
Text: House by telling it of the great plans that

Speaker: NA
Text: allegedly were being made; that it was not

Speaker: NA
Text: necessary to mobilize the States or to have

Speaker: NA
Text: liaison with them and that, as everything

Speaker: NA
Text: was in hand, all we had to do was to leave

Speaker: NA
Text: it to the Government.

Speaker: NA
Text: It has not turned out that way nor, as

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable members can see by the miser-

Speaker: NA
Text: able allocation of £70,000, is anything of

Speaker: NA
Text: the kind projected for next year. It is true

Speaker: NA
Text: that one State-m y own State of New

Speaker: NA
Text: South Wales-ha s endeavoured to set up a

Speaker: NA
Text: rudimentary organization. It is, however,

Speaker: NA
Text: no more than rudimentary, though the

Speaker: NA
Text: officers concerned are doing an excellent

Speaker: NA
Text: job within the resources allocated to them.

Speaker: NA
Text: But the crisis, if there is to be a crisis-

Speaker: NA
Text: and we all hope that there will not be-

Speaker: NA
Text: may come upon us quite suddenly. Who

Speaker: NA
Text: could have told us even a few months ago

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Suez affair would boil up as it did?

Speaker: NA
Text: Who could have told us, a few weeks ago,

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Suez affair would pass off without

Speaker: NA
Text: resort to force of any kind? Who can tell

Speaker: NA
Text: us that now? It may be that, if this organi-

Speaker: NA
Text: zation is to be needed, it will be needed at

Speaker: NA
Text: quite short notice.

Speaker: NA
Text: I wish to say quite clearly and definitely

Speaker: NA
Text: that the implementation of a proper civil

Speaker: NA
Text: defence policy cannot be achieved quickly.

Speaker: NA
Text: It could not be achieved quickly even in a

Speaker: NA
Text: country where there were no constitutional

Speaker: NA
Text: difficulties, but in this country, where the

Speaker: NA
Text: constitutional division of powers between

Speaker: NA
Text: this Parliament and the State Parliaments

Speaker: NA
Text: is an extra impediment to quick and efficient

Speaker: NA
Text: organization, even more time is needed. I

Speaker: NA
Text: appeal to the Government once again to get

Speaker: NA
Text: the States together and try to iron out these

Speaker: NA
Text: constitutional difficulties; not to repeat the

Speaker: NA
Text: eyewash which it tried to put over this

Speaker: NA
Text: House when the subject was last being

Speaker: NA
Text: debated, but to get on and do the job.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am not suggesting that even the most

Speaker: NA
Text: efficient civil defence is enough. Nor am \

Speaker: NA
Text: suggesting that the defence programme has

Speaker: NA
Text: not to include a great deal more than civil

Speaker: NA
Text: defence. This is only one small corner of

Speaker: NA
Text: defence, but for lack of this the whok

Speaker: NA
Text: programme might fail. For lack of this the

Speaker: NA
Text: lives of our people are in danger. We all

Speaker: NA
Text: hope sincerely that the world-wide plan for

Speaker: NA
Text: effective nuclear control will become a

Speaker: NA
Text: reality. We know that civil defence, at its

Speaker: NA
Text: best, can be only a temporary expediency,

Speaker: NA
Text: but until we can induce Russia to join us in

Speaker: NA
Text: a system of nuclear control which would

Speaker: NA
Text: remove the fears of mankind we must take

Speaker: NA
Text: these other precautions. Survival is part of

Speaker: NA
Text: defence.

Speaker: Dr EVATT
Text: Barton-Leade r of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition) [5.55] - I wish to refer to the

Speaker: NA
Text: speeches of the honorable member for Indi

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Bostock) and the honorable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Mackellar ( Mr Wentworth). The nub

Speaker: NA
Text: of the question is to be found in the con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cluding sentences of the speech of the

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member for Mackellar. I

Speaker: NA
Text: believe that the true inference to be drawn

Speaker: NA
Text: from the minute, almost contemptuous vote

Speaker: NA
Text: for civil defence which has been referred

Speaker: NA
Text: to, is that the Government does not en-

Speaker: NA
Text: visage the possibility of war, especially

Speaker: NA
Text: nuclear warfare, reaching our shores.

Speaker: NA
Text: Apparently, the Government believes that it

Speaker: NA
Text: has some justification for its belief. Other-

Speaker: NA
Text: wise, it would be a most recreant act not to

Speaker: NA
Text: make provision against nuclear warfare.

Speaker: NA
Text: Equally-an d I think that this is implied

Speaker: NA
Text: also in the speech of the honorable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Mackellar-i f we are to have so con-

Speaker: NA
Text: temptuous a vote for civil defence, there

Speaker: NA
Text: must be an all-out effort by the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: to ensure that a firm and binding agree-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment is reached in relation to nuclear wea-

Speaker: NA
Text: pons and nuclear experiments. My com-

Speaker: NA
Text: plaint against the Government is that it is

Speaker: NA
Text: doing nothing in this direction.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honorable member for Mackellar, in

Speaker: NA
Text: referring to Russia in this chamber, called

Speaker: NA
Text: the Russians " the enemy ". I do not think

Speaker: NA
Text: that he should do that. I am not saying that

Speaker: NA
Text: merely as a point of order. Surely the situa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion has eased to a substantial extent since

Speaker: NA
Text: the summit talks. They were delayed long

Speaker: NA
Text: enough. Sir Winston Churchill suggested

Speaker: NA
Text: them in 1953. That was the new hope of

Speaker: NA
Text: the world. They were not held until two

Speaker: NA
Text: years later but, undoubtedly, the general

Speaker: NA
Text: climate has greatly improved. It is in that

Speaker: NA
Text: connexion that I want to urge again activity

Speaker: NA
Text: by this Government. Unless some initiative

Speaker: NA
Text: is taken by Australia, I do not believe that

Speaker: NA
Text: the great Powers-Russia , Great Britain

Speaker: NA
Text: and the United States of America-wil l take

Speaker: NA
Text: the initiative soon enough. They have all

Speaker: NA
Text: expressed willingness to ban experiments

Speaker: NA
Text: with nuclear weapons, but an agreement to

Speaker: NA
Text: that effect must be entered into by all of

Speaker: NA
Text: them. All have expressed their willingness.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Russian Foreign Minister did so twice.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Prime Minister of the United Kingdom.

Speaker: NA
Text: Sir Anthony Eden, as recently as 24th July

Speaker: NA
Text: last, when speaking of the muitiplicaiion

Speaker: NA
Text: of experiments, said-

Speaker: NA
Text: We would have preferred to deal wilh this

Speaker: NA
Text: ih the context of a disarmament convention, but we

Speaker: NA
Text: are quite ready now to discuss that matter sepa-

Speaker: NA
Text: . rately from a disarmament convention.

Speaker: NA
Text: Yet it has been said, in this debate and

Speaker: NA
Text: elsewhere, that we cannot deal with nuclear

Speaker: NA
Text: experiments unless we have a firm, binding

Speaker: NA
Text: agreement covering all nuclear weapons, and

Speaker: NA
Text: their use in war as well as conventional

Speaker: NA
Text: weapons. I believe that is the. approach

Speaker: NA
Text: that should be made. I do not believe that

Speaker: NA
Text: the United States of America requires any-,

Speaker: NA
Text: thing more than some firm, binding assur-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance that if it gives up nuclear weapons,

Speaker: NA
Text: Russia will do so as well. That is evident

Speaker: NA
Text: from statements that have been made on

Speaker: NA
Text: behalf of the United States of America.

Speaker: NA
Text: Could that not be made certain? Is it not

Speaker: NA
Text: a fact-a s I believe it to be-tha t no nuclear

Speaker: NA
Text: experiment of any significance can be con-

Speaker: NA
Text: ducted in any one of the three major coun-

Speaker: NA
Text: tries without the other two knowing about

Speaker: NA
Text: it immediately. If such an experiment is

Speaker: NA
Text: made, it is readily detectable. Therefore,

Speaker: NA
Text: in a sense, we could get to tbe situation

Speaker: NA
Text: quickly if there were any breach of the

Speaker: NA
Text: primary undertaking.

Speaker: NA
Text: Sitting suspended from S.S9 to 8 p.m.

Speaker: Dr EVATT
Text: Durin g the time remain-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing to me, I should like to summarize as

Speaker: NA
Text: quickly as I can what seem to us to be the

Speaker: NA
Text: salient points in this great controversy over

Speaker: NA
Text: experiments with the atomic and hydrogen

Speaker: NA
Text: bombs, experiments conducted, of course, on

Speaker: NA
Text: the assumption that in some circumstances

Speaker: NA
Text: they will be utilized in warfare. The Oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: sition has sought to reduce the proposed vote

Speaker: NA
Text: in order to demand of the Government that

Speaker: NA
Text: it take some action other than that which

Speaker: NA
Text: it is taking in connexion with these experi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments. We demand of the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: that it bring the matter before the three

Speaker: NA
Text: great powers which are the sole possessors

Speaker: NA
Text: of atomic and hydrogen bombs; and I re-

Speaker: NA
Text: mind the Government that the leaders of

Speaker: NA
Text: each of those countries have expressed their

Speaker: NA
Text: willingness to agree to the banning of the

Speaker: NA
Text: experiments subject to reasonable safe-

Speaker: NA
Text: guards for the protection of them all. I

Speaker: NA
Text: have referred to the statement by Sir

Speaker: NA
