Text: Anthony Eden that he was quite willing to

Speaker: NA
Text: separate the experimental use of these

Speaker: NA
Text: bombs from the general problem of disarma-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment and to treat that as the first step to-

Speaker: NA
Text: wards major disarmament. The same offer

Speaker: NA
Text: has been made twice by the Foreign Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter of Russia and by the authorities in the

Speaker: NA
Text: United States of America, again subject to

Speaker: NA
Text: certain safeguards. I point out that it is a

Speaker: NA
Text: vital part of our case that we have a safe-

Speaker: NA
Text: guard in the fact that, because of the

Speaker: NA
Text: marvellous -instruments available to scien-

Speaker: NA
Text: tists, it is possible to detect from a great

Speaker: NA
Text: distance whether a bomb has been exploded.

Speaker: NA
Text: By this means, any of the three powers can

Speaker: NA
Text: detect whether the agreement has been

Speaker: NA
Text: breached or honoured.

Speaker: NA
Text: One object, of course, in banning the

Speaker: NA
Text: use of bombs for experimental purposes is

Speaker: NA
Text: the banning of their use altogether for pur-

Speaker: NA
Text: poses of war, and in this connexion I desire

Speaker: NA
Text: to make a short reference to a statement

Speaker: NA
Text: appearing in fhe " Christian Science

Speaker: NA
Text: Monitor " of 29th June, as published in the

Speaker: NA
Text: United States of America. I t sets out that

Speaker: NA
Text: official army estimates showed that a full-

Speaker: NA
Text: scale nuclear attack on the Union of Soviet

Speaker: NA
Text: Socialist Republics could kill several hundred

Speaker: NA
Text: millions of people, including probably

Speaker: NA
Text: millions of America's own allies outside the

Speaker: NA
Text: Soviet Union, depending on which way the

Speaker: NA
Text: wind was blowing. That is an official state-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment that was published despite censorship

Speaker: NA
Text: in the United States of America. Senator

Speaker: NA
Text: Duff asked this question of General Gavin-

Speaker: NA
Text: If we got into a nuclear war and our strategic

Speaker: NA
Text: Air Force made an assult in force against Russia

Speaker: NA
Text: with nuclear weapons so that the weapons exploded

Speaker: NA
Text: in a way where the prevailing winds would carry

Speaker: NA
Text: them south east over Russia, what would be the

Speaker: NA
Text: effect in the way of death?

Speaker: NA
Text: General Gavin said he would answer, but

Speaker: NA
Text: he added that the question should be

Speaker: NA
Text: directed to the Air Force. He then gave

Speaker: NA
Text: this reply-

Speaker: NA
Text: Current planning estimates run on the order

Speaker: NA
Text: several hundred million deaths. That would be

Speaker: NA
Text: either way, depending on whicb way the wind

Speaker: NA
Text: blew.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is surely ample evidence to support

Speaker: NA
Text: the assertion that the winds have a definite

Speaker: NA
Text: effect upon the area in which the greatest

Speaker: NA
Text: amount of damage and destruction and the

Speaker: NA
Text: greatest number of deaths occur. It is also

Speaker: NA
Text: supported by the Maralinga tests. We

Speaker: NA
Text: know that those tests were postponed

Speaker: NA
Text: because the wind was not blowing in the

Speaker: NA
Text: direction for which provision had been

Speaker: NA
Text: made. The weapon was not released until

Speaker: NA
Text: the signal was given that the wind was

Speaker: NA
Text: blowing in the required direction. I repeat

Speaker: NA
Text: that it supports the statement in the

Speaker: NA
Text: " Christian Science Monitor" that the

Speaker: NA
Text: direction of the wind does affect the area

Speaker: NA
Text: contaminated from radiation. In those

Speaker: NA
Text: circumstances, i t is obvious that there Js an

Speaker: NA
Text: element of peril, and it is only probably

Speaker: NA
Text: because great, scientific achievement has

Speaker: NA
Text: -been favoured by chance that the experi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments have been conducted so far without

Speaker: NA
Text: great damage and loss of life. We all

Speaker: NA
Text: know that loss and injury did result from

Speaker: NA
Text: the Bikini experiment, but in that case an

Speaker: NA
Text: H-bomb, not an atom bomb, was exploded.

Speaker: NA
Text: Actually, I think it caused the deaths of a

Speaker: NA
Text: number of Japanese fishermen who were

Speaker: NA
Text: in the affected area.

Speaker: NA
Text: That New Zealander, Lord Rutherford,

Speaker: NA
Text: the great mathematician and nuclear

Speaker: NA
Text: physicist, first saw the way in which this

Speaker: NA
Text: field of science could lead to inventions

Speaker: NA
Text: which, properly controlled, would bring

Speaker: NA
Text: comfort, happiness and power to thousands

Speaker: NA
Text: of millions of people throughout the world.

Speaker: NA
Text: What we want from the leaders of nations

Speaker: NA
Text: is a spirit of determination and humanity,

Speaker: NA
Text: without which these weapons must become

Speaker: NA
Text: the curse of mankind, because, i f they are

Speaker: NA
Text: used for mass destruction during a war.

Speaker: NA
Text: there is no doubt that they could destroy

Speaker: NA
Text: the very fabric of the earth itself. We of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition, therefore, ask what is being

Speaker: NA
Text: done in this connexion. Nearly two years

Speaker: NA
Text: ago, at the federal conference of the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian Labour party, this matter was dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: cussed and, among other things, this was

Speaker: NA
Text: said-

Speaker: NA
Text: The development of atomic weapons has reached

Speaker: NA
Text: such dimensions that the peoples of the world

Speaker: NA
Text: are now faced with the stark and terrifying spec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tacle of a possible atomic world war causing

Speaker: NA
Text: a danger to the very .fabric of the «arth, its

Speaker: NA
Text: atmosphere and all its inhabitants, which is so

Speaker: NA
Text: of real that distinguished scientists refer to the

Speaker: NA
Text: prospect with a sense of desperation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Those were the words used by that great

Speaker: NA
Text: scientist -Einstein and his seven colleagues

Speaker: NA
Text: who .signed the declaration published

Speaker: NA
Text: immediately after his death. The declara-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of the Australian Labour movement, to

Speaker: NA
Text: which I have referred, continues-

Speaker: NA
Text: This desperation is partly -due to the vacillation

Speaker: NA
Text: and delay in arranging high-level political talks

Speaker: NA
Text: aiming at the effective prevention of the -use of

Speaker: NA
Text: atomic and "'hydrogen bombs 'by any nation,

Speaker: NA
Text: whether for purposes of war or experimental

Speaker: NA
Text: purposes.

Speaker: NA
Text: That declaration was criticized, but it

Speaker: NA
Text: pointed fhe way to a solution, because, at

Speaker: NA
Text: the great meetings held after that time, the

Speaker: NA
Text: leaders of the three nations to which I have

Speaker: NA
Text: referred made to each other, and to the

Speaker: NA
Text: world, 'the offers to which I have alluded.

Speaker: NA
Text: Nobody will deny that the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Supply ( Mr Beale) is very energetic in

Speaker: NA
Text: cariying out his duties, but the real respon-

Speaker: NA
Text: sibility lies not with him, but with the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government. It should point out that our

Speaker: NA
Text: country is being used as the place for con-

Speaker: NA
Text: ducting these experiments. We all realize

Speaker: NA
Text: that, originally, Woomera was never

Speaker: NA
Text: intended for atomic or hydrogen experi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments; it was arranged between the Chifley

Speaker: NA
Text: Government and the Labour government

Speaker: NA
Text: of Great Britain that it should be used for

Speaker: NA
Text: experiments seeking to obtain an answer

Speaker: NA
Text: to the V - l and V-2 guided missiles which

Speaker: NA
Text: nearly turned the tide of war against us

Speaker: NA
Text: in 1944 and 1945. I t is now being used

Speaker: NA
Text: for these other purposes.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Beale -Maraling:' . had nothing to ilo

Speaker: NA
Text: with that. ,

Speaker: Dr EVATT
Text: 1 am not speaking aboul

Speaker: NA
Text: Maralinga; I am referring to the original

Speaker: NA
Text: purpose for which that great space at

Speaker: NA
Text: Woomera was to bs used. What is being

Speaker: NA
Text: done about it now? In to-day's issue of

Speaker: NA
Text: the " Sun Pictorial", Douglas Wilkie, who,

Speaker: NA
Text: like Russo of the " Argus ", is one of the

Speaker: NA
Text: best informed of any commentators in Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia on international affairs, said-

Speaker: NA
Text: We're near to that point al v/hich the peoples

Speaker: NA
Text: of the world will insist on putting an end to

Speaker: NA
Text: further nuclear test-explosions-A-bom b and

Speaker: NA
Text: H-bomb.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let the Government take the initiative. It

Speaker: NA
Text: will get 100 per cent, support from the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition and, I believe, from those coun-

Speaker: NA
Text: tries which are concerned with this ques-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. Certainly, it will get support from

Speaker: NA
Text: suffering humanity.

Speaker: The CHAIRMAN
Text: Mr Adermann) -

Speaker: NA
Text: Order! The honorable gentleman's time

Speaker: NA
Text: has expired.

Speaker: Mr BEALE
Text: Parramatta-Ministe r for

Speaker: NA
Text: Supply) [8.10] - I have only a few minutes

Speaker: NA
Text: tn which to address the committee. Before

Speaker: NA
Text: I deal specifically with what the Leader of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition (Dr Evatt) said, may I

Speaker: NA
Text: .nention one or two matters which were

Speaker: NA
Text: raised earlier in the debate? The honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Blaxland ( Mr E. James that

Speaker: NA
Text: Harrison) read a passage from the recent

Speaker: NA
Text: report of the Nuclear Research Foundation,

Speaker: NA
Text: uttering a criticism of the allocation

Speaker: NA
Text: the Lucas Heights reactor. Since the honorin

Speaker: NA
Text: able member has done that, perhaps I might

Speaker: NA
Text: be permitted to read a letter which I

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: man of the foundation, in which he said-

Speaker: NA
Text: The foregoing criticisms are not intended in any

Speaker: NA
Text: way to reflect on the Atomic Energy Commission

Speaker: NA
Text: itself or on you, sir, as the Minister responsible

Speaker: NA
Text: for the work of the Commission and for the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vision of adequate finance for its proper require-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments.

Speaker: NA
Text: All of us want as much money as possible to

Speaker: NA
Text: be spent on the Lucas Heights project, but

Speaker: NA
Text: a lot of other projects in Australia also

Speaker: NA
Text: require money. I f there is to be any sug-

Speaker: NA
Text: gestion that the Government has not done

Speaker: NA
Text: its duty in regard to this item on the

Speaker: NA
Text: Estimates, I point out that we have prac-

Speaker: NA
Text: tically doubled the vote for the Lucas

Speaker: NA
Text: Heights project this year. An extra

Speaker: NA
Text: £1,000,000 has been provided.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Chambers -Th e honorable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Blaxland did not mention Lucas

Speaker: NA
Text: Heights.

Speaker: Mr BEALE
Text: I f he did not mention

Speaker: NA
Text: Lucas Heights, heaven only knows what he

Speaker: NA
Text: was talking about! That is what he was

Speaker: NA
Text: supposed to be talking aboul. The pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: posed vote for this project for this financial

Speaker: NA
Text: year is £2,436,000, compared wilh a vole

Speaker: NA
Text: of £1,416,000 which was placed on the

Speaker: NA
Text: Estimates last year. That seems to nie a

Speaker: NA
Text: pretty handsome recognition of rhe fact

Speaker: NA
Text: that this Government realizes that the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: ject is an important project and that in a

Speaker: NA
Text: time of financial stringency, the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: is prepared to allocate a big increase in

Speaker: NA
Text: funds to bring that project to completion.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honorable member for Blaxland also

Speaker: NA
Text: took the trouble to make some slighting

Speaker: NA
Text: remark which was based on a report in the

Speaker: NA
Text: " Daily Telegraph". I f the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member gets any pleasure out of the fact

Speaker: NA
Text: that a newspaper reporter rings up a Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter's wife, is rude to her, and publishes a

Speaker: NA
Text: snarling report next morning that " a woman

Speaker: NA
Text: who answered the telephone said he was

Speaker: NA
Text: asleep", the honorable member is not as

Speaker: NA
Text: decent a fellow as I thought. I take it very

Speaker: NA
Text: hard that a man like himself should bother

Speaker: NA
Text: to quote a newspaper on a paltry matter

Speaker: NA
Text: of that sort.

Speaker: NA
Text: I should also like to answer something

Speaker: NA
Text: was said by the honorable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Bonython ( Mr Makin), who very rightly

Speaker: NA
Text: expressed some anxiety about the natives in

Speaker: NA
Text: for connexion with atomic tests. I have said,

Speaker: NA
Text: the House, in general terms, that the

Speaker: NA
Text: most elaborate precautions have been taken

Speaker: NA
Text: io safeguard the safety of the natives

Speaker: NA
Text: entirely. I shall not attempt to deal with

Speaker: NA
Text: the matter in detail now, but perhaps the

Speaker: NA
Text: committee will permit me to refer to a

Speaker: NA
Text: letter which 1 wrote on 20th September to

Speaker: NA
Text: the appropriate Minister i n the Labour

Speaker: NA
Text: Government in Western Australia, Mr .

Speaker: NA
Text: Brady, M . L . A . , who had made inquiries

Speaker: NA
Text: about this matter. I t is a long letter which

Speaker: NA
Text: indicates w i th some precision the care that

Speaker: NA
Text: we take, and w i t h the concurrence of

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable members I shall incorporate it in

Speaker: NA
Text: " Hansard " . The letter reads as follows:-

Speaker: NA
Text: I have now had an opportunity of reading the

Speaker: NA
Text: speech made by Mr W. Grayden, M.L.A., in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Legislative Assembly on ISth August, and appre-

Speaker: NA
Text: ciate your courtesy in forwarding this with your

Speaker: NA
Text: letter of 21st August.

Speaker: NA
Text: At the outset let me say that I share your

Speaker: NA
Text: anxiety that nothing should be done to jeopardize

Speaker: NA
Text: the welfare and precarious living of the native.

Speaker: NA
Text: This has always been in the forefront of our

Speaker: NA
Text: minds in planning operations both in respect of

Speaker: NA
Text: the rocket range at Woomera and of the atomic

Speaker: NA
Text: weapons proving ground at Maralinga.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have tried not only to protect the natives

Speaker: NA
Text: from any hazard associated with the operation

Speaker: NA
Text: of these ranges, but also to disturb their normal

Speaker: NA
Text: mode of living as little as possible, and to impose

Speaker: NA
Text: no unnecessary restriction on their movements.

Speaker: NA
Text: My Department has worked in close co-operation

Speaker: NA
Text: with the Department of Native Welfare both in

Speaker: NA
Text: South and Western Australia, and the helpful atti-

Speaker: NA
Text: tude of both States has been appreciated.

Speaker: NA
Text: You might like to have a brief outline of the

Speaker: NA
Text: measures which have been put into operation for

Speaker: NA
Text: looking after native welfare in the area nearer to

Speaker: NA
Text: Maralinga, and this I have set out below-

Speaker: NA
Text: 1. Two or three mobile ground patrols

Speaker: NA
Text: operate between Tarcoola and Ernabella

Speaker: NA
Text: to keep a check on the location and

Speaker: NA
Text: movement of all natives in this area.

Speaker: NA
Text: 2. There are also scientific teams operating

Speaker: NA
Text: east towards Mabel Creek and up to 120

Speaker: NA
Text: miles to the north-west of our base on

Speaker: NA
Text: the Emu claypan. These teams, while

Speaker: NA
Text: not specifically for native patrol, are

Speaker: NA
Text: briefed to report any indication that

Speaker: NA
Text: natives are in this area.

Speaker: NA
Text: 3. These patrols are in daily contact with

Speaker: NA
Text: each other, with Natives Affairs Oflicer

Speaker: NA
Text: Macaulay at the Meteorological Station

Speaker: NA
Text: in the Rawlinsons, and with the Mara-

Speaker: NA
Text: linga and Woomera Ranges.

Speaker: NA
Text: 4. While there is not the slightest danger to

Speaker: NA
Text: the health of natives in and around the

Speaker: NA
Text: station properties in central South Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia arising from the tests at Mara-

Speaker: NA
Text: linga, it is considered politic to keep

Speaker: NA
Text: regular checks on the radio-active

Speaker: NA
Text: ground " in these areas, and in addition

Speaker: NA
Text: to the large number of air sampling

Speaker: NA
Text: stations distributed throughout the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian continent, there are sampling

Speaker: NA
Text: devices located at each of the station

Speaker: NA
Text: properties referred to above.

Speaker: NA
Text: Not only do these supplement the data

Speaker: NA
Text: obtained from the main continental

Speaker: NA
Text: sampling system, but they provide specific

Speaker: NA
Text: confirmation that no significant radio-

Speaker: NA
Text: active material has fallen on the nearby

Speaker: NA
Text: inhabited areas.

Speaker: NA
Text: 5. Betore any major test is conducted at

Speaker: NA
Text: Maralinga, extensive low level aerial

Speaker: NA
Text: reconnaissance over a wide sector centred

Speaker: NA
Text: on Maralinga and extending out ajout

Speaker: NA
Text: 200 miles from the. firing area is made

Speaker: NA
Text: with meticulous care. This will detect

Speaker: NA
Text: the presence of any natives not pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: viously accounted for. In the event of

Speaker: NA
Text: any natives being discovered in locations

Speaker: NA
Text: which might give rise to public anxiety,

Speaker: NA
Text: the tests would be held up until the

Speaker: NA
Text: natives were clear of these areas.

Speaker: NA
Text: 6. The only area in which the radio-active

Speaker: NA
Text: contamination foUowing a test might

Speaker: NA
Text: reach a level prejudicial to health, is in

Speaker: NA
Text: the near vicinity of the firing sites, and

Speaker: NA
Text: this area will be constantly supervised

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Range authorities.

Speaker: NA
Text: Although radio-active material will fall

Speaker: NA
Text: outside this aiea, it will be of such low

Speaker: NA
Text: intensity as not to be a health hazard.

Speaker: NA
Text: Further, it will decay rapidly with time

Speaker: NA
Text: and could not possibly be a danger to

Speaker: NA
Text: any natives who might subsequently

Speaker: NA
Text: move into the area.

Speaker: NA
Text: 7. As part of the scientific plan to assess the

Speaker: NA
Text: effectiveness of the nuclear devices tested

Speaker: NA
Text: at Maraiinga, extensive aerial and ground

Speaker: NA
Text: survey of the radio-active " fallout" are

Speaker: NA
Text: made with highly sensitive measuring

Speaker: NA
Text: instruments to distances of more than 100

Speaker: NA
Text: miles from the firing sites. These measure-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments provide additional confirmation

Speaker: NA
Text: that the scientific predictions were

Speaker: NA
Text: realized and that no harmful radio-

Speaker: NA
Text: active material was deposited on areas

Speaker: NA
Text: used by human beings or live-stock.

Speaker: NA
Text: The initiation and direction of the above

Speaker: NA
Text: measures is the direct responsibility of the Atomic

Speaker: NA
Text: Weapons Tests Safety Committee, which con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sists of eminent Australian scientists and which

Speaker: NA
Text: is present in person at each of the major trials

Speaker: NA
Text: at Maralinga.

Speaker: NA
Text: I trust the foregoing information will not only

Speaker: NA
Text: inform you of the extreme care with which we

Speaker: NA
Text: are planning all these operations, but will enable

Speaker: NA
Text: you to reply to any uninformed criticism that

Speaker: NA
Text: these highly important and essential British Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth defence operations are prejudicing

Speaker: NA
Text: native life and welfare in Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Chambers -Wha t about the con-

Speaker: NA
Text: taminated cattle?

Speaker: Mr BEALE
Text: Th e story about the con-

Speaker: NA
Text: " backtaminated cattle is simply that there were

Speaker: NA
Text: no contaminated cattle. The day after this

Speaker: NA
Text: report appeared, the " Adelaide Advertiser "

Speaker: NA
Text: published a complete and flat denial by the

Speaker: NA
Text: gentleman who was supposed to have given

Speaker: NA
Text: the report to it.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honorable member for Darebin ( Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: R. W. Holt) made, if I may say so, an

Speaker: NA
Text: earnest and well-intentioned speech on

Speaker: NA
Text: what I acknowledge is a serious subject.

Speaker: NA
Text: I regret to say that, in trying to make his

Speaker: NA
Text: case, he misquoted the effect of the Medi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cal Research Council's report in Great

Speaker: NA
Text: Britain and the effect of the report of the

Speaker: NA
Text: United States Academy of Science. He

Speaker: NA
Text: certainly misquoted the intent and effect

Speaker: NA
Text: of the British Labour party's resolution

Speaker: NA
Text: Which was passed at Blackpool a few weeks

Speaker: NA
Text: ago. I have the resolution here, and it is

Speaker: NA
Text: quite clear that the British Labour party

Speaker: NA
Text: did not intend to pass a resolution advocat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing a unilateral discontinuance of atomic

Speaker: NA
Text: tests. Yet that is precisely what the honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able gentleman suggested.

Speaker: NA
Text: Obviously, the honorable member, along

Speaker: NA
Text: with everybody else, including the members

Speaker: NA
Text: of this Government, is anxious to see these

Speaker: NA
Text: tests brought under control and, in due

Speaker: NA
Text: course, discontinued. But to suggest that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Labour party of Great Britain, like the

Speaker: NA
Text: very foolish Labour party in this chamber,

Speaker: NA
Text: passed a resolution advocating a unilateral

Speaker: NA
Text: discontinuance of tests is to insult the intelli-

Speaker: NA
Text: gence of the British Labour party. A

Speaker: NA
Text: resolution was passed by the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Labour party caucus, by a narrow majority,

Speaker: NA
Text: advocating the unilateral abolition of atomic

Speaker: NA
Text: bomb tests. I suggest that if the proposal

Speaker: NA
Text: were put up to the caucus again, it would

Speaker: NA
Text: not go through; but it is on record. There-

Speaker: NA
Text: fore, it is interesting to find the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Darebin so misguided as to

Speaker: NA
Text: advocate in this committee that line of

Speaker: NA
Text: approach.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr R. W. Holt -Doe s the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: oppose the churches?

Speaker: Mr BEALE
Text: I do not oppose the

Speaker: NA
Text: churches. The churches, in common .with

Speaker: NA
Text: most thinking people, are anxious to see an

Speaker: NA
Text: end to this atomic armaments race. This

Speaker: NA
Text: Government, as I shall show, is doing its

Speaker: NA
Text: utmost, along with the governments of the

Speaker: NA
Text: United Kingdom, and the United States ot

Speaker: NA
Text: America, to get some sort of workable and

Speaker: NA
Text: enforceable agreement on the subject. But

Speaker: NA
Text: until we can get something which will pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: tect us, we will not expose this country and

Speaker: NA
Text: our allies to being overwhelmed, as by an

Speaker: NA
Text: avalanche, by the forces of Russia, a coun-

Speaker: NA
Text: try which is completely superior in other

Speaker: NA
Text: forms of armaments.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honorable member misquoted the

Speaker: NA
Text: statement of Mr Adlai Stevenson. Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Adlai Stevenson did not advocate the uni-

Speaker: NA
Text: lateral banning of the hydrogen bomb.

Speaker: NA
Text: The words that he used were-

Speaker: NA
Text: ... the United States should take the lead

Speaker: NA
Text: in working out a ban on hydrogen bomb tests.

Speaker: NA
Text: That does not mean that the United States

Speaker: NA
Text: should abandon its testing of the bomb

Speaker: NA
Text: Unless Russia gave some sort of promise or

Speaker: NA
Text: undertaking, or America had some sort

Speaker: NA
Text: of working arrangement with Russia, to do

Speaker: NA
Text: the same thing.

Speaker: NA
Text: I now turn to the real nub of this matter,

Speaker: NA
Text: and that is the statement by the Leader of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition. The honorable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Darebin and some of his misguided

Speaker: NA
Text: friends are prepared to say, " Let Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: discontinue these tests. Let Great Britain

Speaker: NA
Text: discontinue these tests. Let America dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: continue these tests. But let Russia go on

Speaker: NA
Text: and on and on "

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Chambers -H e did not say that.

Speaker: Mr BEALE
Text: Tha t is the effect of the

Speaker: NA
Text: resolution that the Labour party caucus

Speaker: NA
Text: adopted the other day.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Chambers -Th e Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition advocated bringing the leaders

Speaker: NA
Text: of nations together.

Speaker: Mr BEALE
Text: Tha t is what the Leader

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Opposition said in the chamber, but

Speaker: NA
Text: it is not what he said in caucus.

Speaker: The CHAIRMAN
Text: Order ! Members

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Opposition must keep quiet.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr R. W. Holt- I rise to order. I ask

Speaker: NA
Text: for an unqualified withdrawal of the state-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment that we are in favour of letting Russia

Speaker: NA
Text: go ahead with the development of the atom

Speaker: NA
Text: bomb.

Speaker: The CHAIRMAN
Text: Order ! The honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member is out of order. If he con-

Speaker: NA
Text: siders that he has been misrepresented, be

Speaker: NA
Text: may make a personal explanation.

Speaker: Mr BEALE
Text: Thes e boys do not like

Speaker: NA
Text: the truth. They run away from it every

Speaker: NA
Text: day of the week. To-night, the Leader of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition did not go as far as he went

Speaker: NA
Text: in caucus. He has submitted an amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, the purpose of which is to reduce the

Speaker: NA
Text: proposed vote for the Department of Supply

Speaker: NA
Text: by £1- a sort of motion of censure, I sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: pose-a s a direction to the Government to

Speaker: NA
Text: get the powers together to ensure the ban-

Speaker: NA
Text: ning of tests by agreement. That is a some-

Speaker: NA
Text: what different thing.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Chambers -I t is different from

Speaker: NA
Text: what the Minister said.

Speaker: Mr BEALE
Text: No . I said that the

Speaker: NA
Text: caucus had previously passed a resolution

Speaker: NA
Text: in favour of Australia abandoning tests.

Speaker: NA
Text: But to-night the right honorable gentleman

Speaker: NA
Text: is not prepared to go that far. I am not

Speaker: NA
Text: surprised that he is not prepared to go that

Speaker: NA
Text: far because on 22nd February last, in

Speaker: NA
Text: answer to an interjection by myself, he said,

Speaker: NA
Text: in this chamber, that no one seriously advo-

Speaker: NA
Text: cated the cessation of experimental explo-

Speaker: NA
Text: sions except by international regulation and

Speaker: NA
Text: by consenc. That is why he cannot now an aerial inspection.

Speaker: NA
Text: genuinely advocate unilateral abandonment.

Speaker: NA
Text: But he does want to have the proposed

Speaker: NA
Text: for the Department of Supply reduced as a

Speaker: NA
Text: direction to the Government to get the

Speaker: NA
Text: powers together. It all sounds very nice.

Speaker: NA
Text: I suggest that it might be a good idea

Speaker: NA
Text: if the committee had the opportunity

Speaker: NA
Text: run its mind over the history of this matter

Speaker: NA
Text: and realize what has been done by the

Speaker: NA
Text: great democracies to try to bring about

Speaker: NA
Text: some sort of agreement on this subject

Speaker: NA
Text: already. For Australia now to mount its

Speaker: NA
Text: white charger like a paladin, come into the

Speaker: NA
Text: arena, strike an attitude, and say, "We

Speaker: NA
Text: shall get the great powers together to

Speaker: NA
Text: achieve this thing which Great Britain

Speaker: NA
Text: America have been struggling for since

Speaker: NA
Text: 1954 ", is just childish nonsense, and everyThis

Speaker: NA
Text: body knows it. In 1954, at the United

Speaker: NA
Text: Nations General Assembly, a motion was

Speaker: NA
Text: put forward by India for what it called

Speaker: NA
Text: standstill of atomic explosion. It is signifiof

Speaker: NA
Text: cant that Russia did not open its mouth

Speaker: NA
Text: that session, did not advocate this course,

Speaker: NA
Text: and did not raise the matter in any form

Speaker: NA
Text: all.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Chambers -Ther e was a later meetit

Speaker: NA
Text: ing in 1954.

Speaker: Mr BEALE
Text: I am coming to that. In

Speaker: NA
Text: 1955 Russia did bring forth, before a subthere

Speaker: NA
Text: committee on disarmament, a somewhat

Speaker: NA
Text: elaborate proposal for a cessation of

Speaker: NA
Text: thermo-nuclear tests, which in that context

Speaker: NA
Text: mean both hydrogen and atomic explosions,

Speaker: NA
Text: coupled with a freeze of conventional arms

Speaker: NA
Text: -whic h was very nice because Russia had

Speaker: NA
Text: 50 per cent, more conventional arms than by the wayside.

Speaker: NA
Text: all the rest of the free world put together-

Speaker: NA
Text: the liquidation of all foreign bases, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: acceptance of a solemn obligation not

Speaker: NA
Text: use nuclear weapons. No enforcement, no

Speaker: NA
Text: sanctions, no control! It is little wonder

Speaker: NA
Text: that that proposal Went by default and was

Speaker: NA
Text: not even raised by anybody at the meeting.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is worth mentioning that at about that

Speaker: NA
Text: time President Eisenhower came forward

Speaker: NA
Text: with his open skies proposal, which was a

Speaker: NA
Text: fair and honest proposal for inspection of

Speaker: NA
Text: all forms of armament, and that was turned

Speaker: NA
Text: down by Russia. So do not let us say that

Speaker: NA
Text: the democracies have not been putting up a

Speaker: NA
Text: struggle to try to bring this thing under

Speaker: NA
Text: control.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Chambers -Tha t proposal was for

Speaker: Mr BEALE
Text: I t was for an open skies

Speaker: NA
Text: vote aerial inspection of armaments.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Chambers -The y did not agree to it.

Speaker: Mr BEALE
Text: O f course they did not.

Speaker: NA
Text: In December, 1955, Sir Anthony Eden said

Speaker: NA
Text: to that the United Kingdom could not agree

Speaker: NA
Text: to the stopping of nuclear tests unless there

Speaker: NA
Text: were some sort of international supervision

Speaker: NA
Text: and control. He went on to say, " But my

Speaker: NA
Text: Government is prepared at any time and at

Speaker: NA
Text: any place to have discussions on the control

Speaker: NA
Text: and abolition of atomic bomb tests ". There

Speaker: NA
Text: never was a reply by Russia to that open

Speaker: NA
Text: offer. Between March and May, 1956, the

Speaker: NA
Text: and disarmament sub-committees of the United

Speaker: NA
Text: Nations again had this matter under discus-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion, and again proposals were put forward.

Speaker: NA
Text: time they were Anglo-French proposals

Speaker: NA
Text: fbr comprehensive disarmament, but they

Speaker: NA
Text: also included the abolition of the atomic

Speaker: NA
Text: a tests. The Soviet replied with a proposal

Speaker: NA
Text: its own, somewhat similar to its previous

Speaker: NA
Text: at proposal, but again without any sort of

Speaker: NA
Text: supervision or control. For the democra-

Speaker: NA
Text: at cies to agree to any proposal Which does

Speaker: NA
Text: not, somewhere or Other, have a hope in

Speaker: NA
Text: that the agreement could be supervised

Speaker: NA
Text: and controlled would be, of course, just

Speaker: NA
Text: folly. Russia entered that particular dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: cussion with no better proposal than that

Speaker: NA
Text: should be a solemn obligation on the

Speaker: NA
Text: part of all powers that they would make a

Speaker: NA
Text: solemn promise. It would be, if you like,

Speaker: NA
Text: one of those forms of words, but nothing

Speaker: NA
Text: more than that, with no sanctions to back

Speaker: NA
Text: it, no inspection of any sort, and it is little

Speaker: NA
Text: wonder that that proposal lapsed and went

Speaker: NA
Text: Quite recently, Sir Anthony Eden's Go-

Speaker: NA
Text: to vernment, like this Government, and like

Speaker: NA
Text: every other government, including, I believe,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Russian Government, has become con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cerned with the implications of the thermo-

Speaker: NA
Text: nuclear explosion, that is to say, a hydro-

Speaker: NA
Text: gen bomb explosion, as distinct from an

Speaker: NA
Text: atomic explosion. This is a distinction

Speaker: NA
Text: which members on the Opposition benches

Speaker: NA
Text: Jo not seem to understand. I have heard

Speaker: NA
Text: three speeches this afternoon by Labour

Speaker: NA
Text: members. Two of the speakers obviously

Speaker: NA
Text: did not know the difference between an

Speaker: NA
Text: atomic bomb explosion and a hydrogen

Speaker: NA
Text: bomb explosion. Sir Anthony Eden said

Speaker: NA
Text: that although his Government would prefer

Speaker: NA
Text: io deal with the question of controlling

Speaker: NA
Text: atomic explosions in the context of a dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: armament convention, nevertheless the ques-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion had become so technical, so bogged

Speaker: NA
Text: down in offer and counter-offer, in poli-

Speaker: NA
Text: tical and international diplomatic manoeuvre,

Speaker: NA
Text: that he now, made an open offer that hi*-

Speaker: NA
Text: Government stood immediately ready, at

Speaker: NA
Text: any time and at any place, to discuss a

Speaker: NA
Text: limitation of tests, separately or in any distion

Speaker: NA
Text: armament context whatsoever.

Speaker: Dr EVATT
Text: Tha t is a big step forward.

Speaker: Mr BEALE
Text: I agree with the Leader

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Opposition that that is a big step

Speaker: NA
Text: forward, and it is one with which we heartily

Speaker: NA
Text: agree, because the hydrogen bomb offers

Speaker: NA
Text: sinister possibilities for the world unless

Speaker: NA
Text: mankind does something about it. I

Speaker: NA
Text: remind this committee that the Go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment will not permit such a bomb

Speaker: NA
Text: io be tested in Australia, but that is

Speaker: NA
Text: another matter altogether. The only reply

Speaker: NA
Text: hv Russia to that proposal was the letting

Speaker: NA
Text: off of another series of hydrogen bombs

Speaker: NA
Text: in Russia. And there the matter stands.

Speaker: NA
Text: All I say to the Parliament is that this Go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment will not yield to any one in its

Speaker: NA
Text: belief that the time must come when the

Speaker: NA
Text: nations will be compelled to agree among

Speaker: NA
Text: themselves to control and, if possible, to

Speaker: NA
Text: ban the holding of these tests. We have

Speaker: NA
Text: played our part in every discussion abroad

Speaker: NA
Text: on this matter. Our views are well known

Speaker: NA
Text: and we shall continue to assert them. If

Speaker: NA
Text: it is any consolation to the Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: '>r>r)osition, quite apart from the motion h?

Speaker: NA
Text: proposed to-night, this Government will

Speaker: NA
Text: take as foremost a part as it can take in

Speaker: NA
Text: future discussions, but that does not mean

Speaker: NA
Text: getting up on a post and bawling at the

Speaker: NA
Text: too of our voices and making fools of

Speaker: NA
Text: ouselves.

Speaker: NA
Text: r

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Curtin -N o wonder they call you

Speaker: NA
Text: " Paddles ".

Text: Order ! The honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Kingsford-Smith is entirely

Speaker: NA
Text: out of order in many ways, and he knows

Speaker: NA
Text: it. He will be out of the chamber if he

Text: I have spoken a little

Speaker: NA
Text: warmly on this subject, because I feel

Speaker: NA
Text: warmly about it. It is a matter of great

Speaker: NA
Text: significance to all of us. I think that most

Text: honorable members of the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Labour party, excluding the gentleman who

Speaker: NA
Text: just interjected, think just as seriously about

Speaker: NA
Text: this matter as we do, but the one thing that

Speaker: NA
Text: seems to divide the Government on the one

Speaker: NA
Text: hand and some members of the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Labour party on the other hand- I know

Speaker: NA
Text: it is not so with all of them-i s whether in

Speaker: NA
Text: the meantime, struggling and doing our

Speaker: NA
Text: utmost with our friends to get some sort of

Speaker: NA
Text: workable, enforceable agreement, which

Speaker: NA
Text: will diminish and finally bring to a termina-

Speaker: NA
Text: the holding of these tests, we should go

Speaker: NA
Text: on with these very small atomic tests in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, helping Great Britain and helping

Speaker: NA
Text: ourselves. Does the Australian Labour

Speaker: NA
Text: party, or that little group of it to which I

Speaker: NA
Text: have referred, say that if a Labour govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment had been in power a year or two ago

Speaker: NA
Text: it would have said " No " if Great Britain

Speaker: NA
Text: had said, " We offer you all of the guaran-

Speaker: NA
Text: tees of complete safety in this matter. Yours

Speaker: NA
Text: is the only country in our world that has

Speaker: NA
Text: the vacant space in which these bombs

Speaker: NA
Text: can be tested. Will you help us by allowing

Speaker: NA
Text: these small tests to take place? " I do not

Speaker: NA
Text: believe that Labour supporters would have

Speaker: NA
Text: been so craven as to adopt that attitude. I

Speaker: NA
Text: do not believe that they have so little regard

Speaker: NA
Text: for Great Britain, for the Empire, or for

Speaker: NA
Text: themselves, ever to have done that. I do not

Speaker: NA
Text: believe they would do it.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Davis -Thei r leader would have

Speaker: NA
Text: done so.

Speaker: Mr BEALE
Text: Mayb e he would. I say

Speaker: NA
Text: in conclusion that we will do our utmost

Speaker: NA
Text: and play our part to the limit of Australia's

Speaker: NA
Text: capacity to bring about some sort, of proper

Speaker: NA
Text: working agreement in the matter of thermo-

Speaker: NA
Text: nuclear and nuclear tests, but that

Speaker: NA
Text: in the meantime we intend to go

Speaker: NA
Text: ahead and. subject to complete safety

Speaker: NA
Text: for the Australian people, which we

Speaker: NA
Text: have achieved and will continue to achieve,

Speaker: NA
Text: assist Great Britain, ourselves, and our allies

Speaker: NA
Text: in the conducting of these tests.

Text: I n relation to the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: posed vole for Miscellaneous Services alone,

Speaker: NA
Text: there are many matters that I should like

Speaker: NA
Text: to discuss and which I think the committee

Speaker: NA
Text: PAIRS.

Speaker: NA
Text: should consider. Most of the proposed

Speaker: NA
Text: voles in this group refer to grants and assist-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance to be given by the Government in

Speaker: NA
Text: respect of activities both inside and outside

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, including the very important

Speaker: NA
Text: Chaney, F. C.

Speaker: NA
Text: measure of assistance which the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment has undertaken to give to our Asian

Speaker: NA
Text: friends under the Colombo plan. I wish to

Speaker: NA
Text: devote a few minutes to discussion of

Speaker: NA
Text: assistance within Australia, because I am one

Speaker: NA
Text: of those peculiar people who believe that

Speaker: NA
Text: charity begins at home and that, whilst it is

Speaker: NA
Text: proper to have a charitable and kindly

Speaker: NA
Text: attitude to people outside Australia who

Speaker: NA
Text: require assistance, we should make sure that

Speaker: NA
Text: the fullest possible measure of assistance is

Speaker: NA
Text: given in deserving cases at home.

Speaker: NA
Text: In Division 214 of the Estimates for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister's Department, under the

Speaker: NA
Text: heading of Miscellaneous Services, a long

Speaker: NA
Text: list of organizations and subjects appears for

Speaker: NA
Text: which money is to be made available. Some

Speaker: NA
Text: of these appear to receive their grants

Speaker: NA
Text: almost automatically each year, and it is not

Speaker: NA
Text: often that a new organization or subject

Speaker: NA
Text: appears in the list. However, this year, I

Speaker: NA
Text: notice that a new organization is included,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Humanities Research Coun-

Speaker: NA
Text: cil. Although, as in the case of the other

Speaker: NA
Text: .**ems in this division, the title of this

Speaker: NA
Text: organization is given, no information is pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vided to enable the committee to under-

Speaker: NA
Text: stand what this organization is and what it

Speaker: NA
Text: does. Having regard to its tide, I have

Speaker: NA
Text: no doubt that it devotes its attention to

Speaker: NA
Text: humanitarian activities, and is a deserving

Speaker: NA
Text: body. However, I should appreciate some

Speaker: NA
Text: information as to its objectives.

Speaker: NA
Text: Another item is, " Cultural matters,

Speaker: NA
Text: exhibitions", and the grant for this is

Speaker: NA
Text: £1,500. A similar vote was included in last

Speaker: NA
Text: year's Estimates, but it was not spent.

Speaker: NA
Text: Evidently, the exhibitions did not take place,

Speaker: NA
Text: but it is assumed that they will be held this

Speaker: NA
Text: year. Although the causes listed in this

Speaker: NA
Text: division may merit financial help, I could

Speaker: NA
Text: mention many others which are equally, if

Speaker: NA
Text: not more, deserving of government assis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tance.

Speaker: NA
Text: I direct particular attention to the work

Speaker: NA
Text: that is being carried on by voluntary

Speaker: NA
Text: organizations in every State of the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth to provide medical and educational

Speaker: NA
Text: facilities for spastic children. These children

Speaker: NA
Text: are afflicted with cerebral palsy, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: efforts of these organizations are devoted to

Speaker: NA
Text: the improvement of their physical condition,

Speaker: NA
Text: and to the provision of means of education

Speaker: NA
Text: so that they may be able to enjoy their lives

Speaker: NA
Text: as much as possible and to engage in useful

Speaker: NA
Text: occupations as far as they are able. The

Speaker: NA
Text: demands that have been made for the ser-

Speaker: NA
Text: vices of these organizations, even in the

Speaker: NA
Text: short time that they have been in existence,

Speaker: NA
Text: have been overwhelming, and they will not

Speaker: NA
Text: be able to carry on without some assistance

Speaker: NA
Text: from the Commonwealth Government.

Speaker: NA
Text: The organizations have formed a federal

Speaker: NA
Text: association, and at a recent meeting in

Speaker: NA
Text: Melbourne, after a very careful study of

Speaker: NA
Text: the position, it was found that in order to

Speaker: NA
Text: provide adequately the services necessary to

Speaker: NA
Text: assist spastic children both now and in later

Speaker: NA
Text: life a sum of £400,000 would be required

Speaker: NA
Text: to supplement the funds raised from the

Speaker: NA
Text: public and voted by State governments.

Speaker: NA
Text: Last year an appeal for assistance was made

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Treasurer ( Sir Arthur Fadden), but

Speaker: NA
Text: although he gave a sympathetic hearing he

Speaker: NA
Text: gave no substantial help. The organizations

Speaker: NA
Text: had hoped to receive some assistance in this

Speaker: NA
Text: year's budget, but such has not been the

Speaker: NA
Text: case. The time is fast approaching when

Speaker: NA
Text: the Commonwealth will not be able to keep

Speaker: NA
Text: out of this matter, if only for economic

Speaker: NA
Text: reasons, which is a most inhumane way of

Speaker: NA
Text: considering it. But if the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: does not give financial assistance in the

Speaker: NA
Text: work of helping spastic children, it will

Speaker: NA
Text: be obliged, under its social services legisla-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion, to pay them the invalid pension when

Speaker: NA
Text: they are old enough to qualify for it.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Ian Allan -Wha t are the State go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernments doing?

Speaker: Mr LESLIE
Text: Th e State governments

Speaker: NA
Text: are giving financial assistance in accordance

Speaker: NA
Text: with their constitutional responsibilities.

Speaker: NA
Text: They provide educational facilities, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: State of Queensland subsidizes the spastic

Speaker: NA
Text: centre in that State on a £l-for-£I basis.

Speaker: NA
Text: Nevertheless, the financial assistance from

Speaker: NA
Text: the State governments is inadequate, and

Speaker: NA
Text: the organizations have to depend upon

Speaker: NA
Text: money raised from the public to enable

Speaker: NA
Text: them to carry on. In Western Australia,

Speaker: NA
Text: where it costs £60,000 a year to run the

Speaker: NA
Text: spastic centre, the organization has received

Speaker: NA
Text: generous support from the State govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. The difference between the govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment grant and the actual cost is con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tributed, voluntarily, by the public. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian council of the spastic organiza-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions is fearful that the sympathetic and

Speaker: NA
Text: generous response by the public to the fre-

Speaker: NA
Text: quent appeals will not be maintained, so

Speaker: NA
Text: that it will not be possible to provide the

Speaker: NA
Text: services that the spastic children need.

Speaker: NA
Text: Already, it is impossible to provide any-

Speaker: NA
Text: thing like the services asked for.

Speaker: NA
Text: Although this need has been ignored

Speaker: NA
Text: through the years by governments, the ser-

Speaker: NA
Text: vice now being given by the spastic orga-

Speaker: NA
Text: nizations is being sought by iricreasins num-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers of parents whose children are afflicted.

Speaker: NA
Text: 1. say agam that charity begins at home, and

Speaker: NA
Text: this is a case in which the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: should assist. I i children can receive treat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment in their early years it is possible to do

Speaker: NA
Text: much more for them than in later years.

Speaker: NA
Text: From a humanitarian point of view the need

Speaker: NA
Text: of the spastic children constitutes a demand

Speaker: NA
Text: for government assistance that far tran-

Speaker: NA
Text: scends the claims of many of the organiza-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions listed in this division to which grants

Speaker: NA
Text: have been made. I hope that, as a result

Speaker: NA
Text: of my appeal, some consideration will be

Speaker: NA
Text: given ro the help of spastic organizations,

Speaker: NA
Text: and that when they approach the Treasurer

Speaker: NA
Text: later this year he will give them substance

Speaker: NA
Text: as well as sympathy, and grant them a fair

Speaker: NA
Text: proportion of the £16,000,000 that is set

Speaker: NA
Text: aside for him to spend at his discretion.

Speaker: NA
Text: 1 now turn to a matter under the control

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Postmaster-General-th e operations

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Australian Broadcasting Commission.

Speaker: NA
Text: On previous occasions, I have severely

Speaker: NA
Text: criticized a recent departure in the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: grammes of the Australian Broadcasting

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission by providing only one service

Speaker: NA
Text: in the children's hour, that is, the relay from

Speaker: NA
Text: the eastern States to Western Australia of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Argonauts session. When I discussed

Speaker: NA
Text: this matter with Mr Moses, the general

Speaker: NA
Text: manager of the Australian Broadcasting

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission, he gave me quite a long story,

Speaker: NA
Text: but to me it was unconvincing and left me

Speaker: NA
Text: cold. I am still of the opinion that Western

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia is not being provided with an ade-

Speaker: NA
Text: quate programme for children, and it seems

Speaker: NA
Text: that requests to the Australian Broadcasting

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission from Western Australia will

Speaker: NA
Text: not receive favorable consideration.

Speaker: NA
Text: As proof of that statement I point to the

Speaker: NA
Text: fact that the Royal Show is now taking

Speaker: NA
Text: place at Perth, and the Australian Broad-

Speaker: NA
Text: casting Commission is conspicuous by its

Speaker: NA
Text: absence. At the Royal Show held in each

Speaker: NA
Text: of the capital cities of the eastern States

Speaker: NA
Text: the team which presents the Argonauts ses-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion appears in person at the specially pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vided Australian Broadcasting Commission

Speaker: NA
Text: studio in one of the pavilions. Many

Speaker: NA
Text: Western Australian children who listen to

Speaker: NA
Text: the broadcast of the Argonauts session were

Speaker: NA
Text: keenly looking forward to the appearance

Speaker: NA
Text: of these artists at the Perth Royal Show

Speaker: NA
Text: this year, but they were bitterly dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: appointed. Why should Western Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: be deprived of a personal visit from these

Speaker: NA
Text: artists? Obviously, it is a case of a distant

Speaker: NA
Text: State being forgotten and neglected.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Dab/ -Wher e is Western Australia?

Speaker: Mr LESLIE
Text: I suggest that the honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Grayndler ( Mr Daly)

Speaker: NA
Text: should go back to the kindergarten and

Speaker: NA
Text: learn where Western Australia is. The

Speaker: NA
Text: treatment that has been meted out by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Broadcasting Commission to

Speaker: NA
Text: Western Australia is wholly unsatisfactory.

Speaker: NA
Text: I suggest that the commission should again

Speaker: NA
Text: look at the matter. I f the idea behind the

Speaker: NA
Text: relaying of a single session all over the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth is that it is to prepare the-

Speaker: NA
Text: way for television, I remind the commis-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion that we will not have television in

Speaker: NA
Text: Western Australia for another two or per-

Speaker: NA
Text: haps three years.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Luchetti -Bu t you are paying taxes.

Speaker: Mr LESLIE
Text: O f course, we will be

Speaker: NA
Text: taxed. If the children at the eastern end

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Commonwealth are to have the bene-

Speaker: NA
Text: fits of television and there is to be another

Speaker: NA
Text: programme for Western Australia, South

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia and Queensland, which States will

Speaker: NA
Text: not have television for a considerable time,

Speaker: NA
Text: each State might as well be given its own

Speaker: NA
Text: broadcast children's session at the present

Speaker: NA
Text: time. When the Argonauts session was-

Speaker: NA
Text: run by each State, it was not possible for

Speaker: NA
Text: the stations to cope with the mail that came

Speaker: NA
Text: from the children. The interest of the

Speaker: NA
Text: children in their local affairs, and in the

Speaker: NA
Text: flora and fauna of their country, was such

Speaker: NA
Text: that the stations could not deal with the

Speaker: NA
Text: mail. How in the world those who are

Speaker: NA
Text: responsible are able to deal with the mail

Speaker: NA
Text: since the session was placed on a nation-

Speaker: NA
Text: wide basis I do not know. The discon-

Speaker: NA
Text: tinuance of the session in Western Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia has been very disappointing to the

Speaker: NA
Text: children. I know that the Postmaster-

Speaker: NA
Text: General will tell me that he has no control

Speaker: NA
Text: over the programmes of the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Broadcasting Commission, but he should

Speaker: NA
Text: investigate this matter. I suggest that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Argonauts session, even if it costs three

Speaker: NA
Text: times as much, is worth a jolly sight more

Speaker: NA
Text: than is the broadcast of the proceedings of

Speaker: NA
Text: this Parliament. I remind honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers-an d I include myself-tha t as 1

Speaker: NA
Text: stand here and speak the broadcast of these

Speaker: NA
Text: proceedings is costing the taxpayers ot"

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia £2 5s. a minute. I believe that, as

Speaker: NA
Text: far as I am concerned, they get value for

Speaker: NA
Text: their money, but I am not so sure that that

Speaker: NA
Text: applies to a number of other honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: members.

Speaker: The CHAIRMAN
Text: Order ! The honor-

Speaker: NA

Text: Banks) [8.53] - I desire

Speaker: NA
Text: comment upon the Estimates for the Postbe

Text: master-General's Department, and to refer

Text: 568 offices in Australia, is £720,000.

Text: Representatives of the telegraphists

Speaker: NA
Text: the supervisory officers' organization have

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: their views before me. The unions conregard

Speaker: NA
Text: cerned are opposed to the installation

Text: the service. That opinion is shared by all

Text: the operatives in the telegraph branches,

Text: supervising technicians. The department is

Speaker: NA
Text: basing its argument for the installation

Speaker: NA
Text: Tress on the experience of the Western

Speaker: NA
Text: Union Telegraph Co., in the United States

Speaker: NA
Text: of America. As honorable members know,

Speaker: NA
Text: the postal service in Amenca is conducted

Speaker: NA
Text: by private enterprise and is not run by

Speaker: NA
Text: the government. The reported cost of the

Speaker: NA
Text: installation of this system in the United

Speaker: NA
Text: States was 70,000,000 dollars, or approximultiplex

Speaker: NA
Text: mately £A30,000,000. Moreover, there

Speaker: NA
Text: have been additional heavy annual approof

Speaker: NA
Text: priations for the maintenance of the

Speaker: NA
Text: original equipment and for extension of the

Speaker: NA
Text: service. The department's estimate of

Speaker: NA
Text: approximately £720,000 is relatively low

Speaker: NA
Text: comparison with the cost to the Western

Speaker: NA
Text: Union Telegraph Company of America. I

Speaker: NA
Text: feel that the cost of installing co-axial

Speaker: NA
Text: cables has not been taken into account

Speaker: NA
Text: the department's estimate, and also that

Speaker: NA
Text: system would not work satisfactorily in

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: would be provided by the use of co-axial

Speaker: NA
Text: cable. i

Text: The Postmaster-General, in reply to

Speaker: NA
Text: another question of mine, has stated that

Speaker: NA
Text: the new system would require 400 fewer

Speaker: NA
Text: to telegraphists, which means that it would

Speaker: NA
Text: necessary to effect a retrenchment of

Speaker: NA
Text: telegraphists. On the other hand, because

Text: of the vast amount of mechanization that is

Speaker: NA
Text: with it, introduction of the

Speaker: NA
Text: is system would lead to a greatly increased

Speaker: NA
Text: engineering staff. Because of the fear of

Speaker: NA
Text: retrenchment of telegraphists, the

Speaker: NA
Text: are asking for the exercise of

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: The argument that Tress is the answer to

Speaker: NA
Text: telegraph service economy difficulties is not

Speaker: NA
Text: strengthened by the fact that, apart from

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: of system, and the Australian postal unions

Speaker: NA
Text: that system as being more suitable to

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australian conditions. They believe it

Text: would be more efficient and more economic.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Postal Department owes it to the tax-

Speaker: NA
Text: payers to be careful in its investigations

Speaker: NA
Text: before it spends a lot of money on a new-

Speaker: NA
Text: fangled system which is of doubtful quality.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the past, experimenting engineers have

Speaker: NA
Text: of introduced other systems that have proved

Speaker: NA
Text: to be a failure. For example, they installed

Speaker: NA
Text: the Hunter Valley multiplex system. Twenty-

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: and Cessnock districts, which previously

Text: cuit, were changed over to the mechanized

Text: system. Many technical break-

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: that the system was inefficient and was a

Speaker: NA
Text: costly failure. Consequently, it reverted to

Speaker: NA
Text: the old morse system. The introduction of

Speaker: NA
Text: in Tress could lead to the same result. Multi-

Speaker: NA
Text: plex, Tress and such highly mechanized

Speaker: NA
Text: systems are suitable only for densely popu-

Speaker: NA
Text: lated areas. They are suitable for big cities

Speaker: NA
Text: in or towns that are comparatively close to-

Speaker: NA
Text: the gether. In those circumstances, the laying

Speaker: NA
Text: of co-axial cable would not be so expensive.

Speaker: NA
Text: as Let us take Queensland as an example.

Speaker: NA
Text: During monsoonal and bad weather periods

Speaker: NA
Text: the carrier wave frequency circuits react in

Speaker: NA
Text: a manner that is known as bumping, which

Speaker: NA
Text: is like the static faults that we hear in our

Speaker: NA
Text: wireless sets. This so-called technical

Speaker: NA
Text: bumping fault could last for days, and in

Speaker: NA
Text: that case the present system would have to be

Speaker: NA
Text: resorted to. The same criticism applies to

Speaker: NA
Text: communications in the southern States in

Speaker: NA
Text: summer, especially during stormy weather

Speaker: NA
Text: when there is a contraction of lines due to

Speaker: NA
Text: varying temperatures.

Text: aims of the Postal Department and which railroad

Text: unions dispute the claim that efficiency will

Speaker: NA
Text: be improved. The essence of a telegram is

Speaker: NA
Text: speed and accuracy. A telegram is usually

Speaker: NA
Text: an urgent message sent from one point

Speaker: NA
Text: another, that is from the dispatching office

Speaker: NA
Text: to the receiving office. Telegrams are

Speaker: NA
Text: present transmitted by the teletype or

Speaker: NA
Text: the hand Morse system, and it takes no more

Speaker: NA
Text: than about a minute to send the average

Speaker: NA
Text: message. The installation of a new and

Speaker: NA
Text: costly system to increase that speed will

Speaker: NA
Text: be of much value because the transmission

Speaker: NA
Text: of a telegram at present is almost instannot

Speaker: NA
Text: taneous. What is necessary, however, is

Speaker: NA
Text: the message should be speeded up from the

Speaker: NA
Text: office of destination to the addressee. an-J

Speaker: NA
Text: that is a matter of speeding up delivery.

Speaker: NA
Text: What is the value of transmitting a cable

Speaker: NA
Text: from London to Sydney, or to Canberra,

Speaker: NA
Text: a fast speed if that cable is going to

Speaker: NA
Text: about in an office for one or two hours

Text: waiting to be delivered by a messenger?

Speaker: NA
Text: And that sort of thing does happen. My

Speaker: NA
Text: advice to the Postmaster-General is that

Speaker: NA
Text: should forget about Tress and concentrate

Speaker: NA
Text: cern to the telegraphists union is whether

Text: employment of females on the grounds that

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: fact, they receive only 75 per cent, of

Speaker: NA
Text: male wage. The union has no objection

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: svstem may threaten male employment. of
