Speaker: Mr ERWIN
Text: Ballarat) [9.7] - I desire to

Speaker: NA
Text: direct my remarks to-night to the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth railways. I congratulate the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Shipping and Transport (Sena-

Speaker: NA
Text: tor Paltridge) and the Commonwealth Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: missioner for Railways, Mr Hannaberry, on

Speaker: NA
Text: the very fine job of work they have done in

Speaker: NA
Text: bringing the Commonwealth railways to

Speaker: NA
Text: their present high standard of efficiency,

Speaker: NA
Text: which is as high a standard as any to be

Speaker: NA
Text: found in the world. This year the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth railways made a profit of about

Speaker: NA
Text: £1,500,000, and that was achieved because

Speaker: NA
Text: -of the introduction of diesel-electric loco-

Speaker: NA
Text: motives. The first of these locomotives was

Speaker: NA
Text: brought into service about four years ago,

Speaker: NA
Text: and during the last four years we have had

Speaker: NA
Text: to re-adjust our thinking about railway sys-

Speaker: NA
Text: tems as a fast, efficient and economical

Speaker: NA
Text: means of transport.

Speaker: NA
Text: Diesel-electric trains are able to operate

Speaker: NA
Text: at less than one-third the cost of the

Speaker: NA
Text: steam trains, and, at the same time, give

Speaker: NA
Text: "faster service. Let us now look at the

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australia and trace out where Commonstandard

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth services operate. They operate from

Speaker: NA
Text: Port Pirie north to Port Augusta, thence

Speaker: NA
Text: Kalgoorlie, a distance of approximately

Speaker: NA
Text: 1,100 miles. That service is known as

Speaker: NA
Text: " trans " service. Our central railway line

Speaker: NA
Text: commences at Port Augusta and runs north

Speaker: NA
Text: to Alice Springs. Then there is a large gap

Speaker: NA
Text: across the centre of Australia to Birdum;

Speaker: NA
Text: and from Birdum to Darwin there is

Speaker: NA
Text: 3 ft. 6 in. gauge railway. The present

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment has commenced the conversion

Speaker: NA
Text: the line from 3 ft. 6 in. to 4 ft. 8± in

Speaker: NA
Text: which is the world standard gauge-fro

Speaker: NA
Text: Port Augusta for about 200 miles north;

Speaker: NA
Text: and as our economic conditions permit,

Speaker: NA
Text: we shall eventually have a world standard

Speaker: NA
Text: gauge line of 4 ft. 8 i in. through to Darwin.

Speaker: NA
Text: In view of the comparatively small volume

Speaker: NA
Text: of goods carried and the unbalance of

Speaker: NA
Text: goods traffic-ther e being a greater volume

Speaker: NA
Text: -of goods taken west than is carried east-

Speaker: NA
Text: lack the profit made by the Commonwealth rail-

Speaker: NA
Text: ways is remarkable. If the timber industry

Speaker: NA
Text: of Western Australia could be developed,

Speaker: NA
Text: that profit could be increased considerably,

Speaker: NA
Text: because a good deal of timber would be

Speaker: NA
Text: carried from the west to the east. So much

Speaker: NA
Text: for the Commonwealth railways.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let us glance at the States' railway

Speaker: NA
Text: systems to see whether they could be greatly

Speaker: NA
Text: improved, to the advantage of the economy

Speaker: NA
Text: of the country. From Brisbane, in the

Speaker: NA
Text: north, there is a standard gauge line to

Speaker: NA
Text: Albury, via Sydney. Another standard

Speaker: NA
Text: gauge line runs from Sydney to Broken

Speaker: NA
Text: HiU, where there is a break of gauge. From

Speaker: NA
Text: Broken Hill to Port Pirie, a distance of

Speaker: NA
Text: approximately 240 miles, there is a 3-ft.

Speaker: NA
Text: 6-in. gauge line. But for that gap of 240

Speaker: NA
Text: miles, we could operate a through railway

Speaker: NA
Text: service from Sydney to Kalgoorlie. If the

Speaker: NA
Text: line between Broken Hill and Port Pirie

Speaker: NA
Text: were converted to the standard gauge, goods

Speaker: NA
Text: could be carried by rail from Brisbane to

Speaker: NA
Text: Kalgoorlie, without being unloaded at any

Speaker: NA
Text: intermediate point. If the line from Kal-

Speaker: NA
Text: goorlie to Perth were converted to the

Speaker: NA
Text: standard gauge, we should have a true

Speaker: NA
Text: trans-Australia railway.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let us consider for a few minutes a rail-

Speaker: NA
Text: way service which, I am sure, would return

Speaker: NA
Text: a handsome profit after gauge standardiza-

Speaker: NA
Text: old tion. I refer to the service between Mel-

Speaker: NA
Text: a bourne and Sydney. The line from Albury

Speaker: NA
Text: map to Melbourne could be converted to the

Speaker: NA
Text: gauge and modern central traffic

Speaker: NA
Text: control systems could be introduced at a

Speaker: NA
Text: to total cost of £9,000,000. I understand that

Speaker: NA
Text: the conversion could be done without inter-

Speaker: NA
Text: the fering in any way with the operations of

Speaker: NA
Text: the railway system, of Victoria. The scheme

Speaker: NA
Text: proposed in the Clapp report would have

Speaker: NA
Text: cost something like £76,000,000 at the time

Speaker: NA
Text: the report was published, and to-day it

Speaker: NA
Text: a would cost about £200,000,000. That was

Speaker: NA
Text: Goa scheme for the standardization of all the

Speaker: NA
Text: of railway systems of the Commonwealth, but

Speaker: NA
Text: - I feel that at this stage it would not be

Speaker: NA
Text: m necessary to go so far. We must crawl

Speaker: NA
Text: before we walk. This is a young country,

Speaker: NA
Text: and we must make do with what we can

Speaker: NA
Text: afford. I believe that the cost of convert-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the line from Albury to Melbourne to

Speaker: NA
Text: standard gauge would have to be borne

Speaker: NA
Text: the by the Commonwealth, owing to the finan-

Speaker: NA
Text: cial difficulties of Victoria. The job could

Speaker: NA
Text: not be completed in less than three years.

Speaker: NA
Text: so a nominal sum of £3,000,000 a year

Speaker: NA
Text: could be allocated for the purpose. I f there

Speaker: NA
Text: -are any men unemployed in Australia, their

Speaker: NA
Text: -services could be used usefully on the con-

Speaker: NA
Text: struction of such a railway line.

Speaker: NA
Text: The question that we must ask ourselves

Speaker: NA
Text: iis: Can our railways be brought to such

Speaker: NA
Text: a standard of efficiency as to alleviate

Speaker: NA
Text: severity of some of our road problems? 1

Speaker: NA
Text: say most definitely that that can be done.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Hume Highway between Melbourne

Speaker: NA
Text: and Sydney, to take one example, is

Speaker: NA
Text: quagmire in places. Millions of pounds matters

Speaker: NA
Text: have been spent on the construction and

Speaker: NA
Text: maintenance of that road, but the money

Speaker: NA
Text: spent on it in the last nnanciai year at

Speaker: NA
Text: rate has been spent unwisely. At present,

Speaker: NA
Text: 300 vehicles each carrying an average load

Speaker: NA
Text: of 12 tons travel over the road each

Speaker: NA
Text: So 24,000 tons of goods are carried over

Speaker: NA
Text: it each week. Those figures show that our

Speaker: NA
Text: bituminized roads, in their present form,

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot possibly stand up to the great

Speaker: NA
Text: volume of traffic that uses them. Many of

Speaker: NA
Text: -us believe that if there were a standardyears

Speaker: NA
Text: gauge railway between Sydney and MelCommonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: -bourne, a great portion of the volume of

Speaker: NA
Text: goods now being carried by road between

Speaker: NA
Text: those two cities would be diverted to the

Speaker: NA
Text: railway, but the loss of time and the expense

Speaker: NA
Text: caused by the break of gauge at Albury

Speaker: NA
Text: such that the railways are unable to compete

Speaker: NA
Text: effectively with the road-hauliers. Although

Speaker: NA
Text: almost 80 per cent, of the goods carried

Speaker: NA
Text: between Melbourne and Adelaide is carried

Speaker: NA
Text: by the railways and only 20 per cent, goes

Speaker: NA
Text: try road, road-hauliers are carrying almost

Speaker: NA
Text: 60 per cent, of the goods traffic between

Speaker: NA
Text: Melbourne and Sydney. The success of the

Speaker: NA
Text: railway between Adelaide and Melbourne

Speaker: NA
Text: is an indication of what would happen if from 1st October.

Speaker: NA
Text: we built a standard-gauge line from Mel-

Speaker: NA
Text: bourne to Albury. The cost of carrying

Speaker: NA
Text: goods between Melbourne and Sydney by

Speaker: NA
Text: rail would be less than l i d . a ton-mile.

Speaker: NA
Text: Compare that with the charge of 4d. a tonare

Speaker: NA
Text: mile made at present by road-hauliers.

Speaker: NA
Text: I believe that our population now is suffioutback

Speaker: NA
Text: ciently large to warrant the establishment

Speaker: NA
Text: of three more States. Two of our mair.

Speaker: NA
Text: problems at present are roads and decenthe

Speaker: NA
Text: tralization. If a deep-sea port were estabby

Speaker: NA
Text: lished at Portland to serve a new State

Speaker: NA
Text: sisting of a part of the west of Victoria

Speaker: NA
Text: a part of South Australia, if another

Speaker: NA
Text: sea port were established at Eden to serve

Speaker: NA
Text: another new State taking in the surrounding

Speaker: NA
Text: area, and if another deep-sea port were

Speaker: NA
Text: estabhshed at lluka to serve another new

Speaker: NA
Text: State consisting of the New England district,

Speaker: NA
Text: many of our transport difficulties would be

Speaker: NA
Text: alleviated. With an efficient railway system,

Speaker: NA
Text: less money would be spent on main high-

Speaker: NA
Text: ways and more money would be available

Speaker: NA
Text: the to town, borough and shire councils.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr H. V. JOHNSON (Kalgoorlie) [9.19].

Speaker: NA
Text: -I n the limited time at my disposal, I

Speaker: NA
Text: a shall confine my remarks tb one or two

Speaker: NA
Text: of great importance to my electorate;.

Speaker: NA
Text: First, I wish to congratulate the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Ballarat ( Mr Erwin), because

Speaker: NA
Text: any it is refreshing to hear members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth Parliament give credit

Speaker: NA
Text: where it is due by eulogizing the work of

Speaker: NA
Text: day. the Commonwealth railways, which have

Speaker: NA
Text: done a magnificent job for this country, par-

Speaker: NA
Text: ticularly under the present commissioner,

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Hannaberry, whose services to the

Speaker: NA
Text: nation have won him the admiration of

Speaker: NA
Text: people of all political opinions. In the few

Speaker: NA
Text: in which he has been in charge of the

Speaker: NA
Text: railways he has done such

Speaker: NA
Text: a magnificent job that the deficiencies of

Speaker: NA
Text: the past have vanished, and it is now a

Speaker: NA
Text: thorough pleasure to travel by those rail-

Speaker: NA
Text: ways. I am very happy, therefore, that the

Speaker: NA
Text: is honorable member for Ballarat saw fit to

Speaker: NA
Text: praise the great services of Mr Hannaberry.

Speaker: NA
Text: If I had time I could deal with the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth railways much more fully, but

Speaker: NA
Text: because there are other matters of great

Speaker: NA
Text: import that I wish to deal with I am unable

Speaker: NA
Text: to give the time that I would like to give

Speaker: NA
Text: to a discussion of those railway services.

Speaker: NA
Text: I refer to the increased postal, telephone

Speaker: NA
Text: and telegraph charges which have operated

Speaker: NA
Text: These increases impose a great additional

Speaker: NA
Text: burden on the people who form the pioneer-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing section of our great community. They

Speaker: NA
Text: the people who live far from the cities,

Speaker: NA
Text: and who do not enjoy the advantage of

Speaker: NA
Text: the amenities available to city people. These

Speaker: NA
Text: dwellers are greatly victimized by

Speaker: NA
Text: the new impositions. People who live in

Speaker: NA
Text: the far-out parts of Australia have to do

Speaker: NA
Text: major portion of their business dealings

Speaker: NA
Text: either telephone or telegram. Conse-

Speaker: NA
Text: conquently, increases of telephone and tele-

Speaker: NA
Text: and graph charges have a more direct effect on

Speaker: NA
Text: deepthem than they have on other members of

Speaker: NA
Text: the public. I refer particularly to people

Speaker: NA
Text: who Hve in the north-west of Western Aus-.

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia and in the Murchison and Murchison

Speaker: NA
Text: East gold-fields districts. I appeal to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Postmaster-General ( Mr Davidson) on their

Speaker: NA
Text: behalf but, while doing so, I realize quite

Speaker: NA
Text: well that, although the Minister may be

Speaker: NA
Text: sympathetic in the matter, he is just one

Speaker: NA
Text: member of a government which makes

Speaker: NA
Text: decisions such as that to increase postal

Speaker: NA
Text: and other charges and that, as a result,

Speaker: NA
Text: irrespective of what kind of a case I may be

Speaker: NA
Text: able to put to him to-night, he is not in a

Speaker: NA
Text: position to vary the charges as they affect

Speaker: NA
Text: people who live in isolated areas. I feel,

Speaker: NA
Text: therefore, that the whole thing is hardly

Speaker: NA
Text: fair, because when a worthwhile case that

Speaker: NA
Text: merits thorough attention by the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment is put forward, it is the Government's

Speaker: NA
Text: job to give that case the serious attention

Speaker: NA
Text: that it deserves.

Speaker: NA
Text: As 1 have already said, the greater part

Speaker: NA
Text: of the business transacted by people in out-

Speaker: NA
Text: back areas is transacted by means of tele-

Speaker: NA
Text: phone or telegram. That is a circumstance

Speaker: NA
Text: that is peculiar to the conditions under

Speaker: NA
Text: which those people live and work. The

Speaker: NA
Text: shipping service for people living on the

Speaker: NA
Text: isolated sections of the Western Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: coastline is irregular, and when people in

Speaker: NA
Text: those areas want to make arrangements for

Speaker: NA
Text: the transport of goods such arrangements

Speaker: NA
Text: are made by telephone or telegram.

Speaker: NA
Text: The business in these areas is not con-

Speaker: NA
Text: ducted in the regular fashion adopted in

Speaker: NA
Text: areas where there is assured and regular

Speaker: NA
Text: transport, but is done irregularly because

Speaker: NA
Text: of the lack of regular transport services.

Speaker: NA
Text: Because so much business is done on the

Speaker: NA
Text: telephone people in those areas sometimes

Speaker: NA
Text: have to wait on the line while decisions are

Speaker: NA
Text: being made. This is an exceedingly costly

Speaker: NA
Text: business normally, but now that the charges

Speaker: NA
Text: for trunk-line telephone calls have been in-

Speaker: NA
Text: creased it will be even more so. I stress

Speaker: NA
Text: that it is only by the use of telephones and

Speaker: NA
Text: telegram that people in those isolated areas

Speaker: NA
Text: can rsadily make contact with others. So

Speaker: NA
Text: I regret very much that the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: has found it necessary to place further im-

Speaker: NA
Text: posts on these outback people, who already

Speaker: NA
Text: face many difiiculties quite unknown to

Speaker: NA
Text: people who live in the cities and larger

Speaker: NA
Text: towns of Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: Not only are the people outback victheir

Speaker: NA
Text: timized in connexion with increased postal

Speaker: NA
Text: and other charges, but they are also vicflowed

Speaker: NA
Text: timized in respect of broadcasting recep-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion and the rate of listener's licence fee.

Speaker: NA
Text: In some of the outback areas a listener gets

Speaker: NA
Text: very little return for the money he spends

Speaker: NA
Text: on a broadcast listener's licence, because

Speaker: NA
Text: good reception is possible for only two or

Speaker: NA
Text: three hours a day. Yet those people who

Speaker: NA
Text: do not get the advantage of a 24-hour

Speaker: NA
Text: broadcasting service such as is enjoyed

Speaker: NA
Text: by metropolitan listeners are asked to pay

Speaker: NA
Text: exactly the same listener's licence fee as is

Speaker: NA
Text: paid by people who can use their radios at

Speaker: NA
Text: any time of the day or night. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: another injustice suffered by those people.

Speaker: NA
Text: Some time ago, 1 asked the Postmaster-

Speaker: NA
Text: General whether he would reduce the

Speaker: NA
Text: listener's licence fee payable by such people

Speaker: NA
Text: in isolated areas, on the ground of their

Speaker: NA
Text: not receiving the same standard of service

Speaker: NA
Text: as is received by people who live within

Speaker: NA
Text: effective range of numerous broadcasting

Speaker: NA
Text: stations.

Speaker: NA
Text: Now I turn to a matter that is of greai

Speaker: NA
Text: importance-th e question of the erection

Speaker: NA
Text: of a new post office at Geraldton, in Western

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. The proposed votes we are now

Speaker: NA
Text: considering make no provision for that

Speaker: NA
Text: work. I might mention that the building

Speaker: NA
Text: which serves Geraldton as a post office at

Speaker: NA
Text: present was erected in the early 1890's,

Speaker: NA
Text: when the population of Geraldton was

Speaker: NA
Text: about 1,000. To-day, when Geraldton's

Speaker: NA
Text: population is above 10,000, and with the

Speaker: NA
Text: population of surrounding districts increas-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing rapidly, this same post office which was

Speaker: NA
Text: built in the. early lS90's is still being called

Speaker: NA
Text: on to serve that much larger community.

Speaker: NA
Text: In 1947, after a thorough inspection by

Speaker: NA
Text: officials of the Postmaster-General's De-

Speaker: NA
Text: partment, the then Postmaster-General told

Speaker: NA
Text: the people of Geraldton that they would

Speaker: NA
Text: get a new post office. The plans were

Speaker: NA
Text: drawn up and submitted to the local autho-

Speaker: NA
Text: rities in Geraldton. A draft of the

Speaker: NA
Text: proposed building was also submitted, ln

Speaker: NA
Text: 1949, preparations were being made for the

Speaker: NA
Text: construction of the new post office but, un-

Speaker: NA
Text: fortunately, the Labour Government of

Speaker: NA
Text: that day was defeated in the general election

Speaker: NA
Text: in December, 1949. This Government then

Speaker: NA
Text: took office, and the incoming Postmaster-

Speaker: NA
Text: General, the honorable member for Rich-

Speaker: NA
Text: mond ( Mr Anthony), voiced his sympathy

Speaker: NA
Text: with the people of Geraldton in respect of

Speaker: NA
Text: poor post office facilities. But that is

Speaker: NA
Text: as far as we got. Correspondence has

Speaker: NA
Text: backwards and forwards through the

Speaker: NA
Text: years, and numerous representations have

Speaker: NA
Text: -been made to the Postmaster-General who

Speaker: NA
Text: preceded the present occupant of that hon-

Speaker: NA
Text: orable office. But in no way have we been

Speaker: NA
Text: able to get this Government to provide

Speaker: NA
Text: the money necessary for the erection of the

Speaker: NA
Text: new building. The result is that a building

Speaker: NA
Text: that is about 60 years old, erected to serve

Speaker: NA
Text: a community of 1,000 persons, is still

Speaker: NA
Text: attempting to serve a community that has

Speaker: NA
Text: since grown tenfold. The building is con-

Speaker: NA
Text: gested. It has not sufficient accommoda-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion for the postal officials who work in it.

Speaker: NA
Text: In fact, some of the officials of that post

Speaker: NA
Text: office have had to be accommodated in

Speaker: NA
Text: State buildings because of the lack of room

Speaker: NA
Text: in the post office. For instance, one of the

Speaker: NA
Text: most important postal officers of the dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: trict, the postal inspector, has had to occupy

Speaker: NA
Text: accommodation in a State building. The

Speaker: NA
Text: State is now pressing for that accommoda-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion to be returned to it. So we have this

Speaker: NA
Text: completely inadequate post office in one

Speaker: NA
Text: of the' most important towns in Western

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia- a very important town which

Speaker: NA
Text: is growing in population every day, and

Speaker: NA
Text: whose activities in agriculture and secon-

Speaker: NA
Text: dary industry are continually expanding.

Speaker: NA
Text: Yet over the years this Government has

Speaker: NA
Text: failed to give the people of Geraldton and

Speaker: NA
Text: the surrounding districts the adequate ser-

Speaker: NA
Text: vice that they so rightly deserve. I have

Speaker: NA
Text: discussed this matter with the present Post-

Speaker: NA
Text: m.ister-Gcncr?.l, and he loo has expressed

Speaker: NA
Text: his sympathy for the people of Geraldton

Speaker: NA
Text: in respect of this matter. He has said that

Speaker: NA
Text: he would like to see Geraldton have a new

Speaker: NA
Text: post office, but has also said that the only

Speaker: NA
Text: thing preventing the provision of that new

Speaker: NA
Text: post office is sufficient money to do the job.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Estimates provide for the expenditure

Speaker: NA
Text: of more than £310,000 on new buildings

Speaker: NA
Text: and works in Western Australia that were

Speaker: NA
Text: not mentioned in the Estimates three or

Speaker: NA
Text: four years ago. The new Geraldton post

Speaker: NA
Text: office was supposed to have priority over

Speaker: NA
Text: other works, but it has been discarded and

Speaker: NA
Text: £310,000 is to be spent mainly in the Perth

Speaker: NA
Text: metropolitan area and the south-west of the

Speaker: NA
Text: State.

Speaker: NA
Text: Only a few weeks ago I was deputed by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Postmaster-General to open a new post

Speaker: NA
Text: office at Morawa. When I undertook to

Speaker: NA
Text: perform the ceremony of officially opening

Speaker: NA
Text: that very valuable post office, I did not

Speaker: NA
Text: know that it would coincide with a visit to

Speaker: NA
Text: Western Australia by the Postmaster-

Speaker: NA
Text: General and the Director-General of Posts

Speaker: NA
Text: and Telegraphs, Sir Giles Chippindall. Had

Speaker: NA
Text: I known that, I should have thought it

Speaker: NA
Text: would be the Postmaster-General's job to

Speaker: NA
Text: open the new Morawa post office. It would

Speaker: NA
Text: have done him good to get out into the

Speaker: NA
Text: back country and see the conditions in

Speaker: NA
Text: which people in the country work. I think

Speaker: NA
Text: that, had we got the Minister to Morawa.

Speaker: NA
Text: which is fairly close to Geraldton, we

Speaker: NA
Text: should have had every chance of getting

Speaker: NA
Text: him to visit that town. I am sure he would

Speaker: NA
Text: have met with a very good reception had

Speaker: NA
Text: he attended a civic function at Morawa,

Speaker: NA
Text: and that the local people would have had

Speaker: NA
Text: something pertinent to say to him. I was

Speaker: NA
Text: very disappointed to find, when 1 was al

Speaker: NA
Text: Morawa, that the Postmaster-General and

Speaker: NA
Text: the Director-General of Posts and Tele-

Speaker: NA
Text: graphs were en route to the southern part

Speaker: NA
Text: of the State around Perth, the famed beauty

Speaker: NA
Text: of which attracts many tourists from the

Speaker: NA
Text: eastern Slates, most of whom go to Perth.

Speaker: NA
Text: I do not wish to be parochial, but, having

Speaker: NA
Text: examined the Estimates, I think it is signifi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cant that all of this £310,000 will be spent

Speaker: NA
Text: on buildings and works in electorates that

Speaker: NA
Text: that are represented by Government sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: porters. T do not like that.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Estiniates also provide approximately

Speaker: NA
Text: £1,500,000 more than last year for broad-

Speaker: NA
Text: casting and television services. It is safe

Speaker: NA
Text: to say that most of this amount will be spent

Speaker: NA
Text: on television, which will be of no benefit to

Speaker: NA
Text: people who live outside the metropolitan

Speaker: NA
Text: areas. It will not benefit country people,

Speaker: NA
Text: but they will pay just as heavily for it in

Speaker: NA
Text: taxation as will people who live within a

Speaker: NA
Text: short distance of television broadcasting

Speaker: NA
Text: stations and are able to derive great advan-

Speaker: NA
Text: tage from it. I am disappointed at this, and

Speaker: NA
Text: I appeal to the Postmaster-General to

Speaker: NA
Text: acknowledge the justice of the case that I

Speaker: NA
Text: have put before him this evening. I appeal

Speaker: NA
Text: to him to give consideration to people who

Speaker: NA
Text: are deserving of it and who will pay heavily

Speaker: NA
Text: to meet the increased charges to be levied

Speaker: NA
Text: on them. This Government has talked of

Speaker: NA
Text: decentralization.

Speaker: The CHAIRMAN
Text: Order ! The honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member's time has expired.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: wish to discuss two subjects which are

Speaker: NA
Text: covered by the group of estimates now

Speaker: NA
Text: under consideration. The first relates to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Postmaster-General's Department. I

Speaker: NA
Text: want to take a somewhat unusual course-

Speaker: NA
Text: at least, it appears to be unusual this

Speaker: NA
Text: ing-an d congratulate the Postmasterall

Speaker: NA
Text: General ( Mr Davidson) on the work

Speaker: NA
Text: done since he took over his portfolio. He

Speaker: NA
Text: has experienced a rather difficult period,

Speaker: NA
Text: but 1 am sure that the time immediately

Speaker: NA
Text: ahead will be a time of great advancement

Speaker: NA
Text: for the postal services. Perhaps that will

Speaker: NA
Text: be some encouragement to the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Kalgoorlie ( Mr H. V. Johnson).

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to congratulate the Minister partralia

Speaker: NA
Text: ticularly upon the recognition he has

Speaker: NA
Text: already given to Australia's amateur radio

Speaker: NA
Text: broadcasters, or bams as they are called.

Speaker: NA
Text: He has extended them considerable symcomradeship

Speaker: NA
Text: pathy and has recognized their problems

Speaker: NA
Text: and difficulties. His sympathetic considerawork

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of their problems is a very fine

Speaker: NA
Text: to them. The Minister has allowed them

Speaker: NA
Text: to continue with television experiments,

Speaker: NA
Text: to extend their work with mobile equipof

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, and has tried to get the co-operation

Speaker: NA
Text: of the public and the State governments

Speaker: NA
Text: a campaign to have suppressors fitted

Speaker: NA
Text: appliances and machinery to prevent interin

Speaker: NA
Text: ference to radio and television broadcasts.

Speaker: NA
Text: This will be of considerable help to ham

Speaker: NA
Text: radio operators in Australia, and they thank

Speaker: NA
Text: the Postmaster-General for his sympathy

Speaker: NA
Text: and understanding.

Speaker: NA
Text: 1 feel that we pay too little tribute

Speaker: NA
Text: to Australia's amateur radio operators.

Speaker: NA
Text: Although their work may be classed as

Speaker: NA
Text: hobby, and a very interesting one, which

Speaker: NA
Text: keeps them deeply engrossed, we should,

Speaker: NA
Text: nevertheless, acknowledge the vital part they

Speaker: NA
Text: play. We too often pass lightly over the

Speaker: NA
Text: valuable work done by them, particularly

Speaker: NA
Text: in time of emergency. Disastrous though

Speaker: NA
Text: the recent floods have been, they would

Speaker: NA
Text: have been much worse had it not

Speaker: NA
Text: the work of the amateur radio operators,

Speaker: NA
Text: who struggled against great obstacles to

Speaker: NA
Text: maintain vital communications between

Speaker: NA
Text: flooded areas and other parts of the

Speaker: NA
Text: try. Fine work was done not only by appliances

Speaker: NA
Text: the operators in the devastated areas,

Speaker: NA
Text: also by those in Sydney, Brisbane, Adelaide

Speaker: NA
Text: and elsewhere who picked up messages

Speaker: NA
Text: and transmitted them by telephone to the

Speaker: NA
Text: authorities. It is on record that many

Speaker: NA
Text: the operator* of amateur radio stations gave

Speaker: NA
Text: up their normal work, at considerable

Speaker: NA
Text: sonal expense, and devoted themselves

Speaker: NA
Text: solely to the task they felt they had to

Speaker: NA
Text: for their fellow men in time of disaster.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have the comforting assurance that

Speaker: NA
Text: eventhey .ace ready to serve the community at

Speaker: NA
Text: times should cyclones, fires, floods, or

Speaker: NA
Text: he has disaster in any other form occur.

Speaker: NA
Text: I do not think the Government can

Speaker: NA
Text: properly measure the valuable service that

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's radio hams have given fhe coun-

Speaker: NA
Text: try by promoting international goodwill.

Speaker: NA
Text: Their operations are not confined to Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia. Their transmissions go far abroad

Speaker: NA
Text: and carry messages of goodwill from Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: wherever, they are received. Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia's amateur broadcasters are doing a

Speaker: NA
Text: splendid job for their country in spreading,

Speaker: NA
Text: the spirit of understanding, friendship and

Speaker: NA
Text: among the fraternity of ham

Speaker: NA
Text: operators throughout the world, and this

Speaker: NA
Text: must pay Australia great dividends in

Speaker: NA
Text: tribute the long run. We are indebted to our

Speaker: NA
Text: amateur broadcasters for their work in

Speaker: NA
Text: and war-time also. It is greatly to the credit

Speaker: NA
Text: the hams who were operating just prior

Speaker: NA
Text: to World War II . that, on the outbreak of

Speaker: NA
Text: in war, those in the military age-group who-

Speaker: NA
Text: to were fit joined up in a body and served

Speaker: NA
Text: the signals branches of the three ser-

Speaker: NA
Text: vices. Amateur operators are ready re-

Speaker: NA
Text: serve again if a war emergency arises. If

Speaker: NA
Text: - we could measure completely the value of

Speaker: NA
Text: the work done by Australia's ham radio-

Speaker: NA
Text: broadcasters, I think we could say that the

Speaker: NA
Text: experience gained by them in signals work,

Speaker: NA
Text: radar, electronics, and the manufacture of

Speaker: NA
Text: a radio equipment, is so important that

Speaker: NA
Text: without it Australia's defence programme

Speaker: NA
Text: would be six months behind the present

Speaker: NA
Text: stage. I think the valuable work these men

Speaker: NA
Text: are doing in pursuing their hobby deserves-

Speaker: NA
Text: due recognition from the Government.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are many ways in which it could give

Speaker: NA
Text: them perhaps greater recognition than tbey

Speaker: NA
Text: been for have received in the past.

Speaker: NA
Text: Earlier, I mentioned that the Postmaster-

Speaker: NA
Text: General had given a sympathetic hearing to>

Speaker: NA
Text: the representations for the more extensive

Speaker: NA
Text: counfitting of suppressors to household

Speaker: NA
Text: and motor cars to prevent radio-

Speaker: NA
Text: but interference. I mentioned this matter in

Speaker: NA
Text: relation to television on a previous occasion.

Speaker: NA
Text: Interference can cause great distortion of

Speaker: NA
Text: the image on a television screen. Also,,

Speaker: NA
Text: of if appliances such as electric razors and

Speaker: NA
Text: washing machines are not fitted with sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: perpressors they might, because of the low

Speaker: NA
Text: power on which hams are forced to operate

Speaker: NA
Text: do in Australia, cause interference with their

Speaker: NA
Text: signals. Even an electric razor being usedi

Speaker: NA
Text: in one house can put the ham, who is

Speaker: NA
Text: operating in an adjoining house, off the

Speaker: NA
Text: air until the fellow using the razor has

Speaker: NA
Text: finished shaving. I ask the Postmaster-

Speaker: NA
Text: General ( Mr Davidson) to endeavour to

Speaker: NA
Text: persuade the State governments to enforce

Speaker: NA
Text: the fitting of suppressors to all household-

Speaker: NA
Text: electric appliances and motor cars, and

Speaker: NA
Text: also to inform the general public of the

Speaker: NA
Text: interference that can be caused, not only

Speaker: NA
Text: to television, but also to ham operators,

Speaker: NA
Text: by the use of faulty electrical equipment.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Wheeler -Wha t cost is involved

Speaker: NA
Text: in the fitting of suppressors?

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: suppressor can be fitted to any electrical

Speaker: NA
Text: appliance for about 2s., so that no great

Speaker: NA
Text: outlay of cash would be involved. There

Speaker: NA
Text: is one other matter that causes me some

Speaker: NA
Text: concern in regard to ham operators; that

Speaker: NA
Text: is, the restriction placed on the power

Speaker: NA
Text: under which they may operate in Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: In New Zealand, hams are allowed to

Speaker: NA
Text: operate up to a maximum wattage of 250,

Speaker: NA
Text: whilst in America, the limit is 1,000 watts.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bm here in Australia, we keep them down

Speaker: NA
Text: to 100 watts. As Australia is a large coun-

Speaker: NA
Text: try, I think that consideration should be

Speaker: NA
Text: .given to increasing the maximum wattage

Speaker: NA
Text: at which hams can operate at least to the

Speaker: NA
Text: limit of 250 watts that is observed in New

Speaker: NA
Text: Zealand. By the use of additional power,

Speaker: NA
Text: the hams could get their signals through

Speaker: NA
Text: more clearly than under the present limit

Speaker: NA
Text: of 100 watts.

Speaker: NA
Text: TheFe is one other way in which we

Speaker: NA
Text: could help them, and it would not cost

Speaker: NA
Text: anything, at all. We could allow them com-

Speaker: NA
Text: plete freedom in the importation of equip-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment that has been developed as a result

Speaker: NA
Text: of experiments overseas,, particularly in the

Speaker: NA
Text: United States of America, which seems to

Speaker: NA
Text: lead, the world in the radio field. It would

Speaker: NA
Text: be very little for us to do for a band of

Speaker: NA
Text: devoted people who have served Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: well, and who are ready to serve again, if

Speaker: NA
Text: need be, should we experience either exter-

Speaker: NA
Text: nal or internal trouble, to give them ready

Speaker: NA
Text: access to import licences to enable them to

Speaker: NA
Text: bring into this country, duty free, any

Speaker: NA
Text: material that they need for experimental

Speaker: NA
Text: purposes, and to exempt from sales tax any

Speaker: NA
Text: such material that is manufactured in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: As I mentioned earlier, the radio opera-

Speaker: NA
Text: tors circulate throughout the world. They

Speaker: NA
Text: plan to meet, probably in Geneva* in 1959.

Speaker: NA
Text: That may sound a long way off, but it is

Speaker: NA
Text: sot so far ahead in terms of planning, and

Speaker: NA
Text: when they meet they will discuss their

Speaker: NA
Text: problems and establish standards to operate

Speaker: NA
Text: until the next conference is held, probably

Speaker: NA
Text: four or five years later. I think that it is

Speaker: NA
Text: essential for Australia to be well repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sented at the proposed conference. How-

Speaker: NA
Text: ever, at the moment, it appears that it will

Speaker: NA
Text: be left to the Wireless Institute of Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia to provide the necessary money to

Speaker: NA
Text: send its representatives to the conference.

Speaker: NA
Text: As we subsidize rifle clubs, because of their

Speaker: NA
Text: defence, value to the community,. I think

Speaker: NA
Text: that it would not be unreasonable for us

Speaker: NA
Text: to say to the institute,. " If you pick the

Speaker: NA
Text: men you want to go to the conference, we

Speaker: NA
Text: will pay their fares, or subsidize by 50 pei

Speaker: NA
Text: cent, the cost involved ", so that Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: can be adequately represented. I am sure

Speaker: NA
Text: that suoh a gesture by the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: would pay valuable dividends in the long

Speaker: NA
Text: run. Before hastening to the next subject

Speaker: NA
Text: to which I want to address myself, 1 should

Speaker: NA
Text: like to emphasize that we cannot pay too

Speaker: NA
Text: high a tribute to these men who are serving

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia so well to-day, and who have

Speaker: NA
Text: done a grand job for us in times of emer-

Speaker: NA
Text: gency and peril. By helping them in tbe

Speaker: NA
Text: way I have suggested we would, at least to a

Speaker: NA
Text: small degree,, compensate them for their

Speaker: NA
Text: good work.

Speaker: NA
Text: The other matter that I want to bring

Speaker: NA
Text: before the committee concerns the bounty

Speaker: NA
Text: that is payable under the Sulphuric Acid

Speaker: NA
Text: Bounty Act. With all the goodwill in the

Speaker: NA
Text: world, the Government placed that mea-

Speaker: NA
Text: sure on the statute-book as an incentive to

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian acid manufacturers to use indi-

Speaker: NA
Text: genous material, such as iron pyrites, for the

Speaker: NA
Text: manufacture of sulphuric acid. I notice

Speaker: NA
Text: that £512,471 was expended on such, boun-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties during the last financial year, and this

Speaker: NA
Text: year it is estimated that £450,000 will be so

Speaker: NA
Text: expended. It is a matter of regret to me

Speaker: NA
Text: that, despite this incentive, the great sul-

Speaker: NA
Text: phuric acid manufacturers of Australia are

Speaker: NA
Text: not fully using pyrites, and the producers of

Speaker: NA
Text: pyrites, including Mount Morgan Mines

Speaker: NA
Text: Limited and the Lake George Mining Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pany at Captains Flat have not benefited

Speaker: NA
Text: because the Government has been long-

Speaker: NA
Text: winded in adopting a practical solution to

Speaker: NA
Text: the problem. Officers of the Department

Speaker: NA
Text: of Defence Production have visited various

Speaker: NA
Text: parts of Australia to see whether an im-

Speaker: NA
Text: provement can be effected. I do not believe

Speaker: NA
Text: that Australia can afford to spend millions

Speaker: NA
Text: of pounds on the importation of sulphur for

Speaker: NA
Text: the manufacture of sulphuric acid when

Speaker: NA
Text: there are indigenous materials at hand that

Speaker: NA
Text: could be utilized by the sulphuric acid

Speaker: NA
Text: manufacturers without incurring undue cost.

Speaker: NA
Text: 1 urge the Government to turn its mind

Speaker: NA
Text: expeditiously to this subject. I think that

Speaker: NA
Text: a limitation should be placed on the im-

Speaker: NA
Text: portation of sulphur, and the money thus

Speaker: NA
Text: saved should be used to import other com-

Speaker: NA
Text: modities that we need. It would mean a

Speaker: NA
Text: great deal to the mining companies them-

Speaker: NA
Text: selves if the Government could say to them

Speaker: NA
Text: quickly-an d I am told, he gives twice who

Speaker: NA
Text: gives quickly- " In order to save dollars,

Speaker: NA
Text: indigenous materials should be used for the

Speaker: NA
Text: manufacture of sulphuric acid ". I point

Speaker: NA
Text: out that it is necessary for mining com-

Speaker: NA
Text: panies to plan a long way ahead. 'The life

Speaker: NA
Text: of the great mine that is operated by Mount

Speaker: NA
Text: Morgan Limited might be reduced by 50

Speaker: NA
Text: years if the abundant supply of pyrites that

Speaker: NA
Text: is available is not used. On the other hand,

Speaker: NA
Text: the reverse would be the case if the pyrites

Speaker: NA
Text: were used; the mine would have another

Speaker: NA
Text: 50 years of profitable and effective life, to

Speaker: NA
Text: the benefit of the people of the district. I

Speaker: NA
Text: ask the Minister at the table ( Mr Davidson;

Speaker: NA
Text: to express my strong conviction in this

Speaker: NA
Text: matter to the Government. I hope that

Speaker: NA
Text: something will be done speedily to encour-

Speaker: NA
Text: age the pyrites mining industry, because it

Speaker: NA
Text: is important to the welfare of the nation.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: to address myself to the subject of the repatsettled

Speaker: NA
Text: riation of ex-servicemen, which is a respon-

Speaker: NA
Text: sibility of thc Commonwealth Government.

Speaker: NA
Text: Although the Commonwealth can share cer-

Speaker: NA
Text: tain functions with the States, ultimately the

Speaker: NA
Text: obligation to repatriate ex-servicemen rests

Speaker: NA
Text: on this Government. In 1953, I asked the

Speaker: NA
Text: then Minister for the Interior, the honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Chisholm ( Mr Kent

Speaker: NA
Text: Hughes) to inform me of the number of

Speaker: NA
Text: ex-servicemen who had applied for land

Speaker: NA
Text: under the war service land settlement

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme. He stated that 36,000 of those

Speaker: NA
Text: who had applied for land were regarded by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government as qualified by age or

Speaker: NA
Text: training, or both, to take up land. More

Speaker: NA
Text: than that number had applied for land but

Speaker: NA
Text: only 36,000 had all the qualifications essen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tial to make a success of farming. The

Speaker: NA
Text: other day I asked the Minister for Primary

Speaker: NA
Text: Industry ( Mr MCMahon) to tell me the

Speaker: NA
Text: number of ex-servicemen who had been

Speaker: NA
Text: settled upon the land and the cost to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government of their settlement. He

Speaker: NA
Text: informed me that throughout the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth 7,529 had been settled and the cost

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Commonwealth Government was.

Speaker: NA
Text: £56,645,491. In addition to that, New

Speaker: NA
Text: South Wales had spent £38,600,000.

Speaker: NA
Text: Victoria £38,000,000, and Queensland

Speaker: NA
Text: £4,700,000. That means that 7,000 persons

Speaker: NA
Text: were settled upon the land at a cost of

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Mackinnon -Tha t did not include

Speaker: NA
Text: single-unit farms.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: were settled upon the land. Re-establish-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment agricultural loan applications were in

Speaker: NA
Text: addition to that, and. £10,000.000 was

Speaker: NA
Text: granted for that purpose.

Speaker: NA
Text: The point I desire to make is that that

Speaker: NA
Text: is a vast expenditure to settle comparatively

Speaker: NA
Text: few people upon the land. The story, of

Speaker: NA
Text: course, is worse than it appears at first

Speaker: NA
Text: sight, because in Tasmania 340 ex-service-

Speaker: NA
Text: men were settled at a cost of £9,338,000.

Speaker: NA
Text: nearly £30,000 for each settler. In Western

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia 692 ex-servicemen were settled

Speaker: NA
Text: at a cost of £24.241,000, again over £30,000

Speaker: NA
Text: for each settler - Of course, some additional

Speaker: NA
Text: work may be in progress that will mean that

Speaker: NA
Text: ultimately more ex-servicemen will go upon

Speaker: NA
Text: the land. However, the figures are stagger-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing and national disaster exists in the fact

Speaker: NA
Text: that we cannot, as a nation, commence any

Speaker: NA
Text: type of civilian settlement until we have

Speaker: NA
Text: all the ex-servicemen seeking to go

Speaker: NA
Text: upon the land.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is of the greatest importance to the

Speaker: NA
Text: people of this country that more and more

Speaker: NA
Text: people be settled upon the land. I recall

Speaker: NA
Text: that during the period prior to World

Speaker: NA
Text: War II . governments in this country were

Speaker: NA
Text: deploring the drift from the country to the

Speaker: NA
Text: cities. They were deploring the lack ot

Speaker: NA
Text: balance that existed in the community due

Speaker: NA
Text: to a large preponderance of people being

Speaker: NA
Text: engaged in urban and city occupations

Speaker: NA
Text: whilst relatively few were settled on the

Speaker: NA
Text: land. As the years passed by those engaged

Speaker: NA
Text: in rural occupations were becoming fewer,

Speaker: NA
Text: and it was said that the position had to be

Speaker: NA
Text: remedied. To-day, we have a governmenl

Speaker: NA
Text: that points out that we must bring more

Speaker: NA
Text: and more immigrants from overseas if we

Speaker: NA
Text: are to carry on efficiently as a nation and

Speaker: NA
Text: develop Australia as it should be developed

Speaker: NA
Text: and that our immigrants must be employed

Speaker: NA
Text: mainly in primary production. That being

Speaker: NA
Text: so, we should have more and more people

Speaker: NA
Text: upon the land. Even if the population of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia had remained stationary from

Speaker: NA
Text: 1939 until the present time the position

Speaker: NA
Text: would not be satisfactory, but it has not

Speaker: NA
Text: done so. In 1939, the population was

Speaker: NA
Text: 7,077,586, whereas to-day it is over

Speaker: NA
Text: 9,090,000. The census taken in 1954

Speaker: NA
Text: revealed a population of 9,090,000 people.

Speaker: NA
Text: So, there were 2,000,000 more people in

Speaker: NA
Text: this country at that date than there were

Speaker: NA
Text: I also asked the Minister for Primary

Speaker: NA
Text: Industry to state the number of rural hold-

Speaker: NA
Text: ings in 1939 and the number to-day. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister was unable to tell me the number

Speaker: NA
Text: in 1939 but he told me that in 1946 the

Speaker: NA
Text: number was 233,000. I am able to tell the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister the figure for 1939 because I

Speaker: NA
Text: secured the information from the " Year-

Speaker: NA
Text: Book'". In 1939 there were 253,000 farms

Speaker: NA
Text: in Australia whereas, to-day, there arc

Speaker: NA
Text: 20,000 fewer farms in this country.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Mackinnon -Tha t number included

Speaker: NA
Text: areas of under ten acres on which somebody

Speaker: NA
Text: ran a cow or a sheep. Those areas have

Speaker: NA
Text: been absorbed in building settlements

Speaker: NA
Text: adjacent to metropolitan areas.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: for Corangamite ( Mr Mackinnon) points

Speaker: NA
Text: out that the number I have quoted includes

Speaker: NA
Text: small farms. I am an advocate for small

Speaker: NA
Text: farms. The fact is that in 1939, 253,000

Speaker: NA
Text: farms were owned by farmers and in 1946

Speaker: NA
Text: the number was 233,000, a diminution of

Speaker: NA
Text: 20,000. At the present time, I am in-

Speaker: NA
Text: formed, the number is 243,000; so, the

Speaker: NA
Text: number of farms has diminished by over

Speaker: NA
Text: 10,000 although £138,000,000 has been

Speaker: NA
Text: expended in order to settle on the land

Speaker: NA
Text: 7,000 more farmers, and, in addition,

Speaker: NA
Text: £10,000,000 has been granted to farmers in

Speaker: NA
Text: occupation of farms or to others who were

Speaker: NA
Text: securing farms and required only re-estab-

Speaker: NA
Text: lishment agricultural loans. Nobody can

Speaker: NA
Text: be satisfied with that position from a

Speaker: NA
Text: national point of view.

Speaker: NA
Text: f also asked the Minister for Primary

Speaker: NA
Text: Industry to state the number of people en-

Speaker: NA
Text: gaged in rural occupations in 1939. He

Speaker: NA
Text: informed me that in that year the number

Speaker: NA
Text: was 391.000, and in 1955 it was 357,000, a

Speaker: NA
Text: reduction of 34,000, despite the fact that we

Speaker: NA
Text: have an increased population of well over

Speaker: NA
Text: 2,000,000 people. No one can deny thai

Speaker: NA
Text: there is a lack of balance in the develop-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of this country about which tie

Speaker: NA
Text: Government should do something. Tie

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth Government, of course, fas

Speaker: NA
Text: the overriding authority. It provides tie

Speaker: NA
Text: finance and those who pay the piper shoud

Speaker: NA
Text: have a fair chance of at least calling tie

Speaker: NA
Text: tune.

Speaker: NA
Text: I suggest to the Government that, in tie

Speaker: NA
Text: interests of the development of this nation

Speaker: NA
Text: and to encourage more and more people b

Speaker: NA
Text: go on to the land, it should immediately cal

Speaker: NA
Text: a conference of representatives of the Stat;

Speaker: NA
Text: departments which deal with land settle

Speaker: NA
Text: ment and Commonwealth authorities. Thost

Speaker: NA
Text: representatives should investigate methods

Speaker: NA
Text: that will enable the completion of soldier

Speaker: NA
Text: settlement schemes and evolve some plan

Speaker: NA
Text: that will enable a greater settlement to take

Speaker: NA
Text: place throughout this country. Everybody

Speaker: NA
Text: knows that vast areas of land are not being

Speaker: NA
Text: used to their full productive capacity. From

Speaker: NA
Text: the east to the west of Victoria are vast

Speaker: NA
Text: areas of land with hardly a sheep or any

Speaker: NA
Text: other animal upon them. They are not

Speaker: NA
Text: being used to their full productive capacity.

Speaker: NA
Text: Any one travelling by train from Victoria

Speaker: NA
Text: to Canberra will see areas of land in New

Speaker: NA
Text: South Wales that, under existing conditions,

Speaker: NA
Text: are not being used to their full productive

Speaker: NA
Text: capacity.

Speaker: NA
Text: With the advantages that science has

Speaker: NA
Text: brought to agriculture, those areas could

Speaker: NA
Text: be made considerably more productive than

Speaker: NA
Text: they are to-day. The development of those

Speaker: NA
Text: areas would make possible the settlement

Speaker: NA
Text: of more people on the land and absorb some

Speaker: NA
Text: of those who have come, or who may come,

Speaker: NA
Text: from overseas to help to build up this great

Speaker: NA
Text: nation. But nothing is done! Eleven years

Speaker: NA
Text: have passed since World War II . ended,

Speaker: NA
Text: but governments admit that they have not

Speaker: NA
Text: completed the scheme for the land settle-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of ex-servicemen that was commenced

Speaker: NA
Text: after the war. I do not know how many

Speaker: NA
Text: of those who fought in Korea have applied

Speaker: NA
Text: for land, but their prospects are distant

Speaker: NA
Text: indeed.

Speaker: NA
Text: In a country like Australia, the settle-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of people on the land should be a

Speaker: NA
Text: major and urgent consideration. The Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth says that the States should

Speaker: NA
Text: undertake this responsibility, and the State*

Speaker: NA
Text: sav that the Commonwealth does not pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vide sufficient money for the purpose.

Speaker: NA
Text: Because that method of evading respon-

Speaker: NA
Text: sibility is adopted, the scheme of repatria-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion is not carried out. When I asked my

Speaker: NA
Text: question in 1953, I was told that 36,000

Speaker: NA
Text: elijible, suitable people had applied to go

Speaker: NA
Text: on the land. If I were to ask the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: today how many men wanted to go on the

Speaker: NA
Text: laid, I would probably find that there is

Speaker: NA
Text: net the difference between the 7,000 that

Speaker: NA
Text: hai been settled upon the land

Text: ( Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bwden) -Order ! The honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber's time has expired.

Speaker: Mr TURNBULL
Text: Mallee) [10.4] -

Speaker: NA
Text: lefore I come to the matters on which I

Speaker: NA
Text: cesire to speak, I shall touch on one or two

Speaker: NA
Text: «f the salient points made by the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: rery rightly, that war service land settlement

Speaker: NA
Text: has cost an enormous amount of money. I

Speaker: NA
Text: know that is to be deplored, but however

Speaker: NA
Text: much soldier settlement costs, when valua-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions of soldier settlement holdings are

Speaker: NA
Text: made, the men who have been put on the

Speaker: NA
Text: land must secure it at a productive value.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is not their fault that it has cost the Go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment a lot of money. Valuations are

Speaker: NA
Text: being made at the present time in a place

Speaker: NA
Text: that I represent, Robinvale, in Victoria,

Speaker: NA
Text: where we have a great new vine fruit settle-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. Many of the settlers realize that the

Speaker: NA
Text: prices that are indicated are far too high for

Speaker: NA
Text: them to be able to make a good living.

Speaker: NA
Text: Although these blocks have cost a lot of

Speaker: NA
Text: money, as the honorable member for Scullin

Speaker: NA
Text: has rightly pointed out, let us advocate in

Speaker: NA
Text: this Parliament, whenever we get the oppor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tunity, that the valuations for the returned

Speaker: NA
Text: soldiers be kept as low as possible. If that

Speaker: NA
Text: is done, these men who have served this

Speaker: NA
Text: country will go on the land with a chance of

Speaker: NA
Text: making a good living and at the same time

Speaker: NA
Text: will be in a position to produce those goods

Speaker: NA
Text: that we now need so urgently-mor e

Speaker: NA
Text: urgently, perhaps, than ever before.

Speaker: NA
Text: The other point I want to make may not

Speaker: NA
Text: be quite so pleasant to the honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber for Scullin. He has pointed out that

Speaker: NA
Text: fewer people are on the land to-day than

Speaker: NA
Text: was the case some years ago. I have no

Speaker: NA
Text: reason whatever to doubt his figures, but I

Speaker: NA
Text: believe there is an explanation for the posi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. Tbe explanation is that we have

Speaker: NA
Text: modern machinery now. We have

Speaker: NA
Text: machinery which enables two men to har-

Speaker: NA
Text: vest hundreds of bushels of wheat whereas

Speaker: NA
Text: previously many men were required to do

Speaker: NA
Text: the job. Hitherto, bags had to be sewn,

Speaker: NA
Text: and other jobs had to be done by hand'

Speaker: NA
Text: which gave employment to a number of

Speaker: NA
Text: men. To-day, we have bulk handling of

Speaker: NA
Text: wheat, and few employees are required.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is the full answer to the honorable-

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Scullin.

Speaker: NA
Text: When I came into this Parliament first in

Speaker: NA
Text: 1946, just after the war, when Labour

Speaker: NA
Text: was in power, most of my correspondence

Speaker: NA
Text: was from people wanting tractors, harves-

Speaker: NA
Text: ters and all the modern equipment. Witb

Speaker: NA
Text: the new machinery, two or three times the

Speaker: NA
Text: amount of work can be done with half the

Speaker: NA
Text: number of men. That is all the better for

Speaker: NA
Text: this great continent of Australia because,

Speaker: NA
Text: as everybody knows, we have a labour'

Speaker: NA
Text: shortage. The more labour we can save by

Speaker: NA
Text: using machinery, up to a point-an d I

Speaker: NA
Text: admit with Labour supporters that it must

Speaker: NA
Text: be up to a point-th e better for this,

Speaker: NA
Text: country.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honorable member for Scullin also-

Speaker: NA
Text: stated that vast areas of land are not being

Speaker: NA
Text: used in this country.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: productive capacity.

Speaker: Mr TURNBULL
Text: I accept the correc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. I want to be right when I use the

Speaker: NA
Text: words of the honorable member for Scullin.

Speaker: NA
Text: His suggestion is quite right in relation to-

Speaker: NA
Text: some places. He said that any one travel-

Speaker: NA
Text: ling to Canberra through Albury can see

Speaker: NA
Text: vast areas of paddocks without much stock

Speaker: NA
Text: on them. Much the same thing can be

Speaker: NA
Text: seen in my electorate, but there is such a

Speaker: NA
Text: thing as rotation of cropping. The best

Speaker: NA
Text: method is to sow a crop of wheat in one

Speaker: NA
Text: year, miss two years and then sow another

Speaker: NA
Text: crop. If a crop is sown every year on the

Speaker: NA
Text: same land, the returns will rapidly diminish.

Speaker: NA
Text: With the high price of sheep to-day, it does

Speaker: NA
Text: not pay a man to buy sheep and put them

Speaker: NA
Text: on the land, in certain circumstances, al-

Speaker: NA
Text: though it is an aid to the rotational system.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is the answer to the honorable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Scullin. There are areas of land that

Speaker: NA
Text: could be brought into greater productivity,

Speaker: NA
Text: but a lot of the paddocks that the city

Speaker: NA
Text: dweller looks at and thinks are not used

Speaker: NA
Text: because he cannot see any stock or crops,

Speaker: NA
Text: are not really neglected. There are reasons,

Speaker: NA
Text: for these things, and this is the place for

Speaker: NA
Text: us to give those reasons when a speech is

Speaker: NA
Text: made, such as that made by the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Scullin, which is not wholly

Speaker: NA
Text: wrong but is only partly correct.

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to thank the Federal Government

Speaker: NA
Text: for providing £300,000 for the dried vine

Speaker: NA
Text: fruit growers of Victoria, not as a loan,

Speaker: NA
Text: as a grant. This Government gave it to

Speaker: NA
Text: them through the Victorian Government.

Speaker: NA
Text: For two years I have been pointing out in

Speaker: NA
Text: this chamber that the dried fruits industry

Speaker: NA
Text: needed all the assistance we could give it.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the dry seasons some years ago, the

Speaker: NA
Text: industry had good drying periods; but over

Speaker: NA
Text: the last four or five years, just when the

Speaker: NA
Text: harvest was ready, down came the rain.

Speaker: NA
Text: That was all right for wheat but it was no

Speaker: NA
Text: good for dried fruits. When the rain came,

Speaker: NA
Text: the crop was absolutely ruined. The grant

Speaker: NA
Text: of £300,000, and the price paid overseas

Speaker: NA
Text: for dried fruits, have given the industry new

Speaker: NA
Text: life. Although this year's crop is very poor,

Speaker: NA
Text: I hope brighter times are ahead for the

Speaker: NA
Text: dried fruits industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: Before I say something that does not

Speaker: NA
Text: favour the Postmaster-General ( Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Davidson), I want to state that I was very

Speaker: NA
Text: delighted, after my advocacy, that he was

Speaker: NA
Text: able to reinstate a news service from

Speaker: NA
Text: stations 3WV and 3WL in western Victoria.

Speaker: NA
Text: It will be remembered that I. mentioned

Speaker: NA
Text: this matter in the House on a previous

Speaker: NA
Text: occasion. I said that on Monday morning

Speaker: NA
Text: we had an all-sports broadcast, and that

Speaker: NA
Text: we had no news service at all from Saturday

Speaker: NA
Text: night until Monday night. That has now

Speaker: NA
Text: been changed, and we have a six-minute

Speaker: NA
Text: western Victorian regional news service on

Speaker: NA
Text: Monday mornings from 3WV and 3WL,

Speaker: NA
Text: followed by four minutes of South Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian news. It was thought at one time

Speaker: NA
Text: that there would not be enough news to fill

Speaker: NA
Text: in the time, but that has not proved to be

Speaker: NA
Text: the case. The time is well filled, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: news is quite interesting. When we tune

Speaker: NA
Text: in to this news broadcast we get all the

Speaker: NA
Text: week-end news, and every one knows that

Speaker: NA
Text: it is. during the week-end that interesting

Speaker: NA
Text: news items are gathered. I can assure

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable members that my constituents and

Speaker: NA
Text: others fully appreciate it.

Speaker: NA
Text: 1 should like now to make some remarks

Speaker: NA
Text: about flood relief. I: represent a district

Speaker: NA
Text: that includes 248 miles of Murray River

Speaker: NA
Text: frontage, and the people in my electorate

Speaker: NA
Text: have suffered severely. I had the privilege

Speaker: NA
Text: ef submitting to the House, as its first

Speaker: NA
Text: business in this sessional period, a definite

Speaker: NA
Text: matter of urgent public importance, namely,

Speaker: NA
Text: the disastrous effect of the flooding of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Murray River and its tributaries. In the

Speaker: NA
Text: short time at my disposal I could not

Speaker: NA
Text: traverse the matter in full detail, nor can I

Speaker: NA
Text: but do so now. I have been in the affected

Speaker: NA
Text: area again recently. I went to Swan Hill

Speaker: NA
Text: last Saturday, and one of the results of the

Speaker: NA
Text: flood devastation that was particularly

Speaker: NA
Text: noticeable was the state of the roads. They

Speaker: NA
Text: are just deplorable. The floods have

Speaker: NA
Text: undermined the bitumen and the founda-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions, and have swept the road material

Speaker: NA
Text: away in many places. Much of the road

Speaker: NA
Text: foundations have been completely destroyed,

Speaker: NA
Text: and it will cost many thousands of pounds

Speaker: NA
Text: to put the roads back into their former con-

Speaker: NA
Text: dition. I have tried previously to persuade

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government to change the formula that

Speaker: NA
Text: is used for the distribution of receipts from

Speaker: NA
Text: petrol tax. If the whole of the money raised

Speaker: NA
Text: by petrol tax were distributed to the States.

Speaker: NA
Text: Western Australia and Queensland would

Speaker: NA
Text: receive far more than they could use.

Speaker: NA
Text: Every one knows that that is a fact. I

Speaker: NA
Text: suggest that the Govemment, which is retain-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing about 5d. of the tax collected on each

Speaker: NA
Text: gallon of petrol, should distribute some of

Speaker: NA
Text: that money, in the form of flood relief, to

Speaker: NA
Text: enable the roads that have been devastated

Speaker: NA
Text: by floods to be repaired. This is a fair

Speaker: NA
Text: proposition, because the tax has been col-

Speaker: NA
Text: lected from people who transport goods

Speaker: NA
Text: over the roads, and transport vehicles must

Speaker: NA
Text: be enabled to travel again over good roads

Speaker: NA
Text: in these districts if we are to market the

Speaker: NA
Text: products that grow there so proliflcally, and

Speaker: NA
Text: if, as the honorable member for Scullin

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: more people to settle on the land in the

Speaker: NA
Text: future.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Postmaster-General ( Mr Davidson)

Speaker: NA
Text: knows very well that when I said that 1

Speaker: NA
Text: might speak of a matter that is less pleasing

Speaker: NA
Text: to him I referred to the post office at Robin-

Speaker: NA
Text: vale, in Victoria. Robinvale is a very pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: gressive soldier settlement area, where the

Speaker: NA
Text: settlers produce, mainly, dried vine fruits.

Speaker: NA
Text: The post office in this town is an old tin

Speaker: NA
Text: shed. It was illustrated in the Melbourne

Speaker: NA
Text: " Argus" some nine or ten months ago.

Speaker: NA
Text: The population of the town some little time

Speaker: NA
Text: ago was only 200 or 300, but now it has

Speaker: NA
Text: grown to about 3,000, and we still have the

Speaker: NA
Text: old tin shed for a post office. I am not

Speaker: NA
Text: complaining too bitterly about this matter,

Speaker: NA
Text: because for some years I have been advo-

Speaker: NA
Text: cating that a new post office should be

Speaker: NA
Text: built at Robinvale, and the Postmaster-

Speaker: NA
Text: General has assured me that provision has

Speaker: NA
Text: been made for it in the Estimates. But it

Speaker: NA
Text: was also provided for in the Estimates last

Speaker: NA
Text: year. I am not sure whether it was in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Estimates for the year before that. How-

Speaker: NA
Text: ever, it is included in the Estimates for this

Speaker: NA
Text: year, and I hope that a start will be made

Speaker: NA
Text: -on it. Honorable members can imagine

Speaker: NA
Text: the conditions in a tin shed in northern

Speaker: NA
Text: Victoria in summer, not only for the em-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployees of the department but also for the

Speaker: NA
Text: vastly increased population of the town and

Speaker: NA
Text: -district, who have to use this public utility.

Speaker: NA
Text: 1 ask the Postmaster-General to endeavour

Speaker: NA
Text: to expedite this work as much as possible,

Speaker: NA
Text: -so that the people of Robinvale may be pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vided with a post office building worthy of

Speaker: NA
Text: rhe town.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have heard many honorable members

Speaker: NA
Text: speaking about railways and some speaking

Speaker: NA
Text: about the port at Portland, and I wish to

Speaker: NA
Text: say a few words on this subject in the short

Speaker: NA
Text: time that remains at my disposal. We have

Speaker: NA
Text: had general discussions on railways, and I

Speaker: NA
Text: believe, therefore, that I am entitled to

Speaker: NA
Text: -speak on this matter. I have advocated on

Speaker: NA
Text: many occasions the construction of a rail-

Speaker: NA
Text: way from Hay to Ouyen. This is not only

Speaker: NA
Text: my idea; it has been advocated by people

Speaker: NA
Text: in northern Victoria and other places for

Speaker: NA
Text: 25 years or more. A railway line from

Speaker: NA
Text: Hay to Ouyen would provide a rail link

Speaker: NA
Text: from Adelaide to Sydney, obviating the

Speaker: NA
Text: necessity to send goods via Melbourne.

Speaker: NA
Text: This, incidentally, may be a reason why we

Speaker: NA
Text: have not been successful in obtaining this

Speaker: NA
Text: rail link, because the city octopus prefers

Speaker: NA
Text: to have the goods sent through Melbourne,

Speaker: NA
Text: and then through Bacchus Marsh and up a

Speaker: NA
Text: -steep grade, where all the loads have to be

Speaker: NA
Text: reduced. If a line were constructed be-

Speaker: NA
Text: tween Hay and Ouyen. and another from

Speaker: NA
Text: Patchewollock to Ouyen, we would have a

Speaker: NA
Text: link with the port at Portland. The honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Ballarat ( Mr Erwin) has

Speaker: NA
Text: said that it is time we had a port at Port-

Speaker: NA
Text: land, and also one at Eden. J can tell him

Speaker: NA
Text: that the one at Portland is almost an

Speaker: NA
Text: accomplished fact. The work has been

Speaker: NA
Text: going on for some years, and before many

Speaker: NA
Text: more years have passed there will be a

Speaker: NA
Text: first-class deep-water port at Portland. I

Speaker: NA
Text: am most interested in this matter, because I

Speaker: NA
Text: believe that we should send goods from the

Speaker: NA
Text: Mallee district to Portland, and receive

Speaker: NA
Text: goods at that place from overseas and from

Speaker: NA
Text: other parts of Australia. They should then

Speaker: NA
Text: be transported into the north-western part

Speaker: NA
Text: of Victoria without going through Mel-

Speaker: NA
Text: bourne at all.

Speaker: NA
Text: An amount of money has been provided

Speaker: NA
Text: in these Estimates for the reception of

Speaker: NA
Text: immigrants. I believe that a lot of immi-

Speaker: NA
Text: grants who have been nominated for rural

Speaker: NA
Text: work never get to the country at all. They

Speaker: NA
Text: come to Melbourne and are then sent to

Speaker: NA
Text: the reception depots, and are offered good

Speaker: NA
Text: wages for jobs in the city. Their friends

Speaker: NA
Text: persuade them to stay in Melbourne, and

Speaker: NA
Text: their nominators may never see them. Those

Speaker: NA
Text: immigrants should disembark at places like

Speaker: NA
Text: Portland, from which they can be sent

Speaker: NA
Text: straight to their destinations in the country.

Speaker: NA
Text: They should not be exposed to the cit>

Speaker: NA
Text: lights immediately on their arrival in the

Speaker: NA
Text: country. Many of these immigrants have

Speaker: NA
Text: worked on intensive culture farms, which

Speaker: NA
Text: are little better than market gardens, and

Speaker: NA
Text: which are usually located adjacent to cities.

Speaker: NA
Text: They have been able to go to the cities every

Speaker: NA
Text: weekend, and in some cases every night. If

Speaker: NA
Text: we take them hundreds of miles from a city

Speaker: NA
Text: they will want to get back to it. In ordet

Speaker: NA
Text: to start them off on the right track, I suggest

Speaker: NA
Text: that reception depots should be located ai

Speaker: NA
Text: places like Portland. The immigrants can

Speaker: NA
Text: then be sent to their jobs in the country,

Speaker: NA
Text: and they will be more likely to stay there.

Speaker: NA
Text: Order! The honorable member's time has.

Speaker: NA
Text: expired.

Speaker: Mr MINOGUE
Text: West Sydney) [10.19].

Speaker: NA
Text: -Th e group of Estimates that we are now

Speaker: NA
Text: discussing includes miscellaneous services,

Speaker: NA
Text: refunds of revenue and advance to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer. My complaint is that the Trea-

Speaker: NA
Text: surer has given very few advances to the

Speaker: NA
Text: State of New South Wales, in which my

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate is situated. We are also con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sidering bounties and subsidies, and wai

Speaker: NA
Text: and repatriation services.

Speaker: NA
Text: For the last eight weeks we have been

Speaker: NA
Text: discussing the budget and the Estimates for

Speaker: NA
Text: various departments. Most of our time

Speaker: NA
Text: has been taken up with a discussion of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Estimates for defence services. I take

Speaker: NA
Text: second place to no one in advocating the

Speaker: NA
Text: effective defence of Australia, but I believe

Speaker: NA
Text: it is wrong to spend £190,000,000 annually

Speaker: NA
Text: on defence in peace-time, while allowing

Speaker: NA
Text: thousands of our people to go hungry and

Speaker: NA
Text: unhoused. When war breaks out no diffi-

Speaker: NA
Text: culty is encountered in finding money to

Speaker: NA
Text: finance our war effort. I f the last world

Speaker: NA
Text: war had continued for another two years,

Speaker: NA
Text: we would have found sufficient money to

Speaker: NA
Text: conduct it.

Speaker: NA
Text: The people whom 1 represent should be

Speaker: NA
Text: much better looked after. Every honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member will agree with the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: that shipping is very important, but I have

Speaker: NA
Text: before me a letter from a worker at Cocka-

Speaker: NA
Text: too Dock showing just what the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment is doing about providing shipping.

Speaker: NA
Text: Potatoes have been lying on the wharfs in

Speaker: NA
Text: Tasmania, and hardly a ship has been avail-

Speaker: NA
Text: able to bring them to Sydney, Melbourne

Speaker: NA
Text: and the other places where they are needed.

Speaker: NA
Text: At the same time, shipbuilders, including

Speaker: NA
Text: many men who were trained under the

Speaker: NA
Text: Chifley Labour Government's reconstruc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion training scheme after the war, are being

Speaker: NA
Text: put off at Australian dockyards at the rate

Speaker: NA
Text: of 100 a week. They are good tradesmen,

Speaker: NA
Text: but they are being told to look elsewhere

Speaker: NA
Text: for work. The letter gives first-hand infor-

Speaker: NA
Text: mation on what is happening in the dock-

Speaker: NA
Text: yards. It reads-

Speaker: NA
Text: In the week ending 2nd October, about eighty

Speaker: NA
Text: workers were dismissed at Cockatoo Dockyard, and

Speaker: NA
Text: the management has intimated that upwards of one

Speaker: NA
Text: hundred more will probably be dismissed in the

Speaker: NA
Text: next few weeks.

Speaker: NA
Text: These sackings, following numerous others at

Speaker: NA
Text: Garden Island

Speaker: NA
Text: About 120 men were put off three weeks

Speaker: NA
Text: ago and a deputation came to Canberra to

Speaker: NA
Text: see the Minister for the Navy (Senator

Speaker: NA
Text: O'Sullivan), but with very little result. The

Speaker: NA
Text: letter continues-

Speaker: NA
Text: Williamstown Dockyard, N.S.W. State Dockyard,

Speaker: NA
Text: Mort's Dock, Poole & Steel, and other firms, show

Speaker: NA
Text: an alarming situation in the Australian ship-

Speaker: NA
Text: building industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: Hundreds of men are being sacked while ships

Speaker: NA
Text: for our coastal trade are being built in West

Speaker: NA
Text: Germany and Japan.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government is sacking men who fought

Speaker: NA
Text: for their country, but is giving contracts for

Speaker: NA
Text: shipbuilding to West Germany and Japan!

Speaker: NA
Text: That is typical of its attitude -The writer

Speaker: NA
Text: continues-

Speaker: NA
Text: The Federal Government has stated and reitei-

Speaker: NA
Text: ated its intention of building and maintaining an

Speaker: NA
Text: efficient shipbuilding industry as a national

Speaker: NA
Text: sity, but it would seem this is not being carried

Speaker: NA
Text: out.

Speaker: NA
Text: As an employee of Cockatoo and one of your

Speaker: NA
Text: constituents, I request that you raise this matter

Speaker: NA
Text: in Parliament and have the dismissals at Cockatoo

Speaker: NA
Text: cancelled, and also that steps be taken imme-

Speaker: NA
Text: diately to ensure that the declared policy of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government is put into effect.

Speaker: NA
Text: Is it Government policy to throw skilled

Speaker: NA
Text: tradesmen into an unemployment pool? The

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member for Mallee ( Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Turnbull) told us that men were not needed

Speaker: NA
Text: in the country, where machinery did all the

Speaker: NA
Text: work, yet in the dockyards and shipbuilding

Speaker: NA
Text: industry of the cities men are being put off,

Speaker: NA
Text: as they were in the depression some

Speaker: NA
Text: years ago!

Speaker: NA
Text: I turn now to the subject of war and

Speaker: NA
Text: repatriation services. This is the most in-

Speaker: NA
Text: sincere Government that has ever sat on the

Speaker: NA
Text: treasury bench. I t has promised the soldiers

Speaker: NA
Text: that it will give them homes, but it will have

Speaker: NA
Text: gone to the polls, and been beaten, long

Speaker: NA
Text: before that promise can be honoured. Two

Speaker: NA
Text: years pass before an applicant for a war

Speaker: NA
Text: service home is authorized even to raise

Speaker: NA
Text: money with which to buy a home. The

Speaker: NA
Text: present Minister for Primary Industry ( Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: MCMahon), when he was Minister for Social

Speaker: NA
Text: -Services told honorable members that

Speaker: NA
Text: returned soldiers who wished to buy a home

Speaker: NA
Text: should be advised to go to a private bank or

Speaker: NA
Text: insurance company for finance.

Speaker: NA
Text: Order! Housing does not come within the

Speaker: NA
Text: scope of the Estimates that are before the

Speaker: NA
Text: committee.

Speaker: Mr MINOGUE
Text: Thi s Government, in

Speaker: NA
Text: -telling ex-servicemen that they will have a

Speaker: NA
Text: house in eighteen months' or two years'

Speaker: NA
Text: time, is making a promise that it does not

Speaker: NA
Text: intend to fulfil. Indeed, it will not even be

Speaker: NA
Text: on the treasury bench in another two years.

Speaker: NA
Text: As has happened on previous occasions, it

Speaker: NA
Text: will be dismissed from office and will leave

Speaker: NA
Text: the mess for the incoming Labour govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment to clean up.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government has allowed the age

Speaker: NA
Text: pensioners to starve, ignoring the fact that

Speaker: NA
Text: in recent years the cost of living has gone

Speaker: NA
Text: up 200 per cent. In New South Wales

Speaker: NA
Text: alone, 60,000 people are still urgently in

Speaker: NA
Text: need of homes. A l l that this Government

Speaker: NA
Text: will do is to say that the State government

Speaker: NA
Text: must provide them. The present Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: neces- for the Army ( Mr Cramer) and the honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Sturt ( Mr Wilson) were

Speaker: NA
Text: going to remedy the housing position, but

Speaker: NA
Text: precisely nothing has been done about iL

Speaker: NA
Text: Fifteen shillings of every £1 that is col-

Speaker: NA
Text: lected in taxation in New South Wales goes

Speaker: NA
Text: to the federal Treasurer, who then tells

Speaker: NA
Text: us fhat the State should be able to build the

Speaker: NA
Text: homes that it needs. About £14,000,000

Speaker: NA
