Text: was spent on housing last year.

Speaker: NA
Text: Order! The honorable member cannot disMany

Speaker: NA
Text: cuss housing during a consideration of

Speaker: NA
Text: Estimates.

Speaker: Mr MINOGUE
Text: Referrin g again to the

Speaker: NA
Text: shipping position, I would mention the

Speaker: NA
Text: plight of Lord Howe Island, which .has been

Speaker: NA
Text: virtually boycotted by tbis Government.

Speaker: NA
Text: Though the Treasurer collects income

Speaker: NA
Text: other taxes from the people of the island

Speaker: NA
Text: not one ship has been sent .there in recent

Speaker: NA
Text: times. Tbe Goverament ignores requests to

Speaker: NA
Text: visit the island and ascertain whether

Speaker: NA
Text: airstrip could be built there. There are

Speaker: NA
Text: 215 people oh the electoral roll, and

Speaker: NA
Text: visit the island on holidays every week.

Speaker: NA
Text: These 500 people are at the mercy of a

Speaker: NA
Text: service using a flying boat which is

Speaker: NA
Text: 25 years old. If it breaks down tbere is

Speaker: NA
Text: - not .another to take its place. The Governtutions

Speaker: NA
Text: ment has ignored requests for the

Speaker: NA
Text: -of shipping, and for the building of an air-

Speaker: NA
Text: strip at the island. The people of Lord

Speaker: NA
Text: Howe Island, like Robinson Crusoe, are

Speaker: NA
Text: marooned, yet this Government claims that

Speaker: NA
Text: it looks after the people.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government has done a great dispaupers.

Speaker: NA
Text: service to Australia, and ,to New South

Speaker: NA
Text: "Wales in particular. The present Postmasterpersons

Speaker: NA
Text: General ( Mr Davidson), when appointed, manner.

Speaker: NA
Text: gave excellent promise of supplying some of

Speaker: NA
Text: the services which have been unavailable

Speaker: NA
Text: ten or twelve years, and wc felt that we

Speaker: NA
Text: well rid of his predecessor. The other day

Speaker: NA
Text: I brought up the case of a man who had

Speaker: NA
Text: been waiting for a telephone service

Speaker: NA
Text: ten years. He came into my office last

Speaker: NA
Text: Monday. He was on his way to the general

Speaker: NA
Text: post office, to find out whether he would

Speaker: NA
Text: a telephone. The Minister had sent me a

Speaker: NA
Text: letter saying that he would get a telephone

Speaker: NA
Text: within three months, but my constituent

Speaker: NA
Text: said, " I can't believe that. I don't think

Speaker: NA
Text: that I will ever get i t " . His application

Speaker: NA
Text: has been on the files ever since the honorto

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Dalley, Mr O'Connor,

Speaker: NA
Text: represented that portion of the present

Speaker: NA
Text: torate of West Sydney. It can be seen on

Speaker: NA
Text: the files.

Speaker: NA
Text: -Order! The honorable member must not

Speaker: NA
Text: mention names in this debate.

Speaker: Mr MINOGUE
Text: Th e honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber for East Sydney ( Mr Ward) has re-

Speaker: NA
Text: ferred in this chamber to persons who have

Speaker: NA
Text: had applications for telephones with the

Speaker: NA
Text: Postal Department for six or seven years.

Speaker: NA
Text: persons who urgently need telephone

Speaker: NA
Text: these connexions cannot get the service.

Speaker: NA
Text: 1 give this Government credit for taking

Speaker: NA
Text: a step in the right direction when it pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vided a £l-for-£l subsidy for the provision

Speaker: NA
Text: of homes for aged persons, but the money

Speaker: NA
Text: that is available is not being spent quickly

Speaker: NA
Text: and enough. Why cannot the Government pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vide this money without strings to it? Per-

Speaker: NA
Text: sons who are interested in institutions for

Speaker: NA
Text: the aged have to go around with collection

Speaker: NA
Text: an boxes trying to raise money so that they

Speaker: NA
Text: can obtain the benefit of a subsidy from

Speaker: NA
Text: .300 the Government. At this time, when

Speaker: NA
Text: hospital facilities for aged persons are not

Speaker: NA
Text: available, and many are living in rooms or

Speaker: NA
Text: about are sleeping in parks, the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: should make straight-out advances to insti-

Speaker: NA
Text: and organizations that are prepared

Speaker: NA
Text: provision to provide homes for the aged.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government provides a funeral bene-

Speaker: NA
Text: fit of £10. It is impossible to buy a plot

Speaker: NA
Text: of land for a grave for that amount, but

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government is prepared to allow the

Speaker: NA
Text: pioneers of Australia to be buried as

Speaker: NA
Text: I f they had not subscribed to

Speaker: NA
Text: funds for funeral expenses, many aged

Speaker: NA
Text: -would not be buried in the proper

Speaker: NA
Text: We have an organization at No. 7

Speaker: NA
Text: for Young-street, Sydney, where 3,000 meals

Speaker: NA
Text: were are provided for aged pensioners in the

Speaker: NA
Text: last days of each fortnight before pension

Speaker: NA
Text: day. They flock to that centre. There are

Speaker: NA
Text: for 30 beds where they may sleep without

Speaker: NA
Text: charge. This Government is always ready

Speaker: NA
Text: to give relief to other nations. Why can-

Speaker: NA
Text: get not it give aid to its own peqple first?

Speaker: Mr DAVIDSON
Text: Dawson-Postmaster -

Speaker: NA
Text: General) [10.34] - I do not desire to in-

Speaker: NA
Text: trude unduly into these discussions, or to

Speaker: NA
Text: take too much of the time that is available

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable members to discuss various

Speaker: NA
Text: departments in connexion witb the

Speaker: NA
Text: elecEstimates that are before the committee.

Speaker: NA
Text: Nevertheless, it is desirable that I should

Speaker: NA
Text: make some comments on the opinions that

Speaker: NA
Text: have been expressed by honorable members

Speaker: NA
Text: in connexion with the work of the Post-

Speaker: NA
Text: master-General's Department. The honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Moore ( Mr Leslie)

Speaker: NA
Text: referred to the operations of the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Broadcasting Commission, and complained

Speaker: NA
Text: that no provision had been made for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Broadcasting Commission team

Speaker: NA
Text: to conduct an Argonauts session at the

Speaker: NA
Text: Perth show. The honorable member said

Speaker: NA
Text: he was aware that I , as Minister, had no

Speaker: NA
Text: control over the Australian Broadcasting

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission programmes. That is correct,

Speaker: NA
Text: but I can assure him that a representative

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Australian Broadcasting Commission

Speaker: NA
Text: is in the chamber, and I know that the

Speaker: NA
Text: remarks made by the honorable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Moore will be noted by him.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honorable member for Banks ( Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Costa) spent all the time available to him in

Speaker: NA
Text: dealing with the possible introduction of the

Speaker: NA
Text: system called Tress. He credited me with

Speaker: NA
Text: having said that the system would improve

Speaker: NA
Text: telegraph services in Australia. I join issue

Speaker: NA
Text: witb him on some of his statements, and

Speaker: NA
Text: that statement which he attributed to me

Speaker: NA
Text: is not correct. I believe I said that the

Speaker: NA
Text: system was being investigated because it

Speaker: NA
Text: appeared that it might improve the service

Speaker: NA
Text: that is available in Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: It will be seen from figures that I shall

Speaker: NA
Text: cite that some improvement in the handling

Speaker: NA
Text: of telegraphic traffic is highly desirable.

Speaker: NA
Text: The latest figures available, which relate to

Speaker: NA
Text: the financial year ended 30th June, 1955,

Speaker: NA
Text: indicate that the operating costs in the

Speaker: NA
Text: handling of telegraphic traffic represent

Speaker: NA
Text: 3s. lOd. of the total expenditure of 5s. 2d.

Speaker: NA
Text: on each telegram. In that period, the

Speaker: NA
Text: average revenue from telegrams was about

Speaker: NA
Text: 3s. 6d. so there is a large labour component

Speaker: NA
Text: in operation costs. Therefore, some method

Speaker: NA
Text: of reducing the handling costs is highly

Speaker: NA
Text: desirable if we are to put those services on

Speaker: NA
Text: a sound economic basis.

Speaker: NA
Text: The system known as Tress, which the

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member described as the tele-

Speaker: NA
Text: phone reperforator electric switching sys-

Speaker: NA
Text: tem, was designed in the United States of

Speaker: NA
Text: America with the object of improving the

Speaker: NA
Text: handling of telegraphic traffic. I believe

Speaker: NA
Text: that it could be fairly described, without

Speaker: NA
Text: going into technicalities, as a method of

Speaker: NA
Text: repeating telegrams over long distances

Speaker: NA
Text: through several repeating stations by auto-

Speaker: NA
Text: matic mechanical means instead of by

Speaker: NA
Text: manual handling. In that respect, it is

Speaker: NA
Text: akin to a system that was introduced in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia by the Postmaster-General's De-

Speaker: NA
Text: partment for the handling of long-range

Speaker: NA
Text: trunk-line telephone calls. That is the

Speaker: NA
Text: transit system, by which it is now possible

Speaker: NA
Text: to connect a call from Perth to a person

Speaker: NA
Text: in Brisbane without any manual handling

Speaker: NA
Text: in the stations in between.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Tress system was developed, as the

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member has said, in 1927, by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Western Union Company in the United

Speaker: NA
Text: States. It is correct that, so far, that is one

Speaker: NA
Text: of the few countries that are operating it.

Speaker: NA
Text: That does not mean that the service is not

Speaker: NA
Text: satisfactory. The Postmaster-General's De-

Speaker: NA
Text: partment has had the system under investi-

Speaker: NA
Text: gation for some time, because of the need

Speaker: NA
Text: for some method of reducing operational

Speaker: NA
Text: costs. The investigation was begun during

Speaker: NA
Text: the regime of my predecessor, the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Richmond ( Mr Anthony). Ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: periments have been conducted in Mel-

Speaker: NA
Text: bourne with a pilot plant, and inquiries

Speaker: NA
Text: have been made into the possible cost of

Speaker: NA
Text: installation. That is the position that has

Speaker: NA
Text: been reached so far in the investigations

Speaker: NA
Text: and, as yet, as I have said in this chamber

Speaker: NA
Text: previously, no firm determination to install

Speaker: NA
Text: the system has been reached. Two depart-

Speaker: NA
Text: mental officers were sent to the United

Speaker: NA
Text: States to investigate the system. They found

Speaker: NA
Text: that it was operating very well, and gave

Speaker: NA
Text: great promise of being worthy of introduc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion into Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: A lot of propaganda about the system

Speaker: NA
Text: has emanated from the secretary of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Third Division Postal Clerks and Tele-

Speaker: NA
Text: graphists Union. He has written to most

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable members, I believe, but many of

Speaker: NA
Text: the statements that he has made are not

Speaker: NA
Text: in accordance with the facts as I have

Speaker: NA
Text: ascertained them for myself. The honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member said that it was estimated that the

Speaker: NA
Text: introduction of this system would reduce the

Speaker: NA
Text: telegraphic staff by about 400. I under-

Speaker: NA
Text: stand that is correct; but that does not mean

Speaker: NA
Text: that there would be wholesale retrenchment

Speaker: NA
Text: in the department because if the system is to

Speaker: NA
Text: be introduced- I repeat that this has not yet

Speaker: NA
Text: been determined-i t will be done gradually,

Speaker: NA
Text: over a period of years. Telegraphists who

Speaker: NA
Text: are now working and who may be displaced

Speaker: NA
Text: at the start will not be retrenched because

Speaker: NA
Text: there will be only a few involved and they

Speaker: NA
Text: will be absorbed in other sections of the

Speaker: NA
Text: department. The department has no in-

Speaker: NA
Text: tention whatsoever of allowing highly trained

Speaker: NA
Text: men who have served it for years to be put

Speaker: NA
Text: out on the streets. Any further reductions

Speaker: NA
Text: in staffing which will be possible as the

Speaker: NA
Text: tem is developed can be taken care of by re-

Speaker: NA
Text: ducing the annual intake into the depart-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. Thus, retrenchment of those already

Speaker: NA
Text: employed will be obviated. When the investi-

Speaker: NA
Text: gations to which 1 have referred are com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pleted, I assure the committee that the introthat

Speaker: NA
Text: duction or non-introduction of the Tress

Speaker: NA
Text: system will be treated as a matter of policy

Speaker: NA
Text: which will be determined not by the depart-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment but by the Government.

Speaker: NA
Text: Before leaving this subject, let me correct

Speaker: NA
Text: a few of the mis-statements that have been

Speaker: NA
Text: made about the Tress system by those who

Speaker: NA
Text: are attempting to decry it. It has been

Speaker: NA
Text: stated that a certain gentleman, who is a

Speaker: NA
Text: telegraph supervisor in Brisbane and who

Speaker: NA
Text: has been to the United States of America,

Speaker: NA
Text: said on his return that he was prepared to

Speaker: NA
Text: report that it should not be installed. This

Speaker: NA
Text: gentleman has had discussions with some

Speaker: NA
Text: of the senior officers of the department, and

Speaker: NA
Text: he has stated that in his opinion-h e has

Speaker: NA
Text: made a written statement to this effect-th e

Speaker: NA
Text: Tress system being operated in the United

Speaker: NA
Text: States by the Western Union Telegraph

Speaker: NA
Text: Company appeared to be 100 per cent, satis-

Speaker: NA
Text: factory on the circuits operated by that

Speaker: NA
Text: company. He said he had discussions with

Speaker: NA
Text: officers of that company who had been with

Speaker: NA
Text: it for over 25 years and that they gave him

Speaker: NA
Text: io understand that the present system was

Speaker: NA
Text: more efficient than the old one. He claimed

Speaker: NA
Text: that the system he saw in operation was

Speaker: NA
Text: efficient, virtually foolproof and labour-

Speaker: NA
Text: saving. I remind the committee that this is

Speaker: NA
Text: the gentleman who is supposed to have come

Speaker: NA
Text: back from America and decried the system.

Speaker: NA
Text: Addressing delegates at the annual con-

Speaker: NA
Text: ference of the Australian Fourth Division

Speaker: NA
Text: Telegraphists Union and the Postal Workers

Speaker: NA
Text: Union, this same gentleman said he was

Speaker: NA
Text: amazed at the efficiency of Tress and was

Speaker: NA
Text: completely confident that competent engi-

Speaker: NA
Text: neers would be able to make the system

Speaker: NA
Text: work satisfactorily here.

Speaker: NA
Text: At this stage, it is appropriate to quote

Speaker: NA
Text: statements made by various men, most of

Speaker: NA
Text: them union officials in the United States,

Speaker: NA
Text: who have had experience of this system.

Speaker: NA
Text: These statements are all more or less

Speaker: NA
Text: commendatory. For instance, the vice-

Speaker: NA
Text: president of the Philadelphia local area

Speaker: NA
Text: stated that the telegraph service was more

Speaker: NA
Text: efficient than ever before. He said that the

Speaker: NA
Text: reduction of the human error factor in this

Speaker: NA
Text: sysmethod had been instrumental in providing

Speaker: NA
Text: greater accuracy in the transmission of

Speaker: NA
Text: public telegram traffic. Mr J. Racz, district

Speaker: NA
Text: chairman of the local 146 C.T.U. in

Speaker: NA
Text: America, said that the Australian Tele-

Speaker: NA
Text: graphists Union had been misinformed, and

Speaker: NA
Text: the service had definitely been improved

Speaker: NA
Text: following the introduction of the reper-

Speaker: NA
Text: forator system. Those statements have

Speaker: NA
Text: been made not by departmental officers but

Speaker: NA
Text: by union representatives in America who

Speaker: NA
Text: have had experience of the system.

Speaker: NA
Text: It has been stated also that one of the

Speaker: NA
Text: reasons why this system is obviously not

Speaker: NA
Text: satisfactory is that it is in use only in the

Speaker: NA
Text: United States and that it is not used by

Speaker: NA
Text: postal authorities anywhere else in the world.

Speaker: NA
Text: The fact is that in Argentina there is an

Speaker: NA
Text: efficient teleprinter reperforator switching

Speaker: NA
Text: system in use on the public telegraph ser-

Speaker: NA
Text: vice, and the postal administrations in

Speaker: NA
Text: South Africa and Western Germany are

Speaker: NA
Text: doing exactly what Australia is doing-the y

Speaker: NA
Text: are making investigations into the system

Speaker: NA
Text: with a view to adopting it if it proves to be

Speaker: NA
Text: satisfactory. In addition, the Indian

Speaker: NA
Text: administration is considering the matter and

Speaker: NA
Text: so also are the telegraph operating com-

Speaker: NA
Text: panies of Canada which are private com-

Speaker: NA
Text: panies. This is a relatively recently

Speaker: NA
Text: developed system, and that is the reason

Speaker: NA
Text: why it has not yet been adopted in other

Speaker: NA
Text: countries outside America. However, it is

Speaker: NA
Text: under urgent investigation by other coun-

Speaker: NA
Text: tries, and the fact that it is not yet adopted

Speaker: NA
Text: by them does not mean that it is not satis-

Speaker: NA
Text: factory.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is the position as I know it in con-

Speaker: NA
Text: nexion with this system. I have set out to

Speaker: NA
Text: give a factual statement in reply to what

Speaker: NA
Text: the honorable member for Banks has said.

Speaker: NA
Text: I repeat that as yet no determination has

Speaker: NA
Text: been given, but I anticipate that within the

Speaker: NA
Text: next few weeks a report will be made to me

Speaker: NA
Text: from the department. Whatever happens

Speaker: NA
Text: after that will depend upon my interpreta-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of that report and the attitude of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government towards it as a policy matter.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honorable member for Kalgoorlie

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr H. V. Johnson) referred to the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: posed new post office at Geraldton for which

Speaker: NA
Text: he has been pressing me and my pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: decessor so strongly over a period of years.

Speaker: NA
Text: The department has stated quite frankly that

Speaker: NA
Text: it knows that there is need for a new post

Speaker: NA
Text: office at Geraldton. In fact, a quite com-

Speaker: NA
Text: prehensive scheme was developed a couple

Speaker: NA
Text: of years ago. The honorable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Kalgoorlie gave the full history of the case

Speaker: NA
Text: and he was quite correct when he said that

Speaker: NA
Text: in the list of new buildings for this year no

Speaker: NA
Text: provision is made for the commencement of

Speaker: NA
Text: the work at Geraldton. 1 very much regret

Speaker: NA
Text: that fact, but the suggestion by the honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member that it would seem to him from

Speaker: NA
Text: a perusal of the list of buildings that are

Speaker: NA
Text: to be commenced in Western Australia,

Speaker: NA
Text: that preference has been given to the con-

Speaker: NA
Text: struction of buildings in electorates repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sented by Government members is com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pletely ill-founded. I do not think he

Speaker: NA
Text: really meant that very seriously. I have

Speaker: NA
Text: before me a list of the new works building

Speaker: NA
Text: programmes for all areas throughout Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia. It sets out the new buildings for

Speaker: NA
Text: the various States, and gives their order

Speaker: NA
Text: of priority. The fact is that because the

Speaker: NA
Text: department has not got all the money for

Speaker: NA
Text: new capital works that it would like to

Speaker: NA
Text: have this year-althoug h in the circum-

Speaker: NA
Text: stances generally it has been given a very

Speaker: NA
Text: generous allocation-som e of the works on'

Speaker: NA
Text: the Western Australian programme have had

Speaker: NA
Text: to be cut out, and at the moment the

Speaker: NA
Text: Geraldton proposal is not being undertaken.

Speaker: NA
Text: Far from that building being omitted from

Speaker: NA
Text: the list in order to make provision for

Speaker: NA
Text: others in electorates represented by honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able members on this side, the fact is that

Speaker: NA
Text: it was taken out of the proposed programme

Speaker: NA
Text: in order to make provision for proceeding

Speaker: NA
Text: with the work of improving the facilities

Speaker: NA
Text: in the main store at Perth.

Speaker: NA
Text: Some little time ago, before I went to

Speaker: NA
Text: Perth, the federal secretary of the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian Postal Workers Union saw me per-

Speaker: NA
Text: sonally and wrote to me about the state of

Speaker: NA
Text: the main store in Perth and referred par-

Speaker: NA
Text: ticular to the conditions under which the

Speaker: NA
Text: men were working. He said that those con-

Speaker: NA
Text: ditions were very bad and that it appeared

Speaker: NA
Text: as though it might be two or three years

Speaker: NA
Text: before any improvement was made. He

Speaker: NA
Text: said that something should be done urgently

Speaker: NA
Text: because of the very bad working conditions

Speaker: NA
Text: in that store, and he asked me particularly

Speaker: NA
Text: to have a look at the store. I had a look

Speaker: NA
Text: at it, and I agree with his statement that

Speaker: NA
Text: the conditions are bad. In summer the

Speaker: NA
Text: building is extremely hot, and during the

Speaker: NA
Text: wet season there is a great deal of stagnant

Speaker: NA
Text: water underneath it. Finally, in my own

Speaker: NA
Text: opinion, there was a very grave fire

Speaker: NA
Text: in this building which housed tens of

Speaker: NA
Text: thojsands of poands worth of departmental

Speaker: NA
Text: equipment. For those reasons, and after

Speaker: NA
Text: discussions with departmental officers, it

Speaker: NA
Text: has bien decided this year to proceed with

Speaker: NA
Text: the third and fourth stages of that main

Speaker: NA
Text: store. This will vastly improve conditions

Speaker: NA
Text: for the postal workers and also make it a

Speaker: NA
Text: much better building for the storage of

Speaker: NA
Text: departmental equipment. I acknowledge

Speaker: NA
Text: that the honorable member for Kalgoorlie

Speaker: NA
Text: has made a case for a new post office at

Speaker: NA
Text: G;raIJton, and as that building happens to

Speaker: NA
Text: b; the next item on the list to be dealt

Speaker: NA
Text: with immediately we get more finance, 1

Speaker: NA
Text: shall not forget his representations.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honorable member for Kalgoorlie

Speaker: NA
Text: mentioned another matter which has also

Speaker: NA
Text: been referred to recently by other honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able members from Western Australia, par-

Speaker: NA
Text: ticularly the honorable member for Can-

Speaker: NA
Text: ning ( Mr Hamilton). It relates to broad-

Speaker: NA
Text: casting reception in Western Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Australian Broadcasting Control Board

Speaker: NA
Text: realizes that reception is not good in certain

Speaker: NA
Text: areas of Western Australia. It has been

Speaker: NA
Text: planning, for some time, to try to effect

Speaker: NA
Text: improvements in that State. This is not an

Speaker: NA
Text: easy task, because of the large sparsely

Speaker: NA
Text: populated areas. In actual fact, the national

Speaker: NA
Text: stations in the eastern States are required

Speaker: NA
Text: to cover a much greater number of people

Speaker: NA
Text: than the stations in Western Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are two ways in which the board

Speaker: NA
Text: hopes to improve reception in Western Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia. One is by increasing the power of

Speaker: NA
Text: the two stations at Perth which, I think,

Speaker: NA
Text: speaking from memory, are 6WF and 6WN;

Speaker: NA
Text: and also by increasing the power of station

Speaker: NA
Text: 6WA at Wagin. The power of this latter

Speaker: NA
Text: station is to be increased to 50,000 watts,

Speaker: NA
Text: and I understand that the work required for

Speaker: NA
Text: that purpose will proceed at some time in

Speaker: NA
Text: this financial year. I had the opportunity,

Speaker: NA
Text: with my friend, the honorable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Canning ( Mr Hamilton), to see that station

Speaker: NA
Text: during my visit to the west. I believe,

Speaker: NA
Text: from representations made to me, that that

Speaker: NA
Text: increase in power will go a long way

Speaker: NA
Text: towards meeting the difficulties at present

Speaker: NA
Text: experienced in that area and towards

Speaker: NA
Text: Kalgoorlie.

Speaker: NA
Text: The north-western part of Western Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: risk tralia presents a much more difficult

Speaker: NA
Text: problem, because it is not economically or

Speaker: NA
Text: technically feasible to service that area by

Speaker: NA
Text: the installation of medium frequency

Speaker: NA
Text: stations. It has to be serviced by short-

Speaker: NA
Text: wave stations, and we find that those

Speaker: NA
Text: stations are subject to a considerable

Speaker: NA
Text: amount of interference by stations operat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing in the Near East. For instance, there

Speaker: NA
Text: are times at which considerable interference

Speaker: NA
Text: is experienced from foreign stations, due to

Speaker: NA
Text: the confused situation regarding the use of

Speaker: NA
Text: channels in the high frequency band and

Speaker: NA
Text: to the fact that certain nations, including

Speaker: NA
Text: the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, fre-

Speaker: NA
Text: quently transmit on channels assigned to

Speaker: NA
Text: other countries. Although representations

Speaker: NA
Text: are made to these countries from time to

Speaker: NA
Text: time, and although some adjustments have

Speaker: NA
Text: been made, the position is still not satisfac-

Speaker: NA
Text: tory from that stand-point.

Speaker: NA
Text: Furthermore, the short-wave transmitters

Speaker: NA
Text: in Perth, which operate on two kilowatts

Speaker: NA
Text: and 10 kilowatts, respectively, are required

Speaker: NA
Text: to broadcast to areas in which some of the

Speaker: NA
Text: overseas stations which are powered with

Speaker: NA
Text: 100 kilowatts are also operating. So I

Speaker: NA
Text: hope it will be appreciated that the problem

Speaker: NA
Text: will not be an easy one. Nevertheless, I

Speaker: NA
Text: can assure honorable members from

Speaker: NA
Text: Western Australia-the y are all interested

Speaker: NA
Text: in this matter-tha t the board is fully cog-

Speaker: NA
Text: nisant of the difficulties of reception in that

Speaker: NA
Text: State and will continue to do its utmost to

Speaker: NA
Text: improve these conditions, consistent with

Speaker: NA
Text: the funds available to it.

Speaker: Mr BIRD
Text: Batman) [10.54] - I desire

Speaker: NA
Text: to deal, under the Estimates for Miscelsomething

Speaker: NA
Text: laneous Services, with the item, " Colombo

Speaker: NA
Text: plan-Technica l assistance and economic

Speaker: NA
Text: development, £4,700,000". In recent

Speaker: NA
Text: months there has been some criticism

Speaker: NA
Text: this plan. According to press reports,

Speaker: NA
Text: was a division in the ranks of the

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment about whether the amount should

Speaker: NA
Text: be reduced. Whether any credence should

Speaker: NA
Text: be given to those reports I do not know,

Speaker: NA
Text: but I am pleased that, if any pressure was

Speaker: NA
Text: exerted by a section of the Ministry

Speaker: NA
Text: have the amount reduced, that pressure

Speaker: NA
Text: was resisted and that it is proposed that

Speaker: NA
Text: the same amount shall be spent on the

Speaker: NA
Text: Colombo plan in this financial year as

Speaker: NA
Text: spent in the last financial year.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think, in view of the controversy that

Speaker: NA
Text: has arisen, not only in the ranks of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Cabinet but also among certain newspapers,

Speaker: NA
Text: that it is necessary to re-state the aim of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Colombo plan. The Colombo plan is

Speaker: NA
Text: a co-operative enterprise under which

Speaker: NA
Text: several of the more developed countries

Speaker: NA
Text: of the world, including Australia, are assist-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing less developed countries in South and

Speaker: NA
Text: South-East Asia to raise their living stan-

Speaker: NA
Text: dards. The attitude of the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Labour party to this project is quite unequi-

Speaker: NA
Text: vocal. I wish to read a resolution which

Speaker: NA
Text: was passed last year by the famous Hobart

Speaker: NA
Text: conference-th e federal conference of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Labour party

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Haworth -Whic h Labour party?

Speaker: Mr BIRD
Text: Ther e is only one federal

Speaker: NA
Text: Labour party. Section 6 of the resolution

Speaker: NA
Text: of the conference reads as follows:-

Speaker: NA
Text: The Labour party advocates generous assist-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance by Australia to Asian peoples suffering from

Speaker: NA
Text: poverty, disease and lack of educational

Speaker: NA
Text: facilities.

Speaker: NA
Text: That statement of Labour party policy is

Speaker: NA
Text: unambiguous. Despite any statement that

Speaker: NA
Text: may be made to the contrary, that is our

Speaker: NA
Text: policy and, as our federal policy, this party

Speaker: NA
Text: is bound to support it.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Colombo plan is a long-range plan.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is not necessarily of only twelve months'

Speaker: NA
Text: duration, and it is impossible to assess the

Speaker: NA
Text: result of the plan in the light of expenditure

Speaker: NA
Text: in one year. It is easy to say, " This sum of

Speaker: NA
Text: nearly £5,000,000 should be devoted to

Speaker: NA
Text: else ". I heard one member of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Country party say that,

Speaker: NA
Text: whilst he believed in assisting people over-

Speaker: NA
Text: seas, he considered that charity began at

Speaker: NA
Text: of home. But I point out that charity does

Speaker: NA
Text: there not end at home. I suggest that this is

Speaker: NA
Text: Gocharity that could well be given by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Government outside the confines

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Commonwealth of Australia itself.

Speaker: NA
Text: At this stage, when the Colombo plan

Speaker: NA
Text: to is being discussed and examined by cer-

Speaker: NA
Text: tain interested parties, I consider that the

Speaker: NA
Text: underlying motive for Australia's support

Speaker: NA
Text: of the plan should once again be enunciated.

Speaker: NA
Text: Some people say tbat its purpose is to make

Speaker: NA
Text: was Australia popular in the East. Others say

Speaker: NA
Text: that it is intended to buy Asian gratitude.

Speaker: NA
Text: Then again, some people say that it is in-

Speaker: NA
Text: tended to stop the spread of communism

Speaker: NA
Text: in Asia. A fourth section of the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munity asserts that it is an assurance for

Speaker: NA
Text: ourselves and an attempt to guarantee us

Speaker: NA
Text: allies in the event of some future conflict.

Speaker: NA
Text: If these are reasons that actuate the Go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment in according support to the plan,

Speaker: NA
Text: we should not let it get out to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Asian people that they are the only

Speaker: NA
Text: reasons. A lot of the good work

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Colombo plan will be undone

Speaker: NA
Text: if the Asian people think that we are sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: porting the plan merely in order to achieve

Speaker: NA
Text: base, materialistic gains for this country.

Speaker: NA
Text: We shall delude ourselves dangerously if

Speaker: NA
Text: we think that the giving of aid for these

Speaker: NA
Text: reasons will gain for us permanent Asian

Speaker: NA
Text: friendship. We have to recognize, if we

Speaker: NA
Text: want to understand the Asian mind, that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Asian countries have developed an

Speaker: NA
Text: abnormal, if quite understandable, sensi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tivity to any signs of patronage on the part

Speaker: NA
Text: of Western Powers.

Speaker: NA
Text: Under the provisions of the Colombo

Speaker: NA
Text: plan, Australia is providing material and

Speaker: NA
Text: technical assistance. I regret to say that

Speaker: NA
Text: that assistance has often been received by

Speaker: NA
Text: the recipients with distrust and suspicion.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is to be deplored, but the fact that

Speaker: NA
Text: some of the Asian people apparently mis-

Speaker: NA
Text: trust our motives in giving them equipment

Speaker: NA
Text: and in providing technical assistance is no

Speaker: NA
Text: reason why we should reduce our aid.

Speaker: NA
Text: Nobody really believes that genuine friend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ship between countries will follow auto-

Speaker: NA
Text: matically the mere act of one country

Speaker: NA
Text: giving another some capital equipment or

Speaker: NA
Text: technical assistance. We must impress on

Speaker: NA
Text: the Asian people that Australia is genuinely

Speaker: NA
Text: sympathetic, to their struggle and their

Speaker: NA
Text: resolve to create new standards of living.

Speaker: NA
Text: If we cannot impress that salient factor on

Speaker: NA
Text: the Asian people, the whole basis of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Colombo plan will fail as far as they are

Speaker: NA
Text: concerned. Unless we can secure their

Speaker: NA
Text: genuine friendship and unless they can be

Speaker: NA
Text: sure that vfe are actuated by humanitarian

Speaker: NA
Text: motives in relation to their problems, all

Speaker: NA
Text: money that we can pour into the Colombo

Speaker: NA
Text: plan will be so much money wasted.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think that the Government and the

Speaker: NA
Text: people of Australia are of the opinion-

Speaker: NA
Text: and the Labour party is certainly of the

Speaker: NA
Text: opinion-tha t we must help the people

Speaker: NA
Text: Asia, and recognize their problems wbich

Speaker: NA
Text: they are unable to combat. We can do

Speaker: NA
Text: our share, as a nation, to assist them in

Speaker: NA
Text: their long and upward struggle. While it

Speaker: NA
Text: is quite easy to support the plan from an

Speaker: NA
Text: emotional or sentimental angle, a sober

Speaker: NA
Text: appraisement of the achievement to date

Speaker: NA
Text: shows that although progress has been made

Speaker: NA
Text: in some directions there is still a tremen-

Speaker: NA
Text: dous amount to be achieved before any

Speaker: NA
Text: large-scale success can be reported. For

Speaker: NA
Text: example, the latest report of the consulta-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive committee-th e reports are issued

Speaker: NA
Text: annually and I always read them avidly

Speaker: NA
Text: when they are distributed to members-

Speaker: NA
Text: shows that in a number of countries there

Speaker: NA
Text: have been improvements in the fields of

Speaker: NA
Text: agriculture, irrigation, power, and com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munity development programmes. Expen-

Speaker: NA
Text: diture on health, education, housing, and

Speaker: NA
Text: other social services has continued to rise,

Speaker: NA
Text: despite financial stringency in a number of

Speaker: NA
Text: countries. The technical assistance scheme

Speaker: NA
Text: has prospered. Last year, for example, a

Speaker: NA
Text: record number of Asian trainees was sent

Speaker: NA
Text: abroad. It would not be a bad idea if we

Speaker: NA
Text: reciprocated the visits of Asian students to

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia by sending a number of Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian students to the Colombo plan coun-

Speaker: NA
Text: tries. The universities of India and Indo-

Speaker: NA
Text: nesia would be only too pleased to receive

Speaker: NA
Text: a token number of Australian students who

Speaker: NA
Text: could take courses at those universities. I

Speaker: NA
Text: am certain that a visit by perhaps only 20

Speaker: NA
Text: or 30 students would create a profound

Speaker: NA
Text: effect on the Eastern mind.

Speaker: NA
Text: Public investment in the Colombo plan

Speaker: NA
Text: countries continues to increase. Last year,

Speaker: NA
Text: it reached £723,000,000 sterling, as com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pared with £540,000,000 sterling in the pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: vious year. Unfortunately, private invest-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, which was intended to be a large

Speaker: NA
Text: factor in the Colombo plan has not risen

Speaker: NA
Text: to the extent to which we hoped it would

Speaker: NA
Text: rise. The United Nations research com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mittee, which made a study of the needs of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Asian people in the investment field,

Speaker: NA
Text: stated that about £5,000,000,000 of new

Speaker: NA
Text: investment annually was required to jolt the

Speaker: NA
Text: the Asian people out of their chronic poverty.

Speaker: NA
Text: Of course, that objective is far outside our

Speaker: NA
Text: capacity to attain, so it would therefore

Speaker: NA
Text: appear that for the time being, in the main,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Colombo plan must rely on public in-

Speaker: NA
Text: vestment and that governmental assistance

Speaker: NA
Text: by the donor nations, including Australia,

Speaker: NA
Text: of must be the main prop of the plan.

Speaker: NA
Text: On the debit side, of which we must take

Speaker: NA
Text: particular notice, because it is of no use to

Speaker: NA
Text: delude ourselves that everything is rosy with

Speaker: NA
Text: the plan, the population in recipient coun-

Speaker: NA
Text: tries is increasing at the rate of 10,000,000

Speaker: NA
Text: persons a year, and this increase has com-

Speaker: NA
Text: plicated the position. When health and

Speaker: NA
Text: social services decrease the infant mortality

Speaker: NA
Text: rate in those countries, as they will in a

Speaker: NA
Text: short space of time, the rate of population

Speaker: NA
Text: increase can be expected to accelerate. The

Speaker: NA
Text: expected reduction in this mortality rate

Speaker: NA
Text: will cause the rate of population increase

Speaker: NA
Text: to rise from 10,000,000 to probably

Speaker: NA
Text: 12,000,000 or 15,000,000 a year. This will

Speaker: NA
Text: more than balance the increase in food pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duction in the area as a result of the plan.

Speaker: NA
Text: In other words, the tangible benefits of the

Speaker: NA
Text: plan are being wiped out by the unfore-

Speaker: NA
Text: seen circumstance, if I may use the term,

Speaker: NA
Text: of a rapid increase in population. To-day,

Speaker: NA
Text: despite the operation of the plan, the tragic

Speaker: NA
Text: fact remains that Asians are eating less per

Speaker: NA
Text: head of population than they were eating

Speaker: NA
Text: before the war. That is tragic because we

Speaker: NA
Text: had hoped that as a result of the plan they

Speaker: NA
Text: would eat more; actually, because of the

Speaker: NA
Text: increase in population, they are eating less.

Speaker: NA
Text: Not only has the increase in population more

Speaker: NA
Text: or less cut across the basic purposes of the

Speaker: NA
Text: plan, but also Asia's booming population

Speaker: NA
Text: has added to the severity of the unemploy-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment problem. Unfortunately, the main

Speaker: NA
Text: impact of the Colombo plan has been in

Speaker: NA
Text: the rural sector, and therefore there has

Speaker: NA
Text: been little effect upon the level of employ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment in recipient countries. Over the last

Speaker: NA
Text: four years India's industrial production has

Speaker: NA
Text: increased by 40 per cent. This is a con-

Speaker: NA
Text: siderable increase in a period of four years.

Speaker: NA
Text: Unfortunately, however, there has been no

Speaker: NA
Text: increase in employment in factories.

Speaker: NA
Text: Because of the introduction of technical

Speaker: NA
Text: processes, production has increased without

Speaker: NA
Text: any increase in the work force.

Speaker: NA
Text: One of the great drawbacks of the

Speaker: NA
Text: -an d it may well founder on this, unless

Speaker: NA
Text: solution is found-i s that the recipient

Speaker: NA
Text: tries suffer from fluctuating prices for their

Speaker: NA
Text: staple raw materials which are exported.

Speaker: NA
Text: For example, in the last year or so, the

Speaker: NA
Text: overseas price of rice fell, which had

Speaker: NA
Text: adverse effect upon the economies of

Speaker: NA
Text: exporting countries. The prices of hemp,

Speaker: NA
Text: copra, raw cotton and tin also fell.

Speaker: NA
Text: the credit side, however, the export prices

Speaker: NA
Text: of rubber, tea and jute were higher than

Speaker: NA
Text: formerly. So there is a fluctuating group of

Speaker: NA
Text: economies whose prosperity, to use the term

Speaker: NA
Text: in a very relative, negative sense, rises or

Speaker: NA
Text: falls in accordance with the world prices

Speaker: NA
Text: received for their exports.

Speaker: NA
Text: Existing statistical data does not permit

Speaker: NA
Text: very any exact and reliable measure of the real

Speaker: NA
Text: economic development under the plan, but

Speaker: NA
Text: the general picture revealed by the last

Speaker: NA
Text: report of the consultative committee shows

Speaker: NA
Text: that there has been but limited progress.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is rather disappointing, but neverthe-

Speaker: NA
Text: less some progress must be reported. One

Speaker: NA
Text: fact: stands out like a beacon on a head-

Speaker: NA
Text: land. Despite the impact of the plan, Asian

Speaker: NA
Text: economies remain precariously poised be-

Speaker: NA
Text: tween low productivity and high and rapidly

Speaker: NA
Text: increasing population. These economies

Speaker: NA
Text: wiil never be able to withstand the effects

Speaker: NA
Text: of a run of bad seasons or a mild world

Speaker: NA
Text: recession. In these circumstances, it is not

Speaker: NA
Text: unreasonable to expect that the Colombo

Speaker: NA
Text: plan in its next phase will have to provide

Speaker: NA
Text: for a high rale of economic aid. There

Speaker: NA
Text: must be a next phase, and further phases,

Speaker: NA
Text: because I should say that the plan will on

Speaker: NA
Text: present indications have to operate for al

Speaker: NA
Text: hast 20 or 30 years if we wish to reach

Speaker: NA
Text: ultimately the basis which we originaUy

Speaker: NA
Text: sought to attain. There will have to be

Speaker: NA
Text: heavier investment in most countries, if

Speaker: NA
Text: productivity and national income are to be

Speaker: NA
Text: further increased. There is urgent need

Speaker: NA
Text: for new capital projects to accommodate

Speaker: NA
Text: the growing labour force. The rate of

Speaker: NA
Text: technical assistance will have to be stepped

Speaker: NA
Text: up if additional foreign aid is lo be ab-

Speaker: NA
Text: sorbed. It is not a bit of good giving aid

Speaker: NA
Text: in the form of either private or govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment investment to provide modern

Speaker: NA
Text: machines if the technical knowledge neces-

Speaker: NA
Text: sary for the operation of those machines

Speaker: NA
Text: is not available locally. I would say that

Speaker: NA
Text: the plan, despite the carping criticism that

Speaker: NA
Text: plan has been directed at it, is based upon

Speaker: NA
Text: a humanitarian aims and it should be sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: counported by all of the Australian people.

Speaker: Mr CLEAVER
Text: Swan) [11.9] - I wish

Speaker: NA
Text: an to direct my comments to Division No. 222,

Speaker: NA
Text: riceDepartment of Health, Item 3, " Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth Council for National Fitness.

Speaker: NA
Text: On £72,500". In the first place, I want to

Speaker: NA
Text: remind the committee, by a quick reference

Speaker: NA
Text: to the history of the national fitness move-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, of the outstanding value of this

Speaker: NA
Text: organization to the nation. The movement

Speaker: NA
Text: was estabhshed under the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: National Fitness Act of 1941. We should

Speaker: NA
Text: appreciate, therefore, that it came into

Speaker: NA
Text: being at a time when the nation was engaged

Speaker: NA
Text: in war. The attention of the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth was, no doubt, centred on the need

Speaker: NA
Text: to build the youth of Australia into young

Speaker: NA
Text: men and women who were as fit as it was

Speaker: NA
Text: possible for them to be, so that from that

Speaker: NA
Text: valuable source the nation might draw

Speaker: NA
Text: people suited to the needs of the times.

Speaker: NA
Text: The National Fitness Act was passed in

Speaker: NA
Text: 1941, and the vote provided by the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth naturally was experimental; but

Speaker: NA
Text: within three years it was increased sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: stantially to £72,500. That was the amount

Speaker: NA
Text: of the vote in 1944. 1 make the point that,

Speaker: NA
Text: from 1944 to the present time, there has

Speaker: NA
Text: been no addition to the vote. So far as I

Speaker: NA
Text: can see, this vote, with the exception of

Speaker: NA
Text: the National Service Training Scheme and

Speaker: NA
Text: several grants to certain organizations, is

Speaker: NA
Text: the only direct contribution to the welfare

Speaker: NA
Text: of the youth of the nation.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have spoken previously in this chamber

Speaker: NA
Text: about the responsibility of the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth to consider the needs of our youth.

Speaker: NA
Text: A government that fails to recognize that

Speaker: NA
Text: young men and women need to be given

Speaker: NA
Text: every encouragement surely overlooks one

Speaker: NA
Text: of its fundamental tasks. Is it possible to

Speaker: NA
Text: justify the attitude, on the part of a federal

Speaker: NA
Text: government, that this vote need not be

Speaker: NA
Text: increased and that the States should do

Speaker: NA
Text: more, either through their education depart-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments or by way of grants to the national

Speaker: NA
Text: fitness organization? Can we justify leaving

Speaker: NA
Text: this field of activity to the States alone?

Speaker: NA
Text: Is it not true that, since the National Fitness

Speaker: NA
Text: Act emanated from the National Parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment here at Canberra, other nationally

Speaker: NA
Text: based plans might well be adopted? I

Speaker: NA
Text: believe that it is. At the present time, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government of Victoria is concerned-an d

Speaker: NA
Text: rightly so-wit h the problem of vandalism.

Speaker: NA
Text: If honorable members have read their news-

Speaker: NA
Text: papers during the last few days, they will

Speaker: NA
Text: share the concern of that government. A

Speaker: NA
Text: grant of £20,000 to train youth leaders is

Speaker: NA
Text: being considered by the Victorian Parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment in connexion with the Youth Orga-

Speaker: NA
Text: nizations Assistance Bill. I affirm that there

Speaker: NA
Text: is no need for a new committee to be

Speaker: NA
Text: appointed in Victoria, or elsewhere, to pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vide assistance of this kind for the youth

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australia. In each State, the national

Speaker: NA
Text: fitness organization has an associated youth

Speaker: NA
Text: committee which acts as an extremely valu-

Speaker: NA
Text: able co-ordinating body with voluntary

Speaker: NA
Text: youth organizations. Victoria, like other

Speaker: NA
Text: States, has a most efficient national fitness

Speaker: NA
Text: organization. Only last Friday evening, I

Speaker: NA
Text: understand that the honorabie member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Wills ( Mr Bryant) was invited to attend the

Speaker: NA
Text: re-opening of a youth centre in the Mel-

Speaker: NA
Text: bourne suburb of Brunswick, and, on Mon-

Speaker: NA
Text: day last, it was my privilege to be taken, as

Speaker: NA
Text: a visitor, to see the same centre at which,

Speaker: NA
Text: on Saturday, no less than 250 young people

Speaker: NA
Text: had been in attendance. 1 was delighted to

Speaker: NA
Text: see this practical approach towards helping

Speaker: NA
Text: the young men and women of what I may,

Speaker: NA
Text: perhaps, describe as a very difficult district,

Speaker: NA
Text: by providing training in hobbies such as

Speaker: NA
Text: photography and woodwork, and in a

Speaker: NA
Text: variety of other ways, to employ their time

Speaker: NA
Text: sensibly and usefully.

Speaker: NA
Text: The vote of £72,500, to which I have

Speaker: NA
Text: referred, has been allocated this year, as in

Speaker: NA
Text: recent years, as follows:-Th e various State

Speaker: NA
Text: councils will absorb £36,954; the State

Speaker: NA
Text: education departments will receive grants

Speaker: NA
Text: totalling £17,000; the universities will re-

Speaker: NA
Text: ceive £12,400; the central administrative

Speaker: NA
Text: office here in Canberra will require £3,396;

Speaker: NA
Text: and the balance of £2,750 has been allo-

Speaker: NA
Text: cated for work within the Australian Capital

Speaker: NA
Text: Territory. It is significant that there is a

Speaker: NA
Text: relationship, in this allocation, to educa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional institutions of the States, in the form

Speaker: NA
Text: of State education departments and uni-

Speaker: NA
Text: versities. I have every respect for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Health (Dr Donald Cameron)

Speaker: NA
Text: and for the national fitness officer in charge

Speaker: NA
Text: of this important division, but I pose the

Speaker: NA
Text: question whether the National Fitness

Speaker: NA
Text: Council is well placed strategically under

Speaker: NA
Text: the administration of the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Health and the Department of Health. Be-

Speaker: NA
Text: cause its operations are related almost

Speaker: NA
Text: entirely to the field of youth, I claim that

Speaker: NA
Text: it could be better administered by the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth Office of Education. If that

Speaker: NA
Text: were so, surely matters pertaining to the

Speaker: NA
Text: activities of youth would receive keener

Speaker: NA
Text: scrutiny and wider understanding.

Speaker: NA
Text: If we turn to the last printed report of

Speaker: NA
Text: the National Fitness Council, we find, at

Speaker: NA
Text: page 5, a reference to Australian represennumber

Speaker: NA
Text: tation at international youth conferences,

Speaker: NA
Text: and in that connexion 1 want to make a

Speaker: NA
Text: very important point. The committee will

Speaker: NA
Text: appreciate that Australian representation

Speaker: NA
Text: international youth conferences is dealt with

Speaker: NA
Text: in the report of a council which is adminislems

Speaker: NA
Text: tered by the Department of Health. If

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable members have an opportunity to

Speaker: NA
Text: look carefully at this section of the report,

Speaker: NA
Text: they will see that this matter has given

Speaker: NA
Text: concern to national fitness authorities

Speaker: NA
Text: some years, particularly the associated

Speaker: NA
Text: committees which act as the co-ordinatnow

Speaker: NA
Text: ing bodies for the major voluntary

Speaker: NA
Text: youth organizations in each State. The

Speaker: NA
Text: report states that the lack of a national

Speaker: NA
Text: youth committee has prevented Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: from being affiliated with the international

Speaker: NA
Text: youth organization known as the World

Speaker: NA
Text: Assembly of Youth, with which other counfor

Speaker: NA
Text: tries of the West, and of the British Comrequirements.

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth, are affiliated. The report states

Speaker: NA
Text: that the second general assembly of

Speaker: NA
Text: World Assembly of Youth was held in Apparently,

Speaker: NA
Text: Singapore in August, 1954, and that

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia was invited to send delegates.

Speaker: NA
Text: Through the Commonwealth Office of Eduto

Speaker: NA
Text: cation and the national fitness organization,

Speaker: NA
Text: two observers were nominated. Only two

Speaker: NA
Text: observers were sent because there were no employed.

Speaker: NA
Text: other organizations from which direct repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sentatives of the youth of this country could

Speaker: NA
Text: be sent. These two observers, on their

Speaker: NA
Text: return to Australia, reported that their

Speaker: NA
Text: participation in the meeting was valuable,

Speaker: NA
Text: but that it was considerably hampered

Speaker: NA
Text: lack of proper status as fully accredited

Speaker: NA
Text: delegates of Australia. I think we must

Speaker: NA
Text: recognize that, because of the relationship

Speaker: NA
Text: of national fitness to education, the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth Office of Education is the most

Speaker: NA
Text: appropriate body to handle national fitness

Speaker: NA
Text: matters.

Speaker: NA
Text: The report of the national fitness

Speaker: NA
Text: organization convinces one of the value

Speaker: NA
Text: this body and indicates something of its

Speaker: NA
Text: achievements. At the same time, it

Speaker: NA
Text: lines the inadequacy of the vote, which,

Speaker: NA
Text: I have said, has remained unaltered since

Speaker: NA
Text: 1944. The report, in referring to thc

Speaker: NA
Text: achievements of the organization, mentions

Speaker: NA
Text: the continuing use of nationalfitnesscamps

Speaker: NA
Text: for leadership training, and by youth

Speaker: NA
Text: organizations. It directs attention to

Speaker: NA
Text: need to promote physical recreation. The of that kind.

Speaker: NA
Text: of school camps and hostels has in-

Speaker: NA
Text: creased in all States. In addition, there has

Speaker: NA
Text: been splendid co-ordination of youth activi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties by each of the State councils. To

Speaker: NA
Text: at support my claim concerning the. inadequacy

Speaker: NA
Text: of the vote, I invite attention to the prob-

Speaker: NA
Text: occasioned by shortage of finance.

Speaker: NA
Text: The various State governments have been

Speaker: NA
Text: called upon to supplement their grants sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: stantially because last year this Parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: for decided that the vote of £72,500 could

Speaker: NA
Text: youth not be increased. New South Wales is

Speaker: NA
Text: providing approximately £72,000, com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pared with the Commonwealth grant, under

Speaker: NA
Text: this vote, of £12,000. The report clearly

Speaker: NA
Text: indicates that the grants to universities

Speaker: NA
Text: which undertake physical education courses

Speaker: NA
Text: are inadequate, as are the grants for State

Speaker: NA
Text: centres and youth head-quarters. Bursaries

Speaker: NA
Text: specialist training are also short of

Speaker: NA
Text: I find, with interest, that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Tasmanian bursary has not been taken

Speaker: NA
Text: the up because it is only £400 per annum.

Speaker: NA
Text: it is not attractive to any one

Speaker: NA
Text: Auswho otherwise would be glad of bursary

Speaker: NA
Text: assistance. The amount of £484 granted

Speaker: NA
Text: each State for books, films, records, and

Speaker: NA
Text: so on, has been wholly expended, indicating

Speaker: NA
Text: that a larger amount could be usefully

Speaker: NA
Text: In conclusion, I wish to recommend, first,

Speaker: NA
Text: the transfer of the National Fitness Division

Speaker: NA
Text: from the administration of the Department

Speaker: NA
Text: by of Health to that of the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: Office of Education. Secondly, that the

Speaker: NA
Text: vote of £72,500 for nationalfitnessshould

Speaker: NA
Text: be increased, at the first opportunity, to at

Speaker: NA
Text: least £150,000. I suggest, further, that

Speaker: NA
Text: grants to youth organizations should be

Speaker: NA
Text: substantially increased. The grants of

Speaker: NA
Text: £3,000 in the State of New South Wales

Speaker: NA
Text: and of £600 in my own State of Western

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia represent only a very small pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: of portion of the funds needed to provide

Speaker: NA
Text: equipment and facilities for the training

Speaker: NA
Text: underof young people. I further recommend

Speaker: NA
Text: as greater activity among underprivileged

Speaker: NA
Text: children, and the children of immigrants

Speaker: NA
Text: and aborigines, so that camps may be orga-

Speaker: NA
Text: nized and free equipment and even uni-

Speaker: NA
Text: forms may be issued to boy scouts, girl

Speaker: NA
Text: the guides, and members of other organizations

Speaker: NA
Text: My final recommendation is that youth

Speaker: NA
Text: head-quarters should be set up in every

Speaker: NA
Text: capital city. Surely this country warrants

Speaker: NA
Text: central head-quarters for national fitness

Speaker: NA
Text: organizations to provide council and com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mittee rooms, theatrettes and central youth

Speaker: NA
Text: group offices. These are essential in a is

Speaker: NA
Text: country such as Australia, which has many duties?

Speaker: NA
Text: privileges and opportunities available to

Speaker: NA
Text: train young men and women. I urge the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government to recognize the need for makable

Speaker: NA
Text: ing special grants, even greater than the

Speaker: NA
Text: figures I have recommended, so that there

Speaker: NA
Text: may rise in every capital city of the as follows:-

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth youth head-quarters in

Speaker: NA
Text: which a work second to none may be done.

Speaker: NA
Text: Progress reported.

Speaker: NA
Text: House adjourned at 11.23 p.m.

Text: Australian A r m y Camps.

Speaker: Mr LUCHETTI
Text: the Minister f o r the

Speaker: NA
Text: A r m y , upon notice-

Speaker: NA
Text: 1. What was the number of Army camps in use

Speaker: NA
Text: and under the control of the Army at the end

Speaker: NA
Text: of World War II.?

Speaker: NA
Text: 2. How many camps are now in use?

Speaker: NA
Text: 3. What is the number of camps under the

Speaker: NA
Text: control of the Army not being used for Army

Speaker: NA
Text: purposes?

Speaker: NA
Text: 4. How many camps were sold or leased by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Department of the Army?

Speaker: NA
Text: 5. What was the total cost of the construction

Speaker: NA
Text: of all Army camps, and what has been realized

Speaker: NA
Text: from the sale of Army camps and establishments?

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Cramer -Th e answers to the honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member's questions are as follows:-

Speaker: NA
Text: 1. Eighty-three, each of which provided accom-

Speaker: NA
Text: modation for more than 1,000 personnel. There

Speaker: NA
Text: were also numerous smaller temporary transit

Speaker: NA
Text: camps established at various strategic locations

Speaker: NA
Text: providing accommodation for lesser numbers.

Speaker: NA
Text: 2. Twenty-three wholly and three partly used

Speaker: NA
Text: (Wacol, Queensland; Woodside, South Australia;

Speaker: NA
Text: and Wallgrove, New South Wales).

Speaker: NA
Text: 3. The number of camps which are nominally

Speaker: NA
Text: under Army control, in that the sites were acquired

Speaker: NA
Text: statefor my department's use, and which are now

Speaker: NA
Text: occupied on a permissive occupancy basis by

Speaker: NA
Text: other Commonwealth departments is: Three

Speaker: NA
Text: wholly and three partly. There are no Army

Speaker: NA
Text: personnel in these camps wholly occupied by

Speaker: NA
Text: other departments and responsibility for repairs

Speaker: NA
Text: and maintenance and general administration rests

Speaker: NA
Text: with the occupying department, or is shared pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: portionately where camps are jointly occupied.

Speaker: NA
Text: 4. Fifty-four camps, each of which provided

Speaker: NA
Text: accommodation for more than 1,000 personnel,

Speaker: NA
Text: have been disposed of by my department in that

Speaker: NA
Text: control thereof has been passed to the appropriate

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth authority, i.e. the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: Disposals Commission, which functioned until July,

Speaker: NA
Text: 1949, and since that date the Department of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Interior, in which the custody of all Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth property is vested.

Speaker: NA
Text: 5. (a) Construction costs -Th e total cost of

Speaker: NA
Text: the construction of all Army camps is not known.

Speaker: NA
Text: Camps were constructed by many agencies during

Speaker: NA
Text: the war-generall y under conditions of extreme

Speaker: NA
Text: urgency, (b) Realizations from disposals -I t is

Speaker: NA
Text: regretted the information desired is not available

Speaker: NA
Text: within my department. Since the war the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth Disposals Commission (until July,

Speaker: NA
Text: and then the Department of the Interior have

Speaker: NA
Text: arranged the disposal of Army assets and any

Speaker: NA
Text: moneys obtained have been paid into Consolidated

Speaker: NA
Text: Revenue. To obtain the desired information from

Speaker: NA
Text: the various authorities concerned would require

Speaker: NA
Text: detailed research involving many man hours. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: regretted that staff are not available for the task.
